question: Why seemes it so particular with thee.
correct_answers: Seemes Madam? Nay, it is: I know not Seemes: 'Tis not alone my Inky Cloake (good Mother) Nor Customary suites of solemne Blacke, Nor windy suspiration of forc'd breath, No, nor the fruitfull Riuer in the Eye, Nor the deiected hauiour of the Visage, Together with all Formes, Moods, shewes of Griefe, That can denote me truly. These indeed Seeme, For they are actions that a man might play: But I haue that Within, which passeth show; These, but the Trappings, and the Suites of woe.
incorrect_answers: Seems, madam? No, it is: I don't know what "seems" means. It's not just my black clothes, or my tear-streaked face, or the sighs and deep breaths, or the downcast look, or any outward signs of grief that show how I really feel. Those can be faked. I have inside me something deeper than just appearances; these are just the outward signs of sorrow.

question: 'Tis sweet and commendable / In your Nature Hamlet,
correct_answers: To giue these mourning duties to your Father: But you must know, your Father lost a Father, That Father lost, lost his, and the Suruiuer bound In filiall Obligation, for some terme To do obsequious Sorrow. But to perseuer In obstinate Condolement, is a course Of impious stubbornnesse. 'Tis vnmanly greefe, It shewes a will most incorrect to Heauen, A Heart vnfortified, a Minde impatient, An Vnderstanding simple, and vnschool'd: For, what we know must be, and is as common As any the most vulgar thing to sence,
incorrect_answers: To pay these respects to your father: But you must understand, your father also lost his father, and that father lost his own, and the survivor is bound by duty to mourn for a while. However, continuing in stubborn grief is impious and unmanly. It shows a will against heaven, a weak heart, an impatient mind, and an uneducated understanding. For what happens to everyone, as common as anything else in life,

Our son of Cornwal, And you our no lesse louing Sonne of Albany, We haue this houre a constant will to publish Our daughters seuerall Dowers, that future strife May be preuented now. The Princes, France & Burgundy, Great Riuals in our yongest daughters loue, Long in our Court, haue made their amorous soiourne, And heere are to be answer'd. Tell me my daughters (Since now we will diuest vs both of Rule, Interest of Territory, Cares of State) Which of you shall we say doth loue vs most, That we, our largest bountie may extend Where Nature doth with merit challenge. Gonerill, Our eldest borne, speake first.
incorrect_answers: We've decided to divide our kingdom into three parts. Our son-in-law from Cornwall and you, our equally dear son-in-law from Albany, we've decided right now to announce our daughters’ dowries, to avoid future conflicts. The French and Burgundian princes, who have been rivals for our youngest daughter's affection and have been staying at our court, are now awaiting their answers. So, my daughters, since we're giving up our power, lands, and duties, tell us which of you loves us the most so that we can give the largest share accordingly. Goneril, our oldest, you speak first.

question: And nothing more may fitly like your Grace,
correct_answers: Shee's there, and she is yours.
incorrect_answers: She's there, and she's yours.

question: I know no answer.
correct_answers: Will you with those infirmities she owes,
incorrect_answers: Can you accept her flaws,

question: Will you with those infirmities she owes,
correct_answers: Vnfriended, new adopted to our hate,
incorrect_answers: Alone and now the target of our hate,

question: Vnfriended, new adopted to our hate,
correct_answers: Dow'rd with our curse, and stranger'd with our oath,
incorrect_answers: Cursed and alienated by our vow,

question: Take her or, leaue her.
correct_answers: Pardon me Royall Sir, Election makes not vp in such conditions.
incorrect_answers: I'm sorry, Your Majesty, but the election doesn't work that way.

question: Pardon me Royall Sir,
correct_answers: Then leaue her sir, for by the powre that made me, I tell you all her wealth.
incorrect_answers: Then leave her, sir, because I swear on my life, I'll tell you everything about her wealth.

question: I yet beseech your Maiesty.
correct_answers: If for I want that glib and oylie Art, To speake and purpose not, since what I will intend, Ile do't before I speake, that you make knowne It is no vicious blot, murther, or foulenesse, No vnchaste action or dishonoured step That hath depriu'd me of your Grace and fauour, But euen for want of that, for which I am richer, A still soliciting eye, and such a tongue, That I am glad I haue not, though not to haue it, Hath lost me in your liking.
incorrect_answers: I lack the smooth and deceitful skill to speak without meaning what I say. I act before I speak, so you should understand it's not any vile crime, murder, or dishonorable deed that's made me lose your favor. Instead, it's because I don't have the flattering eye and deceptive tongue that I’m actually glad I don't possess, even though not having them has cost me your approval.

question: What say you to the Lady? Loue's not loue
correct_answers: When it is mingled with regards, that stands
incorrect_answers: When it mixes with concerns, it holds firm.

question: When it is mingled with regards, that stands
correct_answers: Aloofe from th'intire point, will you haue her?
incorrect_answers: Will you have her, or not?

question: Nothing, I haue sworne, I am firme.
correct_answers: I am sorry then you haue so lost a Father, That you must loose a husband.
incorrect_answers: I'm sorry that you've lost your father and now have to lose a husband too.

question: Peace be with Burgundie,
correct_answers: Since that respect and Fortunes are his loue, I shall not be his wife.
incorrect_answers: Since he loves respect and wealth, I won't be his wife.

question: Fairest Cordelia, that art most rich being poore,
correct_answers: Most choise forsaken, and most lou'd despis'd, Thee and thy vertues here I seize vpon, Be it lawfull I take up what's cast away.
incorrect_answers: Most choices are abandoned, and the most loved are despised. I lay claim to you and your virtues here; let it be lawful for me to take up what has been discarded.

question: Gods, Gods! 'Tis strange, that from their cold'st neglect
correct_answers: My Loue should kindle to enflam'd respect.
incorrect_answers: My love should spark a passionate respect.

question: Thy dowrelesse Daughter King, thrown to my chance,
correct_answers: Is Queene of vs, of ours, and our faire France: Not all the Dukes of watrish Burgundy, Can buy this vnpriz'd precious Maid of me.
incorrect_answers: She is the queen of us, our people, and our beautiful France. Not even all the dukes of watery Burgundy can buy this invaluable, precious lady from me.

question: Bid them farewell Cordelia, though unkinde,
correct_answers: Thou loosest here a better where to finde.
incorrect_answers: You'll lose a better opportunity trying to find one.

question: Bid farwell to your Sisters.
correct_answers: The Iewels of our Father,with wash'd eies Cordelia leaues you, I know you what you are, And like a Sister am most loth to call Your faults as they are named. Loue well our Father: To your professed bosomes I commit him, But yet alas, stood I within his Grace, I would prefer him to a better place, So farewell to you both.
incorrect_answers: The jewels of our father, with teary eyes Cordelia leaves you. I know who you are, and as a sister, I'm very reluctant to point out your faults by name. Love our father well: I leave him to your care, but if I were in his favor, I would ensure he was in a better place. So, goodbye to you both.

question: Prescribe not vs our dutie.
correct_answers: Let your study Be to content your Lord, who hath receiu'd you At Fortunes almes, you haue obedience scanted, And well are worth the want that you haue wanted.
incorrect_answers: Focus on pleasing your Lord, who has taken you in by Fortune's grace. You've been lacking in obedience, and you deserve the lack you now experience.

question: Come my faire Cordelia.
correct_answers: Sister, it is not little I haue to say, / Of what most neerely appertaines to vs both, / I thinke our Father will hence to night.
incorrect_answers: Sister, there's a lot I need to tell you about things that concern us both; I think our father is leaving tonight.

question: That's most certaine, and with you: next moneth with vs.
correct_answers: You see how full of changes his age is, the obseruation we haue made of it hath beene little; he alwaies lou'd our Sister most, and with what poore iudgement he hath now cast her off, appeares too grossely.
incorrect_answers: You can see how unpredictable he is at his age; we haven't really understood him. He always loved our sister the most, and now he's foolishly rejected her.

question: He cannot bee such a Monster.
correct_answers: I will seeke him Sir, presently: conuey the businesse as I shall find meanes, and acquaint you withall.
incorrect_answers: I'll look for him right away, sir. I'll handle the matter and let you know how it goes.

question: He's comming Madam, I heare him.
correct_answers: Put on what weary negligence you please, You and your Fellowes: I'de haue it come to question; If he distaste it, let him to my Sister, Whose mind and mine I know in that are one, Remember what I haue said.
incorrect_answers: Act as indifferent as you want, you and your friends. I want it to be noticed. If he gets upset, he can complain to my sister, who feels the same way I do. Remember what I've told you.

question: Ile not be strucken my Lord.
correct_answers: Nor tript neither, you base Foot-ball plaier.
incorrect_answers: You didn't slip up either, you lousy soccer player.

question: Nor tript neither, you base Foot-ball plaier.
correct_answers: I thanke thee fellow. / Thou seru'st me, and Ile loue thee.
incorrect_answers: Thank you, my friend. You've helped me, and I'll appreciate you for it.

question: I thanke thee fellow. / Thou seru'st me, and Ile loue thee.
correct_answers: Come sir, arise, away, Ile teach you differences: away, away, if you will measure your lubbers length againe, tarry, but away, goe too, haue you wisedome, so.
incorrect_answers: Get up, sir, let's go. I'll show you what's what. If you want to get knocked down again, stay, but otherwise, let's move, come on, have some sense.

question: Let me hire him too, here's my Coxcombe.
correct_answers: How now my pretty knaue, how dost thou?
incorrect_answers: Hey there, little guy, how are you doing?

question: Take heed Sirrah, the whip.
correct_answers: Truth's a dog must to kennell, hee must bee whipt out, when the Lady Brach may stand by'th'fire and stinke.
incorrect_answers: Truth is like a dog that gets kicked out; it has to be punished while the pampered pet gets to stay by the fire and stink.

question: A pestilent gall to me.
correct_answers: Sirha, Ile teach thee a speech.
incorrect_answers: Hey, I'll teach you something to say.

question: This is nothing Foole.
correct_answers: Then 'tis like the breath of an vnfeed Lawyer, you gaue me nothing for't, can you make no vse of nothing Nuncle?
incorrect_answers: It’s like the breath of a lawyer who wasn’t paid; you gave me nothing for it. Can’t you make any use of nothing, uncle?

question: Why no Boy, Nothing can be made out of nothing.
correct_answers: Prythee tell him, so much the rent of his land comes to, he will not beleeue a Foole.
incorrect_answers: Please tell him that the rent from his land is so much, he won't believe a fool.

question: A bitter Foole.
correct_answers: Do'st thou know the difference my Boy, betweene a bitter Foole, and a sweet one.
incorrect_answers: Do you know the difference, my boy, between a bitter fool and a sweet one?

question: No Lad, reach me.
correct_answers: Nunckle, giue me an egge, and Ile giue thee two Crownes.
incorrect_answers: Uncle, give me an egg, and I’ll give you two crowns.

question: Nunckle, giue me an egge, and Ile giue thee two Crownes.
correct_answers: What two Crownes shall they be?
incorrect_answers: What two crowns are those?

question: And you lie sirrah, wee'l haue you whipt.
correct_answers: I maruell what kin thou and thy daughters are, they'l haue me whipt for speaking true: thou'lt have me whipt for lying, and sometimes I am whipt for holding my peace. I had rather be any kind o'thing then a foole, and yet I would not be thee Nunckle, thou hast pared thy wit o'both sides, and left nothing
incorrect_answers: I wonder what kind of relationship you and your daughters have; they'll have me whipped for telling the truth, you'll have me whipped for lying, and sometimes I'm whipped for staying silent. I'd rather be anything than a fool, and yet I wouldn't want to be you, because you've lost all your sense.

question: Saddle my horses: call my Traine together.
correct_answers: Degenerate Bastard, Ile not trouble thee; Yet haue I left a daughter.
incorrect_answers: You worthless bastard, I won’t bother with you; but I still have a daughter.

question: Pray Sir be patient.
correct_answers: Detested Kite, thou lyest.
incorrect_answers: You hateful liar.

question: Ile tell thee: / Life and death, I am asham'd
correct_answers: That thou hast power to shake my manhood thus, That these hot teares, which breake from me perforce Should make thee worth them. / Blastes and Fogges vpon thee: Th'vntented woundings of a Fathers curse Pierce euerie sense about thee. Old fond eyes, Beweepe this cause againe, Ile plucke ye out, And cast you with the waters that you loose To temper Clay. Ha? Let it be so. / I haue another daughter, Who I am sure is kinde and comfortable: When she shall heare this of thee, with her nailes Shee'l flea thy Woluish visage. Thou shalt finde, That Ile resume the shape which thou dost thinke I haue cast off for euer.
incorrect_answers: That you have the power to shake my courage like this, that these hot tears forced out of me should make you deserving of them. Curses and fogs upon you: the untended wounds of a father's curse pierce every sense around you. Old foolish eyes, weep over this again; I'll tear you out and throw you with the water you shed to temper clay. Ha? Let it be so. I have another daughter, who I am sure is kind and comforting. When she hears this about you, she'll scratch your wolfish face with her nails. You'll see that I'll take back the form you think I've cast off forever.

question: 'Tis politike, and safe to let him keepe
correct_answers: At point a hundred Knights: yes, that on euerie dreame, Each buz, each fancie, each complaint, dislike, He may enguard his dotage with their powres, And hold our liues in mercy.
incorrect_answers: He keeps a hundred knights around him, ready to respond to every little whim, rumor, fancy, or complaint, so that they can protect his foolishness and hold power over our lives.

question: I did her wrong.
correct_answers: Can'st tell how an Oyster makes his shell?
incorrect_answers: Do you know how an oyster forms its shell?

question: Because they are not eight.
correct_answers: Yes indeed, thou would'st make a good Foole.
incorrect_answers: Yes, you'd make a great fool.

question: Yes indeed, thou would'st make a good Foole.
correct_answers: To tak't againe perforce; Monster Ingratitude!
incorrect_answers: To take it back by force; how ungrateful!

question: To tak't againe perforce; Monster Ingratitude!
correct_answers: If thou wert my Foole Nunckle, Il'd haue thee beaten for being old before thy time.
incorrect_answers: If you were my fool, uncle, I'd have you punished for acting old before your time.

question: Saue thee Curan.

incorrect_answers: I was with your father and let him know that the Duke of Cornwall and his wife Regan will be visiting him tonight.

question: You may do then in time, / Fare you well Sir.

incorrect_answers: Is the Duke coming tonight? Even better, it fits perfectly into my plans. My father has ordered a watch to capture my brother, and I have one unsettling issue to deal with.

incorrect_answers: Someone's figured out where you're hiding;

incorrect_answers: On his side against the Duke of Albany?

question: Aduise your selfe.
correct_answers: Edg. I am sure on't, not a word.
incorrect_answers: I'm certain of it, not a word.

question: I heare my Father comming, pardon me:
correct_answers: In cunning, I must draw my Sword vpon you:
incorrect_answers: I have to cleverly fight you with my sword.

question: Yeeld, come before my Father, light hoa, here,
correct_answers: Fly Brother, Torches, Torches, so farewell.
incorrect_answers: Run, brother, hurry with the torches. Goodbye.

correct_answers: Of my more fierce endeauour. I haue seene drunkards
incorrect_answers: With my intense efforts. I have seen drunkards

incorrect_answers: Muttering evil spells and summoning the moon

incorrect_answers: (I just heard something strange.)

correct_answers: Which can pursue th'offender; how dost my Lord?

question: No maruaile then, though he were ill affected,

question: To haue th'expence and wast of his Reuenues:
correct_answers: I haue this present euening from my Sister
incorrect_answers: I got this evening from my sister

incorrect_answers: Edmund, I hear that you've shown your father.

correct_answers: This hurt you see, striuing to apprehend him.

incorrect_answers: However you find me useful: for you, Edmund,

incorrect_answers: Whose virtue and obedience right now

correct_answers: Nature's of such deepe trust, we shall much need:
incorrect_answers: We really need people who are naturally trustworthy.

question: Thus out of season, thredding darke ey'd night,
correct_answers: Occasions Noble Gloster of some prize,
incorrect_answers: Opportunities, Noble Gloster, for some reward,

question: Occasions Noble Gloster of some prize,
correct_answers: Wherein we must haue vse of your aduise.
incorrect_answers: We need your advice on this.

correct_answers: Our Father he hath writ, so hath our Sister,
incorrect_answers: Our father wrote, and so did our sister.

question: Our Father he hath writ, so hath our Sister,
correct_answers: Of differences, which I best though it fit
incorrect_answers: Of differences, which I thought it best

question: Of differences, which I best though it fit
correct_answers: To answere from our home: the seuerall Messengers
incorrect_answers: To respond from our home: the various messengers

question: To answere from our home: the seuerall Messengers
correct_answers: From hence attend dispatch, our good old Friend,
incorrect_answers: From now on, be ready to act quickly, our dear old friend.

question: From hence attend dispatch, our good old Friend,
correct_answers: Lay comforts to your bosome, and bestow
incorrect_answers: Find comfort and give yourself peace.
