incorrect_answers: We need your advice for our plans.

question: Your needfull counsaile to our businesses,
correct_answers: Which craues the instant vse.
incorrect_answers: Which requires immediate use.

question: Why then I care not for thee.
correct_answers: If I had thee in Lipsbury Pinfold, I would make thee care for me.
incorrect_answers: If I had you locked up, I would make you pay attention to me.

question: Strike you slaue: stand rogue, stand you neat slaue, strike.
correct_answers: Helpe hoa, murther, murther.
incorrect_answers: Help! Murder! Murder!

question: I am scarce in breath my Lord.
correct_answers: No Maruell, you haue so bestir'd your valour, you cowardly Rascall, nature disclaimes in thee: a Taylor made thee.
incorrect_answers: No wonder you’ve been acting so brave, you cowardly scoundrel; even nature disowns you—a tailor must have created you.

question: None of these Rogues, and Cowards But Aiax is there Foole.
correct_answers: Fetch forth the Stocks? You stubborne ancient Knaue, you reuerent Bragart, Wee'l teach you.
incorrect_answers: Get the stocks. You stubborn old fool, you arrogant braggart, we'll teach you a lesson.

question: Why Madam, if I were your Fathers dog,
correct_answers: You should not vse me so.
incorrect_answers: You shouldn't treat me like this.

question: You should not vse me so.
correct_answers: Sir, being his Knaue, I will.
incorrect_answers: Sir, since I am his servant, I will.

question: This is a Fellow of the selfe same colour,
correct_answers: Our Sister speakes of. Come, bring away the Stocks.
incorrect_answers: Our sister mentioned them. Come on, bring the stocks.

question: Let me beseech your Grace, not to do so,
correct_answers: The King his Master, needs must take it ill
incorrect_answers: The King, his master, will surely take it badly.

question: The King his Master, needs must take it ill
correct_answers: That he so slightly valued in his Messenger, Should haue him thus restrained.
incorrect_answers: He had so little regard for his messenger, and now he's keeping him trapped like this.

question: My Sister may recieue it much more worsse,
correct_answers: To haue her Gentleman abus'd, assaulted.
incorrect_answers: To have her gentleman mistreated and attacked.

question: I am sorry for thee friend, 'tis the Duke pleasure,
correct_answers: Whose disposition all the world well knowes Will not be rub'd nor stopt, Ile entreat for thee.
incorrect_answers: Everyone knows he has a stubborn nature and won't be swayed, but I'll try to speak on your behalf.

question: Pray do not Sir, I haue watch'd and trauail'd hard,
correct_answers: Some time I shall sleepe out, the rest Ile whistle: A good mans fortune may grow out at heeles: Giue you good morrow.
incorrect_answers: Sometimes I'll sleep through it, and the rest I'll keep myself entertained. A good man's luck can turn around unexpectedly. Have a good day.

question: Good King, that must approue the common saw,
correct_answers: Thou out of Heauens benediction com'st To the warme Sun.
incorrect_answers: You've left heaven's blessing for the warmth of the sun.

question: Thou out of Heauens benediction com'st
correct_answers: To the warme Sun. Approach thou Beacon to this vnder Globe.
incorrect_answers: Come closer, warm sun, light up this world below.

question: By Iuno, I sweare I.
correct_answers: They durst not do't: They could not, would not do't: 'tis worse then murther, To do vpon respect such violent outrage: Resolue me with all modest haste, which way Thou might'st deserue, or they impose this vsage.
incorrect_answers: They didn't dare do it. They couldn't and wouldn't. It's worse than murder to do such violent acts out of respect. Tell me as quickly and politely as you can, how you might have deserved this, or why they treated you this way.

question: My Lord, when at their home
correct_answers: I did commend your Highnesse Letters to them,
incorrect_answers: I gave them your letters, Your Highness.

question: Ere I was risen from the place, that shewed
correct_answers: My dutie kneeling, came there a reeking Poste,
incorrect_answers: As I was bowing, a breathless messenger arrived,

question: Stew'd in his haste, halfe breathlesse, painting forth
correct_answers: From Gonerill his Mistris, salutations;
incorrect_answers: Greetings from his mistress, Gonerill;

question: Deliver'd Letters spight of intermission,
correct_answers: Which presently they read; on those contents
incorrect_answers: They read it right away, and the contents...

question: do make their Children blind,
correct_answers: But Fathers that beare bags,
incorrect_answers: But fathers who carry money,

question: shall see their children kind.
correct_answers: Fortune that arrant whore,
incorrect_answers: Fortune, that shameless trickster,

question: nere turns the key to th'poore.
correct_answers: But for all this thou shalt haue as many Dolors for thy
incorrect_answers: But despite all this, you will still have as many sorrows for your

question: Daughters, as thou canst tell in a yeare.
correct_answers: Oh how this Mother swels vp toward my heart!
incorrect_answers: Oh, how this emotion swells up inside me!

question: Vengeance, Plague, Death, Confusion:
correct_answers: Fiery? What quality? Why Gloster, Gloster, I'ld speake with the Duke of Cornewall, and his wife.
incorrect_answers: Fiery? What's wrong? Gloster, I want to speak with the Duke of Cornwall and his wife.

question: The King would speake with Cornwall, / The deere Father Would with his Daughter speake, commands, tends, seruice, Are they inform'd of this? My breath and blood:
correct_answers: Fiery? The fiery Duke, tell the hot Duke that---- No, but not yet, may be he is not well, Infirmity doth still neglect all office, Whereto our health is bound, we are not our selues, When Nature being opprest, commands the mind To suffer with the body; Ile forbeare, And am fallen out with my more headier will, To take the indispos'd and sickly fit, For the sound man. Death on my state: wherefore Should he sit heere? This act perswades me, That this remotion of the Duke and her Is practise only. Giue me my Seruant forth; Goe tell the Duke, and's wife, Il'd speake with them: Now, presently: bid them come forth and heare me, Or at their Chamber doore Ile beate the Drum, Till it crie sleepe to death.
incorrect_answers: Angry? The angry Duke, tell the hot-headed Duke that—No, not yet, maybe he’s not well. Illness often neglects all duties that our health binds us to. We’re not ourselves when our body’s struggling and commands the mind to suffer with it. I'll wait and have abandoned my impulsive desire to treat the sick as if they were well. My life's at stake; why should he sit here? This act convinces me that removing the Duke and her is just a scheme. Bring my servant out; go tell the Duke and his wife I want to speak with them now. Tell them to come out and hear me, or I’ll bang the drum at their door until it drives them mad.

question: I would haue all well betwixt you.
correct_answers: Oh me my heart! My rising heart! But downe.
incorrect_answers: Oh my heart! It's pounding! Calm down.

question: Haile to your Grace.
correct_answers: Kent here set at liberty.
incorrect_answers: Kent has been released.

question: I am glad to see your Highnesse.
correct_answers: Regan, I thinke your are. I know what reason I haue to thinke so, if thou should'st not be glad.
incorrect_answers: Regan, I believe you are. I have my reasons for thinking this, if you weren’t happy.

question: Regan, I thinke your are. I know what reason I haue to thinke so, if thou should'st not be glad.
correct_answers: I would diuorce me from thy Mother Tombe, Sepulchring an Adultresse. O are you free?
incorrect_answers: I would separate myself from your mother's grave, burying an adulteress. Are you free?

question: Who comes here? O Heauens!
correct_answers: If you do loue old men; if your sweet sway Allow Obedience; if you your selues are old, Make it your cause: Send downe, and take my part.
incorrect_answers: If you care about old men; if your kind influence commands respect; if you yourselves are old, take up my cause and support me.

question: At your choice Sir.
correct_answers: I prythee Daughter do not make me mad, I will not trouble thee my Child; farewell: Wee'l no more meete, no more see one another.
incorrect_answers: Please, daughter, don't drive me crazy. I won't bother you anymore, my child. Goodbye. We'll never see each other again.

question: I gaue you all.
correct_answers: And in good time you gaue it.
incorrect_answers: And you gave it just in time.

question: My Lord, entreate him by no meanes to stay.
correct_answers: Alacke the night comes on, and the high windes Do sorely ruffle, for many Miles about There's scarce a Bush.
incorrect_answers: Oh no, night is falling, and the strong winds are causing a huge commotion, and there's hardly a bush in sight for miles around.

question: Shut up your doores my Lord, 'tis a wil'd night.
correct_answers: My Regan counsels well: come out oth'storme.
incorrect_answers: Regan makes a good point; let's get out of the storm.

question: One minded like the weather, most vnquietly.
correct_answers: I know you: Where's the King?
incorrect_answers: I know you. Where's the King?

question: Sir, I do know you, And dare vpon the warrant of my note Commend a deere thing to you. There is diuision (Although as yet the face of it is couer'd With mutuall cunning) 'twixt Albany, and Cornwall: Who haue, as who haue not, that their great Starres Thron'd and set high; Seruants, who seeme no lesse, Which are to France the Spies and Speculations Intelligent of our State. What hath bin seene, Either in snuffes, and packings of the Dukes, Or the hard Reine which both of them hath borne Against the old kinde King; or something deeper, Whereof (perchance) these are but furnishings.
correct_answers: I will talke further with you.
incorrect_answers: I'll talk more with you later.

question: I will talke further with you.
correct_answers: No, do not: For confirmation that I am much more Then my out-wall; open this Purse, and take What it containes. If you shall see Cordelia, (As feare not but you shall) shew her this Ring, And she will tell you who that Fellow is That yet you do not know. Fye on this Storme,
incorrect_answers: No, don't: To prove that I'm more than what you see on the outside; open this purse and take what's inside. If you meet Cordelia (and don't worry, you will), show her this ring and she will tell you who I really am. This storm is terrible,

question: Few words, but to effect more then all yet;
correct_answers: That when we haue found the King, in which your pain
incorrect_answers: When we find the King, where your efforts

question: That when we haue found the King, in which your pain
correct_answers: That way, Ile this: He that first lights on him,
incorrect_answers: I'll go this way: whoever finds him first,

question: Holla the other.
correct_answers: Blow windes, & crack your cheeks; Rage, blow
incorrect_answers: Blow winds, and crack your cheeks; rage on, blow

question: Blow windes, & crack your cheeks; Rage, blow
correct_answers: O Nunkle, Court holy-water in a dry house, is better
incorrect_answers: Hey Uncle, flattery in a tough situation is better

question: O Nunkle, Court holy-water in a dry house, is better
correct_answers: Rumble thy belly full: spit Fire, spowt Raine:
incorrect_answers: Rumble all you want: spit fire, pour rain:

question: Rumble thy belly full: spit Fire, spowt Raine:
correct_answers: He that has a house to put's head in, has a good
incorrect_answers: Anyone with a roof over their head is fortunate.

question: Here is the place my Lord, good my Lord enter,
correct_answers: The tirrany of the open night's too rough For Nature to endure.
incorrect_answers: The harshness of the open night is too much for anyone to handle.

question: Thou think'st 'tis much that this contentious storme Inuades vs to the skin so:
correct_answers: 'tis to thee, But where the greater malady is fixt, The lesser is scarce felt. Thou'dst shun a Beare, But if they flight lay toward the roaring Sea, Thou'dst meete the Beare i'th'mouth, when the mind's free, The bodies delicate: the tempest in my mind, Doth from my sences take all feeling else, Saue what beates there, Filliall ingratitude, Is it not as this mouth should teare this hand For lifting food too't? But I will punish home; No, I will weepe no more; in such a night, To shut me out? Poure on, I will endure: In such a night as this? O Regan, Gonerill, Your old kind Father, whose franke heart gaue all, O that way madnesse lies, let me shun that: No more of that.
incorrect_answers: It's like this, when there's a greater problem, you barely notice the smaller ones. You would avoid a bear, but if your escape led to the roaring sea, you’d face the bear head-on. When the mind is strained, the body suffers: the storm in my mind numbs all other feelings except the pain of being wronged by my children. Isn't it like this mouth tearing this hand for feeding it? But I will pay them back. No, I won't cry anymore; on a night like this, to shut me out? Let it pour, I will endure it. On a night like this? Oh, Regan, Goneril, your old kind father who gave you everything, that way lies madness; let me avoid that: no more of that.

question: Prythee go in thy selfe, seeke thine owne ease,
correct_answers: This tempest will not giue me leaue to ponder On things would hurt me more, but Ile goe in, In Boy, go first. You houselesse pouertie, Nay get thee in; Ile pray, and then Ile sleepe. Poore naked wretches, where so ere you are
incorrect_answers: This storm won’t let me think about things that could hurt me even more, so I’m going inside. Boy, you go in first. Homeless poverty, no, get inside; I'll pray and then sleep. Poor, naked souls, wherever you are.

question: Now all the plagues that in the pendulous ayre
correct_answers: Hang fated o're mens faults, light on thy Daughters.
incorrect_answers: May your unlucky fate befall your daughters for their mistakes.

question: He hath no Daughters Sir.
correct_answers: Death Traitor, nothing could haue subdu'd Nature To such a lownesse, but his vnkind Daughters.
incorrect_answers: You traitor, only his cruel daughters could have brought him so low.

question: Is it the fashion, that discarded Fathers,
correct_answers: Should haue thus little mercy on their flesh:
incorrect_answers: Should have so little compassion for their own bodies:

question: Iudicious punishment, 'twas this flesh begot
correct_answers: Those Pelicane Daughters.
incorrect_answers: Those ungrateful daughters.

question: Let me aske you one word in priuate.
correct_answers: Importune him once more to go my Lord, His wits begin t' vnsettle.
incorrect_answers: Ask him to leave again, my Lord; he's starting to lose his mind.

question: O cry you mercy, Sir:
correct_answers: Noble Philosopher, your company.
incorrect_answers: Wise scholar, your presence.

question: With him; I will keepe still with my Philosopher.
correct_answers: Good my Lord, sooth him: / Let him take the Fellow.
incorrect_answers: Please, my Lord, calm him down: let him take the man.

question: I may be censured, that Nature thus giues way to Loyaltie, something feares mee to thinke of.
correct_answers: I now perceiue, it was not altogether your Brothers euill disposition made him seeke his death: but a prouoking merit set a-worke by a reprouable badnesse in himselfe.
incorrect_answers: I realize now that it wasn't just your brother's bad nature that made him want to die, but also a commendable trait set into motion by his own reprehensible behavior.

question: Go with me to the Dutchesse.
correct_answers: If the matter of this Paper be certain, you haue mighty businesse in hand.
incorrect_answers: If the information in this document is true, you have a big task ahead of you.

question: True or false, it hath made thee Earle of Gloucester: seeke out where thy Father is, that hee may bee ready for our apprehension.
correct_answers: If I finde him comforting the King, it will
incorrect_answers: If I catch him consoling the King, it will

question: Fraterretto cals me, and tells me Nero is an Angler in the Lake of Darknesse: pray Innocent, and beware the foule Fiend.
correct_answers: Prythee Nunkle tell me, whether a madman be a Gentleman, or a Yeoman.
incorrect_answers: Please, Uncle, tell me if a madman is a gentleman or a commoner.

question: A King, a King.
correct_answers: No, he's a Yeoman, that ha's a Gentleman to his Sonne: for hee's a mad Yeoman that sees his Sonne a Gentleman before him.
incorrect_answers: No, he's a yeoman with a son who's a gentleman; it would be crazy if he saw his son become a gentleman before him.

question: Here Sir, but trouble him not, his wits are gon.
correct_answers: Good friend, I prythee take him in thy armes; I haue ore-heard a plot of death vpon him: There is a Litter ready, lay him in't,
incorrect_answers: Good friend, please take him in your arms; I’ve overheard a plan to kill him. There’s a litter ready, put him in it.

question: Plucke out his eyes.
correct_answers: Leaue him to my displeasure. Edmond, keepe you our Sister company: the reuenges wee are bound to take vppon your Traitorous Father, are not fit for your beholding.
incorrect_answers: Leave him to my anger. Edmund, stay with our sister: the revenge we have to exact on your traitorous father isn't something you should see.

question: To whose hands/ You haue sent the Lunaticke King: Speake.
correct_answers: I haue a Letter guessingly set downe Which came from one that's of a newtrall heart, And not from one oppos'd.
incorrect_answers: I have a letter that seems to be from someone with a neutral stance, not an adversary.

question: Wherefore to Douer? Let him answer that.
correct_answers: I am tyed to'th'Stake, / And I must stand the Course.
incorrect_answers: I’m stuck here and just have to face whatever comes.

question: Hold your hand, my Lord:
correct_answers: I haue seru'd you euer since I was a Childe: But better seruice haue I neuer done you, Then now to bid you hold.
incorrect_answers: I've served you since I was a child, but I've never done you a greater favor than telling you to stop now.

question: Oh I am slaine: my Lord, you haue one eye left To see some mischefe on him. Oh.
correct_answers: Lest it see more, preuent it; Out vilde gelly: Where is thy luster now?
incorrect_answers: Stop it before it gets worse; out with revolting goo: where's your shine now?

question: Out treacherous Villaine,
correct_answers: Thou call'st on him, that hates thee. It was he That made the ouerture of thy Treasons to vs:
incorrect_answers: You're calling on him, but he hates you. He was the one who exposed your treachery to us.

question: O my Follies! then Edgar was abus'd,
correct_answers: Kinde Gods, forgiue me that, and prosper him.
incorrect_answers: Kind gods, forgive me for that and help him succeed.

question: Yet better thus, and knowne to be contemn'd,
correct_answers: Then still contemn'd and flatter'd, to be worst: The lowest, and most deiected thing of Fortune, Stands still in esperance, liues not in feare: The lamentable change is from the best, The worst returnes to laughter. Welcome then, Thou vnsubstantiall ayre that I embrace: The Wretch that thou hast blowne vnto the worst, Owes nothing to thy blasts.
incorrect_answers: Even when despised and flattered, the lowest and most unfortunate still have hope and don’t live in fear. The saddest changes come from those who had the best; the worst can find joy again. So welcome, insubstantial air I hold, the wretch you’ve knocked down owes you nothing.

question: O my good Lord,
correct_answers: I haue bene your Tenant, / And your Fathers Tenant, these fourescore yeares.
incorrect_answers: I've been your tenant, and your father's tenant, for eighty years.

question: Away, get thee away: good Friend be gone,
correct_answers: Thy comforts can do me no good at all, Thee, they may hurt.
incorrect_answers: Your comforts don't help me at all; they might actually hurt you.

question: Old. 'Tis poore mad Tom.
correct_answers: Edg. And worse I may be yet: the worst is not,So long as we can say this is the worst.
incorrect_answers: Edgar: Things can still get worse; it’s not truly the worst as long as we can say it is.

question: Oldm. Madman, and beggar too.
correct_answers: Glou. He has some reason, else he could not beg.
incorrect_answers: Gloucester: He must have a reason; otherwise, he wouldn't be begging.

question: Welcome my Lord. I meruell our mild husband	Not met vs on the way.
correct_answers: Now, where's your Master?
incorrect_answers: Where is your boss now?

question: Madam within, but neuer man so chang'd: I told him of the Army that was Landed: He smil'd at it. I told him you were comming, His answer was, the worse. Of Glosters Treachery, And of the loyall Seruice of his Sonne When I inform'd him, then he call'd me Sot, And told me I had turn'd the wrong side out: What most he should dislike, seemes pleasant to him; What like, offensiue.
correct_answers: Then shall you go no further.
incorrect_answers: That's as far as you go.

question: Then shall you go no further.
correct_answers: It is the Cowish terror of his spirit That dares not vndertake: Hee'l not feele wrongs Which tye him to an answer: our wishes on the way May proue effects. Backe Edmond to my Brother, Hasten his Musters, and conduct his powres. I must change names at home, and giue the Distaffe Into my Husbands hands. This trustie Seruant Shall passe betweene vs: ere long you are like to heare
incorrect_answers: He's too afraid to take action; he won't respond to insults. Our hopes may turn into reality. Go back to my brother, hurry his troops, and lead his forces. I need to switch roles at home and give domestic duties to my husband. This trusted servant will go between us. Soon, you'll hear from us.

question: A Mistresses command. Weare this; spare speech, Decline your head. This kisse, if it durst speake Would stretch thy Spirits vp into the ayre: Conceiue, and fare thee well.
correct_answers: Bast. Yours in the rankes of death.
incorrect_answers: I'll be with you in death's ranks.

question: Bast. Yours in the rankes of death.
correct_answers: Gon. My most deere Gloster.
incorrect_answers: Gon. My dearest Gloucester.

question: Stew. Madam, here come's my Lord.
correct_answers: Gon. I haue beene worth the whistle.
incorrect_answers: I've been worth the attention.

question: Gon. I haue beene worth the whistle.
correct_answers: Alb. Oh Gonerill, You are not worth the dust which the rude winde Blows in your face.
incorrect_answers: Alb. Oh Gonerill, you aren't even worth the dust that the harsh wind blows in your face.

question: Alb. Oh Gonerill, You are not worth the dust which the rude winde Blows in your face.
correct_answers: Gon. Milke-Liuer'd man, That bear'st a cheeke for blowes, a head for wrongs, Who hast not in thy browes an eye-discerning Thine Honor, from thy suffering.
incorrect_answers: You cowardly man, who takes slaps on the face and endures insults, without the wisdom to see the difference between your honor and your suffering.

question: Gon. Milke-Liuer'd man, That bear'st a cheeke for blowes, a head for wrongs, Who hast not in thy browes an eye-discerning Thine Honor, from thy suffering.
correct_answers: Alb. See thy selfe diuell: Proper deformitie seemes not in the Fiend So horrid as in woman.
incorrect_answers: Albany: Look at yourself, you're like a devil. Ugliness looks much worse in a woman than it does in a demon.

question: Alacke, 'tis he: why he was met euen now As mad as the vext Sea, singing alowd, Crown'd with ranke Fenitar, and furrow weeds, With Hardokes, Hemlocke, Nettles, Cuckoo flowres, Darnell, and all the idle weedes that grow In our sustaining Corne. A Centery send forth; Search every Acre in the high-growne field, And bring him to our eye.
correct_answers: What can mans wisedom In the restoring his bereaued Sense; he that helpes him, / Take all my outward worth.
incorrect_answers: What can human wisdom do to restore his lost senses; whoever helps him can have all my possessions.

question: Faith he is poasted hence on serious matter:
correct_answers: It was great ignorance, Glousters eyes being out
incorrect_answers: It was really foolish, considering Gloucester was blind.

question: I must needs after him, Madam,with my Letter.
correct_answers: Our troopes set forth to morrow, stay with vs:
incorrect_answers: Our troops leave tomorrow; stay with us.

question: I may not Madam:
correct_answers: My Lady charg'd my dutie in this busines.
incorrect_answers: My lady assigned me this task.

question: Madam, I had rather----
correct_answers: I know your Lady do's not loue her Husband, I am sure of that: and at her late being heere, She gaue strange Eliads, and most speaking lookes To Noble Edmund. I know you are of her bosome.
incorrect_answers: I know your lady doesn't love her husband, I'm sure of it. When she was here recently, she gave strange messages and very telling looks to Noble Edmund. I know she's close to you.

question: So may it be indeed.
correct_answers: Me thinkes thy voyce is alter'd, and thou speak'stIn better phrase, and matter then thou did'st.
incorrect_answers: I think your voice has changed, and you're speaking more eloquently and sensibly than before.

question: Me thinkes thy voyce is alter'd, and thou speak'stIn better phrase, and matter then thou did'st.
correct_answers: Y'are much deceiu'd: In nothing am I chang'dBut in my Garments.
incorrect_answers: You're really mistaken. I'm the same as always, just in different clothes.

question: Y'are much deceiu'd: In nothing am I chang'dBut in my Garments.
correct_answers: Me thinkes y'are better spoken.
incorrect_answers: I think you speak better.

question: O you mighty Gods!
correct_answers: This world I do renounce,and in your sights
incorrect_answers: I reject this world, and in front of you all

question: Gone Sir, farewell:
correct_answers: And yet I know not how conceit may rob
incorrect_answers: I don't know how an idea might take away

question: From the dread Somnet of this Chalkie Bourne
correct_answers: Looke vp a height, the shrill-gorg'd Larke so farre
incorrect_answers: Look up high, the lark with its piercing voice so far away

question: Looke vp a height, the shrill-gorg'd Larke so farre
correct_answers: Cannot be seene, or heard: Do but looke up.
incorrect_answers: You can't see or hear it. Just look up.

question: Alacke, I haue no eyes:
correct_answers: Is wretchednesse depriu'd that benefit
incorrect_answers: Is misery deprived of that benefit?

question: Is wretchednesse depriu'd that benefit
correct_answers: To end it selfe by death? 'Twas yet some comfort,
incorrect_answers: To end it all with death? There was some comfort in that.

question: To end it selfe by death? 'Twas yet some comfort,
correct_answers: When misery could beguile the Tyranrs rage,
incorrect_answers: When suffering could calm the tyrant's anger.

question: When misery could beguile the Tyranrs rage,
correct_answers: And frustrate his proud will.
incorrect_answers: And ruin his arrogant plans.

question: Giue me your arme.
correct_answers: Vp, so: How is't? Feele you your Legges? You stand.
incorrect_answers: Okay, how are you feeling? Can you stand on your legs?

question: This is aboue all strangeness
correct_answers: Vpon the crowne o'th'Cliffe. What thing was that
incorrect_answers: On the edge of the cliff. What was that?

question: As I stood heere below, me thought his eyes
correct_answers: Were two full Moones: he had a thousand Noses,
incorrect_answers: There were two full moons; he had a thousand noses.

question: Were two full Moones: he had a thousand Noses,
correct_answers: Hornes wealk'd, and waued like the enraged Sea:
incorrect_answers: Horns moved and waved like the angry sea.

question: Hornes wealk'd, and waued like the enraged Sea:
correct_answers: It was some Fiend: Therefore thou happy Father,
incorrect_answers: It was a demon: So you should be happy, Father,

question: It was some Fiend: Therefore thou happy Father,
correct_answers: Thinke that the cleerest Gods, who make them Honors
incorrect_answers: Consider that the most honorable gods

question: Thinke that the cleerest Gods, who make them Honors
correct_answers: Of mens Impossibilities, haue preserued thee.
incorrect_answers: Men's limitations have kept you safe.

question: I do remember now: henceforth Ile beare
correct_answers: Affliction, till it do cry out it selfe
incorrect_answers: Suffering, until it cries out on its own

question: Affliction, till it do cry out it selfe
correct_answers: Enough, enough, and dye. That thing you speake of,
incorrect_answers: That's enough, just let it go. The thing you're talking about,

question: Enough, enough, and dye. That thing you speake of,
correct_answers: I tooke it for a man: often 'twould say
incorrect_answers: I thought it was a man; it often said

question: I tooke it for a man: often 'twould say
correct_answers: The Fiend, the Fiend, he led me to that place.
incorrect_answers: The devil, the devil, he guided me there.

question: I know that voice.
correct_answers: Ha! Gonerill with a white beard? They flatter'd me like a Dogge, and told mee I had the white hayres in my Beard, ere the blacke ones were there. To say I, and no, to euery thing that I said: I, and no too, was no good Diuinity. When the raine came to wet me once, and the winde to make me chatter: when the Thunder would not peace at my bidding, there I found 'em, there I smelt 'em out. Go too, they are not men o'their words; they told me, I was euery thing: 'Tis a Lye, I am not Agu-proofe.
incorrect_answers: Ha! Goneril with a white beard? They treated me like a fool, flattering me and saying I had white hairs in my beard before the black ones even appeared. They agreed with everything I said, which was no good. When the rain soaked me and the wind made me shiver, when the thunder didn't stop at my command, that's when I realized the truth. They're not true to their word; they told me I was invincible: It's a lie, I'm not immune to sickness.

question: I see it feelingly.
correct_answers: What, art mad? A man may see how this world goes, with no eyes. Looke with thine eares: See how yond Iustice railes vpon yond simple theefe. Hearke in thine eare: Change places, and handy-dandy, which is the Iustice, which is the theefe: Thou hast seene a Farmers dogge barke at a Beggar?
incorrect_answers: Are you crazy? You can see how the world works without using your eyes. Listen and observe: Notice how that judge treats the simple thief. Just imagine: switch their places, and suddenly, who’s the judge and who’s the thief? Have you ever seen a farmer's dog bark at a beggar?

question: Thou, Rascall Beadle, hold thy bloody hand: why dost thou lash that Whore? Strip thy owne backe, thou hotly lusts to vse her in that kind, for which thou whip'st her. The Usurer hangs the Cozener.
correct_answers: Thorough tatter'd cloathes great Vices do appeare: Robes, and Furr'd gownes hide all. Place sinnes with Gold, and the strong Lance of Iustice, hurtlesse breakes: Arme it in ragges, a Pigmies straw do's pierce it. None do's offend, none, I say none, Ile able 'em; take that of me my Friend, who haue the power to seale th'accusers lips.
incorrect_answers: Through tattered clothes, major vices are exposed: Robes and furred gowns cover everything. Arm sins with gold and the powerful lance of justice breaks harmlessly; dress it in rags, even a pygmy's straw pierces it. No one offends, no one, I say no one. Believe that from me, my friend, who has the power to silence the accusers.

question: Get thee glasse-eyes, and like a scuruy Politician, seeme to see the things thou dost not. Now, now, now, now.
correct_answers: Pull off my Bootes: harder, harder, so.
incorrect_answers: Take off my boots. Harder, that's it.

question: Thou must be patient; we came crying hither:
correct_answers: Thou know'st, the first time that we smell the Ayre
incorrect_answers: You know, the first time we smell the air

question: Thou know'st, the first time that we smell the Ayre
correct_answers: We wawle, and cry. I will preach to thee: Marke.
incorrect_answers: We wail and cry. I'll preach to you: Listen up.

question: Alacke, alacke the day.
correct_answers: When we are borne, we cry that we are come
incorrect_answers: When we're born, we cry because we've arrived.

question: No rescue? What, a Prisoner? I am euen
correct_answers: The Naturall Foole of Fortune. Vse me well,
incorrect_answers: I'm just a pawn of fate. Treat me kindly.

question: You shall haue any thing.
correct_answers: No Seconds? All my selfe?
incorrect_answers: No backup? It's just me?

question: You are a Royall one, and we obey you.
correct_answers: Then there's life in't. Come, and you get it, / You shall / get it by running: Sa, sa, sa, sa.
incorrect_answers: There's still a chance. If you want it, you'll have to chase it: Go, go, go, go.

question: A proclaim'd prize: most happie
correct_answers: That eyelesse head of thine, was first fram'd flesh
incorrect_answers: That eyeless head of yours was once made of flesh

question: That eyelesse head of thine, was first fram'd flesh
correct_answers: To raise my fortunes. Thou old, vnhappy Traitor, Breefely thy selfe remember: the Sword is out That must destroy thee.
incorrect_answers: To improve my luck. You old, unlucky traitor, remember who you are quickly: the sword is out to destroy you.

question: Now let thy friendly hand
correct_answers: Put strength enough too't.
incorrect_answers: Put enough effort into it.

question: Wherefore, bold Pezant, Dar'st thou support a publish'd Traitor? Hence, Least that th'infection of his fortune take Like hold on thee. Let go his arme.
correct_answers: Chill not let go Zir, / Without vurther 'casion.
incorrect_answers: I won't let go, sir, without more reason.

question: Let go Slaue, or thou dy'st.
correct_answers: Good Gentleman goe your gate, and let poore volke passe: and 'chud ha'bin zwaggerd out of my life, 'twould not ha'bin zo long as 'tis, by a vortnight. Nay, come not neere th'old man: keepe out che vor'ye, or ice try whither your Costard, or my Ballow be the harder; chill be plaine with you.
incorrect_answers: Good sir, go on your way and let the poor folk pass. If I had been pushed out of my life, it wouldn't have lasted as long as it has by two weeks. No, don't come near the old man. Stay away from me, or I'll find out whether your head or my stick is harder; I'll be blunt with you.

question: Sit you downe Father: rest you.
correct_answers:
Let's see these Pockets; the Letters that he speakes of
May be my Friends: hee's dead; I am onely sorry
He had no other Deathsman.
incorrect_answers: Let's check his pockets; the letters he mentioned might be from my friends. He's dead, and I only regret that someone else didn't kill him.

question:
Let's see these Pockets; the Letters that he speakes of
May be my Friends: hee's dead; I am onely sorry
He had no other Deathsman.
correct_answers:
LEt our reciprocall vowes be remembred. You haue manie
opportunities to cut him off: if your will want not, time and
place will be fruitfully offer'd. There is nothing done. If hee
returne the Conqueror, then am I the Prisoner, and his bed,
my Gaole, from the loathed warmth whereof, deliuer me, and
supply the place for your Labour.

Your (Wife, so I would say) affectionate Seruant.
incorrect_answers:
Let's remember our mutual promises. You have many chances to take him out: if you have the will, the right time and place will come. Nothing has been done yet. If he comes back victorious, I'm his prisoner, and his bed is my jail. Free me from the place I hate and take his place.

Your (Wife, as I should say) devoted servant.

question:
LEt our reciprocall vowes be remembred. You haue manie
opportunities to cut him off: if your will want not, time and
place will be fruitfully offer'd. There is nothing done. If hee
returne the Conqueror, then am I the Prisoner, and his bed,
my Gaole, from the loathed warmth whereof, deliuer me, and
supply the place for your Labour.

Your (Wife, so I would say) affectionate Seruant.
correct_answers:
The King is mad: / How stiffe is my vilde sense
That I stand vp, and haue ingenious feeling
Of my huge Sorrowes? Better I were distract,
So should my thoughts be seuer'd from my greefes,
And woes, by wrong imaginations loose
The knowledge of themselues.
incorrect_answers: The King has gone mad. How dull is my sense of awareness that I stand here, fully aware and feeling my immense sorrows? It would be better if I were insane, so my thoughts would be separated from my griefs and my woes would lose their awareness through confused thoughts.

question: O thou good Kent,
correct_answers: How shall I liue and worke To match thy goodnesse? My life will be too short, And euery measure faile me.
incorrect_answers: How can I live and work to match your goodness? My life will be too short, and every effort will fall short.

question: How shall I liue and worke To match thy goodnesse? My life will be too short, And euery measure faile me.
correct_answers: To be acknowledg'd Madam is ore-pai'd, All my reports go with the modest truth, Nor more, nor clipt, but so.
incorrect_answers: Being acknowledged, Madam, is more than enough. All my reports stick to the modest truth, no more and no less.

question: To be acknowledg'd Madam is ore-pai'd, All my reports go with the modest truth, Nor more, nor clipt, but so.
correct_answers: Be better suited, These weedes are memories of those worser houres: I prythee put them off.
incorrect_answers: Wear something more appropriate; these clothes are reminders of bad times. Please take them off.

question: Be better suited, These weedes are memories of those worser houres: I prythee put them off.
correct_answers: Pardon deere Madam, Yet to be knowne shortens my made intent, My boone I make it, that you know me not, Till time and I, think meet.
incorrect_answers: Excuse me, dear Madam, but revealing myself too soon ruins my plans. My request is that you don't know who I am until the right time.

question: Pardon deere Madam, Yet to be knowne shortens my made intent, My boone I make it, that you know me not, Till time and I, think meet.
correct_answers: Then be't so my good Lord: How do's the King?
incorrect_answers: Alright then, my good Lord. How is the King doing?

question: Madam sleepes still.
correct_answers: O you kind Gods! Cure this great breach in his abused Nature, Th'vntun'd and iarring senses, O winde vp, Of this childe-changed Father.
incorrect_answers: Oh kind gods! Heal the deep damage to his tormented mind, bring harmony to his troubled senses, and restore this father who has been altered by his children's actions.

question: O you kind Gods! Cure this great breach in his abused Nature, Th'vntun'd and iarring senses, O winde vp, Of this childe-changed Father.
correct_answers: So please your Maiesty, That we may wake the King, he hath slept long?
incorrect_answers: If it pleases Your Majesty, should we wake the King? He's been asleep for a long time.

question: O looke vpon me Sir
correct_answers: And hold your hand in benediction o're me, You must not kneele.
incorrect_answers: And bless me without kneeling.

question: Pray do not mocke me
correct_answers: I am a very foolish fond old man, Fourescore and vpward, Not an houre more, nor lesse: And to deale plainely, I feare I am not in my perfect mind.
incorrect_answers: I'm a very foolish, sentimental old man, over eighty years old, not an hour more or less. And to be honest, I fear I'm not in my right mind.

question: Be your teares wet? / Yes faith: I pray weepe not
correct_answers: If you haue poyson for me, I will drinke it: I know you do not loue me, for your Sisters Haue (as I do remember) done me wrong.
incorrect_answers: If you have poison for me, I'll drink it. I know you don't love me because, if I remember correctly, your sisters have wronged me.

question: You see is kill'd in him:
correct_answers: desire him to go in, / Trouble him no more
incorrect_answers: ask him to go inside and don't bother him anymore

question: Gentlemen, and Souldiers.
correct_answers: Know of the Duke if his last purpose hold, / Or whether since he is aduis'd by ought / To change the course, he's full of alteration, / And selfe reprouving, bring his constant pleasure.
incorrect_answers: Ask the Duke if he’s sticking to his latest decision, or if he’s considering changing his mind after some advice—he’s always changing his plans and second-guessing himself.

question: Our Sisters man is certainely miscarried.
correct_answers: 'Tis to be doubted Madam.
incorrect_answers: It's doubtful, ma'am.

question: Now sweet Lord,
correct_answers: You know the goodnesse I intend vpon you: / Tell me but truly, but then speake the truth, / Do you not loue my Sister?
incorrect_answers: You know the kindness I plan to show you. Just tell me honestly, do you love my sister?

question: But haue you neuer found my Brothers way,
correct_answers: To the fore-fended place?
incorrect_answers: To the protected place?

question: I neuer shall endure her, deere my Lord
correct_answers: Be not familiar with her.
incorrect_answers: Don't get close to her.

question: 'Tis most conuenient, pray go with vs.
correct_answers: Oh ho, I know the Riddle, I will goe.
incorrect_answers: Oh, I get the puzzle; I'm going.

question: Heere Father, take the shadow of this Tree
correct_answers: For your good hoast: pray that the right may thriue:
incorrect_answers: For your good host: pray that the right may succeed.

question: Away old man, giue me thy hand, away:
correct_answers: King Lear hath lost, he and his Daughter tane, Giue me thy hand: Come on.
incorrect_answers: King Lear has lost, and he and his daughter have been captured. Give me your hand; let's go.

question: No further Sir, a man may rot euen heere.
correct_answers: What in ill thoughts againe? / Men must endure Their going hence, euen as their comming hither, Ripenesse is all come on.
incorrect_answers: Are you having dark thoughts again? People have to accept their leaving this world just like their arrival. Maturity is everything, come on.

question: Some Officers take them away: good guard,
correct_answers: Vntill their greater pleasures first be knowne That are to censure them.
incorrect_answers: Until their higher-ups decide what to do with them.

question: We are not the first,
correct_answers: Who with best meaning haue incurr'd the worst: For thee oppressed King I am cast downe, My selfe could else out-frowne false Fortunes frowne.
incorrect_answers: Those who meant well ended up with the worst outcomes. For you, oppressed King, I am devastated; otherwise, I could have faced bad luck without flinching.

question: Sir, you haue shew'd to day your valiant straine
correct_answers: And Fortune led you well: you haue the Captiues
incorrect_answers: Luck was on your side: you've captured them.

question: I do require them of you so to vse them,
correct_answers: As we shall find their merites, and our safety
incorrect_answers: Based on their merits and our safety.

question: Sir, I thought it fit,
correct_answers: To send the old and miserable King
incorrect_answers: To send the old and unhappy King

question: That's as we list to grace him.
correct_answers: Methinkes our pleasure might haue bin demanded
incorrect_answers: I think they could have asked us if we wanted to join.

question: In his owne grace he doth exalt himselfe,
correct_answers: More then in your addition.
incorrect_answers: More than just your title.

question: Lady I am not well, else I should answere
correct_answers: From a full flowing stomack. Generall, Take thou my Souldiers, prisoners, patrimony, Dispose of them, of me, the walls is thine: Witnesse the world, that I create thee heere My Lord, and Master.
incorrect_answers: With a full heart, General, take my soldiers, prisoners, and inheritance. They are yours, and so am I. The city is yours. Let the world bear witness that I make you my Lord and Master here.

question: Nor in thine Lord.
correct_answers: Halfe-blooded fellow, yes.
incorrect_answers: Yes, you're a half-blooded guy.

question: Let the Drum strike, and proue my title thine.
correct_answers: Stay yet,heare reason: Edmund, I arrest thee On capitall Treason; and in thy arrest, This guilded Serpent: for your claime faire Sisters, I bare it in the interest of my wife, 'Tis she is sub-contracted to this Lord, And I her husband contradict your Banes. If you will marry, make your loues to me, My Lady is bespoke.
incorrect_answers: Wait, listen to reason: Edmund, I'm arresting you for high treason; and with you, this deceitful person. As for your claim, noble sisters, I uphold it on behalf of my wife. She is already engaged to this lord, and as her husband, I oppose your marriage banns. If you want to marry, direct your intentions to me, as my lady is already promised.

question: There's my exchange, what in the world hes
correct_answers: That names me Traitor, villain-like he lies,
incorrect_answers: Calling me a traitor is a total lie.

question: Call by the Trumpet: he that dares approach;
correct_answers: On him, on you, who not, I will maintaine
incorrect_answers: I'll defend him, you, anyone.

question: If any man of qualitie or degree, within the
correct_answers: lists of the Army, will maintaine vpon Edmund, supposed
incorrect_answers: Challenges Edmund to a fight.

question: Aske him his purposes, why he appeares
correct_answers: Vpon this Call o'th'Trumpet.
incorrect_answers: At the sound of the trumpet.

question: In wisedome I should aske thy name,
correct_answers: But since thy out-side lookes so faire and Warlike,
incorrect_answers: But since you look so handsome and strong,

question: This is practise Gloster,
correct_answers: By th'law of Warre, thou wast not bound to answer An vnknowne opposite: thou art not vanquish'd, But cozend, and beguild.
incorrect_answers: By the rules of war, you weren't obligated to respond to an unknown opponent: you're not defeated, just tricked and deceived.

question: By th'law of Warre, thou wast not bound to answer An vnknowne opposite: thou art not vanquish'd, But cozend, and beguild.
correct_answers: Shut your mouth Dame, Or with this paper shall I stop it: hold Sir, Thou worse then any name, reade thine owne euill: No tearing Lady, I perceiue you know it.
incorrect_answers: Be quiet, ma'am, or I’ll gag you with this paper. Hold this, sir, you're worse than anything I can say. Read your own misdeeds. Don’t tear it, lady, I see you recognize it.

question: Shut your mouth Dame, Or with this paper shall I stop it: hold Sir, Thou worse then any name, reade thine owne euill: No tearing Lady, I perceiue you know it.
correct_answers: Say if I do, the Lawes are mine not thine, Who can araigne me for't?
incorrect_answers: If I do it, the laws are mine, not yours. Who can judge me for it?

question: Aske me not what I know.
correct_answers: Go after her, she's desperate, gouerne her.
incorrect_answers: Follow her, she's in a bad state, take control.

question: What you haue charg'd me with, / That haue I done, And more, much more, the time will bring it out.
correct_answers: 'Tis past, and so am I: But what art thou That hast this Fortune on me? If thou'rt Noble, I do forgiue thee.
incorrect_answers: It's over, and so am I. But who are you to bring this fate upon me? If you're honorable, I forgive you.

question: 'Tis past, and so am I: But what art thou That hast this Fortune on me? If thou'rt Noble, I do forgiue thee.
correct_answers: Let's exchange charity: I am no lesse in blood then thou art Edmond, If more, the more th'hast wrong'd me. My name is Edgar and thy Fathers Sonne, The Gods are iust, and of our pleasant vices Make instruments to plague vs: The darke and vitious place where thee he got, Cost him his eyes.
incorrect_answers: Let's be fair to each other: I'm just as noble as you are, Edmund. If anything, I'm more so, which makes your betrayal even worse. My name is Edgar, your father's son. The gods are just and use our own weaknesses to punish us. The sinful act that led to your birth is what cost him his eyes.

question: Who dead? Speake man.
correct_answers: Your Lady Sir, your Lady; and her Sister By her is poyson'd: she confesses it.
incorrect_answers: Your wife, sir, your wife; and her sister was poisoned by her: she has confessed it.

question: Produce the bodies, be they aliue or dead;
correct_answers: This iudgement of the Heauens that makes vs tremble. Touches vs not with pitty: O, is this he?
incorrect_answers: This judgment from the heavens that makes us tremble doesn't touch us with pity. Oh, is this him?

question: Yet Edmund was belou'd:
correct_answers: The one the other poison'd for my sake,
incorrect_answers: One poisoned the other for my sake,

question: And after slew herself.
correct_answers: Euen so: couer their faces.
incorrect_answers: Alright, cover their faces.

question: I pant for life: some good I meane to do
correct_answers: Despight of mine owne Nature. Quickly send,
incorrect_answers: Despite my own nature. Hurry up,

question: Despight of mine owne Nature. Quickly send,
correct_answers: (Be briefe in it) to'th'Castle, for my Writ
incorrect_answers: Keep it brief; take it to the Castle for my letter.

question: (Be briefe in it) to'th'Castle, for my Writ
correct_answers: Is on the life of Lear, and on Cordelia:
incorrect_answers: Is about Lear's life and Cordelia's.

question: Send thy token of repreeve.
correct_answers: Well thought on, take my Sword,
incorrect_answers: Good idea, take my sword.

question: Hast thee for thy life.
correct_answers: He hath Commission from thy Wife and me,
incorrect_answers: He has authorization from your wife and me.

question: He hath Commission from thy Wife and me,
correct_answers: To hang Cordelia in the prison, and
incorrect_answers: Execute Cordelia in the prison, and

question: To hang Cordelia in the prison, and
correct_answers: To lay the blame vpon her owne dispaire,
incorrect_answers: To blame her own despair,

question: To lay the blame vpon her owne dispaire,
correct_answers: That she for-did her selfe.
incorrect_answers: She killed herself.

question: That she for-did her selfe.
correct_answers: The Gods defend her, beare him hence awhile.
incorrect_answers: May the gods protect her, take him away for now.

question: Howle, howle, howle: O your are men of stones,
correct_answers: Had I your tongues and eyes, Il'd vse them so,
incorrect_answers: If I had your voices and looks, I'd use them that way too.

question: Had I your tongues and eyes, Il'd vse them so,
correct_answers: That Heauens vault should crack: she's gone for euer.
incorrect_answers: The sky should shatter: she's gone forever.

question: That Heauens vault should crack: she's gone for euer.
correct_answers: I know when one is dead, and when one liues,
incorrect_answers: I can tell when someone is dead and when someone is alive.

question: I know when one is dead, and when one liues,
correct_answers: She's dead as earth: Lend me a Looking-glasse,
incorrect_answers: She's as dead as can be. Pass me a mirror.

question: She's dead as earth: Lend me a Looking-glasse,
correct_answers: If that her breath will mist or staine the stone,
incorrect_answers: If her breath fogs up or stains the stone,

question: Fall and cease.
correct_answers: This feather stirs, she liues: if it be so, It is a chance which do's redeeme all sorrowes That euer I haue felt.
incorrect_answers: This feather moves, she’s alive: if that’s true, it makes up for all the pain I’ve ever felt.

question: 'Tis Noble Kent your Friend.
correct_answers: A plague vpon you Murderors, Traitors all, I might haue sau'd her, now she's gone for euer: Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a little. Ha: What is't thou saist? Her voice was euer soft, Gentle, and low, an excellent thing in woman. I kill'd the Slaue that was a hanging thee.
incorrect_answers: Curse you all, murderers and traitors! I could've saved her, and now she's gone forever. Cordelia, Cordelia, stay a moment. What did you say? Her voice was always soft, gentle, and low—such a great quality in a woman. I killed the man who was hanging you.

question: If Fortune brag of two, she lou'd and hated, One of them we behold.
correct_answers: This is a dull sight, are you not Kent?
incorrect_answers: This is a boring view. Aren't you Kent?

question: He's a good fellow, I can tell you that,
correct_answers: He'le strike and quickly too, he's dead and rotten.
incorrect_answers: He’ll hit fast; he’s long gone and decayed.

question: Ile see that straight.
correct_answers: That from your first of difference and decay, Haue follow'd your sad steps.
incorrect_answers: From the moment things started to go wrong, trouble has followed you.

question: Your are welcome hither.
correct_answers: Nor no man else: / All's cheerlesse, darke, and deadly, Your eldest Daughters haue fore-done themselues, And desperately are dead.
incorrect_answers: No one else either. Everything’s bleak, dark, and grim. Your eldest daughters have ended their lives and are dead by their own choice.

question: Edmund is dead my Lord.
correct_answers: That's but a trifle heere: You Lords and Noble Friends, know our intent, What comfort to this great decay may come, Shall be appli'd. For vs we will resigne, During the life of this old Maiesty To him our absolute power, you to your rights, With boote, and such addition as your Honours Haue more then merited. All Friends shall Taste the wages of their vertue,and all Foes The cup of their deseruings: O see, see.
incorrect_answers: That's just a minor matter. You lords and noble friends, you know our plan. We'll provide what comfort we can for this great downfall. As for us, we'll give our absolute power to this old Majesty for the rest of his life, you’ll get your rights, along with rewards that you more than deserve. All our friends will be rewarded for their virtue, and all our enemies will get what they deserve. Oh, look!

question: When the Hurley-burley's done,
correct_answers: When the Battaile's lost, and wonne.
incorrect_answers: When the battle's over, some will have won, and some will have lost.

question: Vpon the Heath.
correct_answers: There to meet with Macbeth.
incorrect_answers: To meet with Macbeth there.

question: What bloody man is that? he can report,
correct_answers: As seemeth by his plight, of the Reuolt
incorrect_answers: It looks like he's been affected by the rebellion.

question: Who like a good and hardie Souldier fought
correct_answers: 'Gainst my Captiuitie: Haile braue friend;
incorrect_answers: Against my captivity: Hello, brave friend.

question: God saue the King.
correct_answers: Whence cam'st thou, worthy Thane?
incorrect_answers: Where did you come from, noble Thane?

question: From Fiffe, great King.
correct_answers: Where the Norweyan Banners flowt the Skie, And fanne our people cold.
incorrect_answers: Where the Norwegian flags wave in the sky and chill our people.

question: Great happinesse.
correct_answers: That now Sweno, the Norwayes King, Craues composition:
incorrect_answers: Now Sweno, the King of Norway, wants to negotiate a peace deal.

question: No more that Thane of Cawdor shall deceiue Our Bosome interest:
correct_answers: Goe pronounce his present death, And with his former Title greet Macbeth.
incorrect_answers: Go announce his immediate execution, and give Macbeth his previous title.

question: 1. A Saylors Wife had Chestnuts in her Lappe, And mouncht, & mouncht, and mouncht: Giue me, quoth I. Aroynt thee, Witch, the rumpe-fed Ronyon cryes. Her Husband's to Aleppo gone, Master o'th' Tiger: But in a Syue Ile thither sayle, And like a Rat without a tayle, Ile doe, Ile doe, and Ile doe.
correct_answers: 2. Ile giue thee a Winde.
incorrect_answers: I'll get you a breeze.

question: 3. And I another.
correct_answers: 1. I my selfe haue all the other, And the very Ports they blow, All the Quarters that they know, I'th' Ship-mans Card.
incorrect_answers: I know all the directions and the winds that blow from every corner on the sailor's map.

question: Shew me, shew me.
correct_answers: Here I haue a Pilots Thumbe, Wrackt, as homeward he did come.
incorrect_answers: I have a pilot's thumb here, wrecked on his way home.

question: Here I haue a Pilots Thumbe, Wrackt, as homeward he did come.
correct_answers: A Drumme, a Drumme: Macbeth doth come.
incorrect_answers: A drum, a drum: Macbeth is coming.

question: A Drumme, a Drumme: Macbeth doth come.
correct_answers: All. The weyward Sisters, hand in hand, Posters of the Sea and Land, Thus doe goe, about, about, Thrice to thine, and thrice to mine, And thrice againe, to make vp nine. Peace, the Charme's wound vp.
incorrect_answers: All. The weird sisters, hand in hand, traveling over sea and land, dance around and around. Three times for you, and three times for me, and three times again to make it nine. Quiet now, the spell is cast.

question: All haile Macbeth, haille to thee Thane of Glamis.
correct_answers: All haile Macbeth, haille to thee Thane of Cawdor.
incorrect_answers: Hello, Macbeth! Hail to you, Thane of Cawdor.

question: All haile Macbeth, haille to thee Thane of Cawdor.
correct_answers: All haile Macbeth, that shalt be King hereafter.
incorrect_answers: Congratulations Macbeth, you will be the future king.

question: All haile Macbeth, haille to thee Thane of Glamis.
correct_answers: 2. All haile Macbeth, haille to thee Thane of Cawdor.
incorrect_answers: Congratulations, Macbeth! Hail to you, Thane of Cawdor.

question: All haile Macbeth, haille to thee Thane of Cawdor.
correct_answers: 3. All haile Macbeth, that shalt be King hereafter.
incorrect_answers: Hail Macbeth, you're going to be the future king.

question: Good Sir, why doe you start, and seeme to feare
correct_answers: Macb. So foule and faire a day I haue not seene.
incorrect_answers: Macbeth: I've never seen a day so good and bad at the same time.

question: You shall be King.
correct_answers: And Thane of Cawdor too: went it not so?
incorrect_answers: And Thane of Cawdor too: wasn't that right?

question: And for an earnest of a greater Honor,
correct_answers: He bad me, from him, call thee Thane of Cawdor: In which addition, haile most worthy Thane, For it is thine.
incorrect_answers: He told me to call you the Thane of Cawdor on his behalf. Congratulations, most worthy Thane, it's yours now.

question: My Liege, they are not yet come back. / But I haue spoke
correct_answers: Shakes so my single state of Man, That Function is smother'd in surmise, And nothing is, but what is not.
incorrect_answers: It shakes me up so much that I can't think straight and nothing feels real anymore.

question: Enter Macbeth, Banquo, Rosse, and Angus.
correct_answers: O worthyest Cousin, The sinne of my Ingratitude euen now Was heauie on me. Thou art so farre before, That swiftest Wing of Recompence is slow, To ouertake thee. Would thou hadst lesse deseru'd, That the proportion both of thanks, and payment, Might haue beene mine: onely I haue left to say, More is thy due, then more then all can pay.
incorrect_answers: My dear cousin, I felt guilty about my lack of gratitude, but you’re so far ahead that even the fastest reward can’t catch up to you. I wish you deserved less, so I could thank and repay you properly. All I can say is that you deserve more than anyone can give.

question: To morrow, as he purposes.
correct_answers: O neuer, Shall Sunne that Morrow see.
incorrect_answers: Oh never, that will never happen.

question: We will proceed no further in this Businesse:
correct_answers: He hath Honour'd me of late, and I haue bought Golden Opinions from all sorts of people, Which would be worne now in their newest glosse, Not cast aside so soone.
incorrect_answers: He's honored me recently, and I've earned praise from all kinds of people. I should enjoy this while it lasts, not throw it away so quickly.

question: Who dares receiue it other,
correct_answers: As we shall make our Griefes and Clamor rore, Upon his Death?
incorrect_answers: We'll make sure our grief and anger roar when he dies?

question: And she goes downe at Twelue.
correct_answers: I take't, 'tis later, Sir.
incorrect_answers: I think it's later, sir.

question: What Sir, not yet at rest? the King's a bed.
correct_answers: He hath beene in vnusuall Pleasure, And sent forth great Largesse to your Offices. This Diamond he greetes your Wife withall, By the name of most kind Hostesse, / And shut vp in measurelesse content.
incorrect_answers: He's been in an unusually good mood and sent generous gifts to your staff. He gives your wife this diamond, calling her a very kind hostess, and is extremely happy.

question: I dreamt last Night of the three weyward Sisters:
correct_answers: To you they haue shew'd some truth.
incorrect_answers: They have shown you some truth.

question: I thinke not of them:
correct_answers: Yet when we can entreat an houre to serue,
incorrect_answers: But when we can ask for a moment to help,

question: Yet when we can entreat an houre to serue,
correct_answers: We would spend it in some words vpon that Businesse,
incorrect_answers: Let's have a quick discussion about that matter.

question: We would spend it in some words vpon that Businesse,
correct_answers: If you would graunt the time.
incorrect_answers: If you could give me a moment.

question: At your kind'st leysure.
correct_answers: If you shall cleaue to my consent, / When 'tis,
incorrect_answers: If you stick with me when the time comes,

question: If you shall cleaue to my consent, / When 'tis,
correct_answers: it shall make Honor for you.
incorrect_answers: It will earn you honor.

question: So I lose none,
correct_answers: In seeking to augment it, but still keepe
incorrect_answers: In trying to increase it, but still keep

question: In seeking to augment it, but still keepe
correct_answers: My Bosome franchis'd, and Allegeance cleare,
incorrect_answers: My conscience is free, and my loyalty is pure.

question: Good repose the while.
correct_answers: Thankes Sir: the like to you.

question: A deed without a name.

incorrect_answers: I command you, by whatever you believe in, (however you came to know it) answer me: Even if you unleash the winds to battle against the churches, even if the foaming waves overwhelm and swallow ships, even if crops are flattened, trees are blown down, castles collapse on their guards, palaces and pyramids fall to their foundations, and nature's treasures are completely destroyed until everything is in ruins; answer me the question I ask you.

I dare not speake much further, But cruell are the times, when we are Traitors And do not know our selues: when we hold Rumor From what we feare, yet know not what we feare, But floate vpon a wilde and violent Sea Each way, and moue.
incorrect_answers: As for your husband, he's noble, wise, and discerning, and he understands the times best. I can't say much more, but these are cruel times when we're seen as traitors without knowing why. We follow rumors driven by our fears, yet we don't even know exactly what we're afraid of, and we drift in every direction on a wild and stormy sea.
