correct_answers: In my Voluptuousnesse: Your Wiues, your Daughters, Your Matrons, and your Maides, could not fill vp The Cesterne of my Lust, and my Desire All continent Impediments would ore-beare That did oppose my will.
incorrect_answers: In my indulgence: Your wives, your daughters, your matrons, and your maids couldn't satisfy my lust and desire, and any restraints would be overpowered by my will.

question: Boundlesse intemperance
correct_answers: In Nature is a Tyranny: It hath beene Th' vntimely emptying of the happy Throne, And fall of many Kings.
incorrect_answers: Nature can be tyrannical: It has often unfairly stripped the throne of worthy rulers and caused the downfall of many kings.

question: But I haue none.
correct_answers: The King-becoming Graces, As Iustice, Verity, Temp'rance, Stablenesse, Bounty, Perseuerance, Mercy, Lowlinesse, Deuotion, Patience, Courage, Fortitude, I haue no rellish of them, but abound In the diuision of each seuerall Crime, Acting it many wayes. Nay, had I powre, I should Poure the sweet Milke of Concord, into Hell, Vprore the vniuersall peace, confound All vnity on earth.
incorrect_answers: The qualities that make a good king, like justice, honesty, self-control, stability, generosity, perseverance, mercy, humility, devotion, patience, courage, and strength—I lack all of them and only excel in committing every kind of crime in many different ways. In fact, if I had the power, I would ruin peace and harmony and bring chaos and conflict to the world.

question: Macduff, this Noble passion
correct_answers: Childe of integrity, hath from my soule Wip'd the blacke Scruples, reconcil'd my thoughts To thy good Truth, and Honor. Diuellish Macbeth,
incorrect_answers: Child of integrity, you've cleared my doubts, reconciling my thoughts to your true goodness and honor. Wicked Macbeth,

question: See who comes heere.
correct_answers: My Countryman: but yet I know him not.
incorrect_answers: He's my fellow countryman, but I don't know him.

question: My euer gentle Cozen, welcome hither.
correct_answers: I know him now. Good God betimes remoue The meanes that makes vs Strangers.
incorrect_answers: I know him now. Dear God, please quickly remove whatever keeps us apart.

question: What concerne they,
correct_answers: The generall cause, or is it a Fee-griefe
incorrect_answers: Is it a widespread issue, or is it a personal problem?

question: The generall cause, or is it a Fee-griefe
correct_answers: Due to some single brest?
incorrect_answers: Because of some personal issue?

question: No minde that's honest
correct_answers: But in it shares some woe, though the maine part
incorrect_answers: But it contains some sadness, though the main part

question: Humh: I guesse at it.
correct_answers: Your Castle is surpriz'd: your Wife, and Babes
incorrect_answers: Your castle has been taken over: your wife and children

question: He ha's no Children.
correct_answers: All my pretty ones? / Did you say All?
incorrect_answers: All my children? Did you say all of them?

question: Dispute it like a man.
correct_answers: I shall do so: But I must also feele it as a man; I cannot but remember such things were That were most precious to me: Did heauen looke on, And would not take their part?
incorrect_answers: I'll do it, but I still need to feel it like a man. How can I not remember the things that were most important to me? Did Heaven see it happen and do nothing?

question: You see her eyes are open.
correct_answers: I, but their sense are shut.
incorrect_answers: Yes, but they're unresponsive.

question: What is it she do's now? Looke how she rubbes her hands.
correct_answers: It is an accustom'd action with her, to seeme thus washing her hands: I haue knowne her continue in this a quarter of an houre.
incorrect_answers: She habitually acts like she's washing her hands; I've seen her do this for fifteen minutes straight.

question: What a sigh is there? The hart is sorely charg'd.
correct_answers: I would not haue such a heart in my bosome, for the dignity of the whole body.
incorrect_answers: I wouldn't want to have a heart like that in me, even if it meant I could have the highest honor.

question: What do's the Tyrant.
correct_answers: Great Dunsinane he strongly Fortifies: Some say hee's mad: Others, that lesser hate him, Do call it valiant Fury, but for certaine He cannot buckle his distemper'd cause Within the belt of Rule.
incorrect_answers: He's fortifying Dunsinane heavily. Some say he's crazy; others, who dislike him less, call it reckless bravery. But one thing is sure: he can't control his chaotic situation.

question: Send out moe Horses, skirre the Country round, Hang those that talke of Feare. Giue me mine Armor:
correct_answers: How do's your Patient, Doctor?
incorrect_answers: How is your patient doing, Doctor?

question: Throw Physicke to the Dogs, Ile none of it. Come, put mine Armour on: giue me my Staffe:
correct_answers: Seyton, send out: Doctor, the Thanes flye from me:
incorrect_answers: Seyton, send the message out: Doctor, the nobles are abandoning me.

question: If thou could'st Doctor, cast The Water of my Land, finde her Disease, And purge it to a sound and pristine Health, I would applaud thee to the very Eccho, That should applaud againe. Pull't off I say,
correct_answers: What Rubarb, Cyme, or what Purgatiue drugge
incorrect_answers: What herb, plant, or what purging medicine

question: Let euery Souldier hew him downe a Bough
correct_answers: And bear't before him, thereby shall we shadow The numbers of our Hoast, and make discouery
incorrect_answers: Carry it in front of him so we can hide the size of our army and avoid detection.

question: It shall be done.
correct_answers: We learne no other, but the confident Tyrant Keeps still in Dunsinane, and will indure Our setting downe befor't.
incorrect_answers: We've heard nothing else, but the arrogant tyrant remains in Dunsinane and is prepared to withstand our siege.

question: For where there is aduantage to be giuen
correct_answers: Both more and lesse haue giuen him the Reuolt
incorrect_answers: Both the high and low have rebelled against him.

question: I haue almost forgot the taste of Feares:
correct_answers: The time ha's beene, my sences would haue cool'd to heare a Night-shrieke, and my Fell of haire Would at a dismall Treatise rowze, and stirre As life were in't. I haue supt full with horrors, Direnesse familiar to my slaughterous thoughts Cannot once start me.
incorrect_answers: There was a time when a night scream would chill me and make my hair stand on end. But I’ve had my fill of horrors; now, nothing scares me anymore.

question: Thou com'st to vse thy Tongue: thy Story quickly.
correct_answers: Gracious my Lord, I should report that which I say I saw, But know not how to doo't.
incorrect_answers: My Lord, I need to tell you what I've seen, but I don't know how to say it.

question: Now neere enough:
correct_answers: Your leauy Skreenes throw downe, And shew like those you are: You (worthy Vnkle) Shall with my Cosin your right Noble Sonne Leade our first Battell. Worthy Macduffe, and wee Shall take vpon's what else remaines to do, According to our order.
incorrect_answers: Drop your leafy screens and show yourselves as you truly are. You, my noble uncle, will lead our first battle alongside your son. Worthy Macduff and I will handle everything else according to our plan.

question: My name's Macbeth.
correct_answers: The diuell himselfe could not pronounce a Title More hatefull to mine eare.
incorrect_answers: Even the devil couldn't say a name more hateful to me.

question: No: nor more fearefull.
correct_answers: Thou lyest abhorred Tyrant, with my Sword Ile proue the lye thou speak'st.
incorrect_answers: You're lying, hateful tyrant, and I'll prove it with my sword.

question: That way the noise is: Tyrant shew thy face, If thou beest slaine, and with no stroake of mine, My Wife and Childrens Ghosts will haunt me still:
correct_answers: I cannot strike at wretched Kernes, whose armes Are hyr'd to beare their Staues; either thou Macbeth, Or else my Sword with an vnbattered edge I sheath againe vndeeded.
incorrect_answers: I can't fight lowly mercenaries whose only job is to carry weapons. Either you face me, Macbeth, or I'll put my unused sword back in its sheath.

question: This way my Lord, the Castles gently rendred:
correct_answers: The Tyrants people, on both sides do fight, The Noble Thanes do brauely in the Warre, The day almost it selfe professes yours, And little is to do.
incorrect_answers: The tyrant's people are fighting on both sides, the noble thanes are fighting bravely in the war, the day is almost yours, and there's little left to do.

question: Why should I play the Roman Foole, and dye
correct_answers: On mine owne sword? whiles I see liues, the gashes
incorrect_answers: On my own sword? While I see lives, the wounds

question: Turne Hell-hound, turne.
correct_answers: Of all men else I haue auoyded thee:
incorrect_answers: I've avoided everyone else but you.

question: Of all men else I haue auoyded thee:
correct_answers: But get thee backe, my soule is too much charg'd
incorrect_answers: But go back, I can't take any more.

question: I haue no words,
correct_answers: My voice is in my Sword, thou bloodier Villaine
incorrect_answers: I'm speaking through my sword, you bloody villain.

question: My voice is in my Sword, thou bloodier Villaine
correct_answers: Then tearmes can giue thee out.
incorrect_answers: Then words can describe you.

question: Thou loosest labour
correct_answers: As easie may'st thou the intrenchant Ayre
incorrect_answers: You might as well try to cut through the air

question: As easie may'st thou the intrenchant Ayre
correct_answers: With thy keene Sword impresse, as make me bleed:
incorrect_answers: Make me bleed with your sharp sword.

question: With thy keene Sword impresse, as make me bleed:
correct_answers: Let fall thy blade on vulnerable Crests,
incorrect_answers: Strike at the weak spots.

question: Let fall thy blade on vulnerable Crests,
correct_answers: I beare a charmed Life, which must not yeeld
incorrect_answers: I lead a protected life that won't be taken.

question: Dispaire thy Charme,
correct_answers: And let the Angell whom thou still hast seru'd
incorrect_answers: And let the Angel you have always served

question: And let the Angell whom thou still hast seru'd
correct_answers: Tell thee, Macduffe was from his Mothers womb
incorrect_answers: Macduff was born from his mother’s womb

question: Accursed be that tongue that tels mee so;
correct_answers: For it hath Cow'd my better part of man:
incorrect_answers: It has made me lose my courage.

question: For it hath Cow'd my better part of man:
correct_answers: And be these Iugling Fiends no more beleeu'd,
incorrect_answers: And don't trust these deceptive spirits anymore.

question: And be these Iugling Fiends no more beleeu'd,
correct_answers: That palter with vs in a double sence,
incorrect_answers: They deceive us with double meanings,

question: That palter with vs in a double sence,
correct_answers: That keepe the word of promise to our eare,
incorrect_answers: They tell us what we want to hear,

question: That keepe the word of promise to our eare,
correct_answers: And breake it to our hope. Ile not fight with thee.
incorrect_answers: And ruin our chances. I’m not going to fight you.

question: Then yeeld thee Coward,
correct_answers: And liue to be the shew, and gaze o'th' time.
incorrect_answers: And live to be the spectacle and fascination of the moment.

question: And liue to be the shew, and gaze o'th' time.
correct_answers: Wee'l haue thee, as our rarer Monsters are
incorrect_answers: We'll treat you like one of our rare curiosities.

question: Wee'l haue thee, as our rarer Monsters are
correct_answers: Painted vpon a pole, and vnder-writ,
incorrect_answers: Painted on a sign, with a message below,

question: Painted vpon a pole, and vnder-writ,
correct_answers: Heere may you see the Tyrant.
incorrect_answers: Here you can see the Tyrant.

question: I will not yeeld
correct_answers: To kisse the ground before young Malcolmes feet,
incorrect_answers: To bow down before young Malcolm.

question: To kisse the ground before young Malcolmes feet,
correct_answers: And to be baited with the Rabbles curse.
incorrect_answers: And to be harassed by the crowd's insults.

question: And to be baited with the Rabbles curse.
correct_answers: Though Byrnane wood be come to Dunsinane,
incorrect_answers: Even though Birnam Wood has come to Dunsinane,

question: Though Byrnane wood be come to Dunsinane,
correct_answers: And thou oppos'd, being of no woman borne,
incorrect_answers: And you, not born from a woman,

question: And thou oppos'd, being of no woman borne,
correct_answers: Yet I will try the last. Before my body,
incorrect_answers: But I will give it one last shot. With my own body,

question: Yet I will try the last. Before my body,
correct_answers: I throw my warlike Shield: Lay on Macduffe,
incorrect_answers: I drop my battle shield: Bring it on, Macduff

question: I throw my warlike Shield: Lay on Macduffe,
correct_answers: And damn'd be him, that first cries hold, enough.
incorrect_answers: And cursed be the one who gives up first.

question: Retreat, and Flourish. Enter with Drumme and Colours,
correct_answers: Malcolm, Seyward, Rosse, Thanes, & Soldiers
incorrect_answers: Malcolm, Siward, Ross, lords, and soldiers

question: Your son my Lord, ha's paid a souldiers debt,
correct_answers: He onely liu'd but till he was a man,
incorrect_answers: He only lived until he became an adult.

question: He onely liu'd but till he was a man,
correct_answers: The which no sooner had his Prowesse confirm'd
incorrect_answers: As soon as he had proven his bravery

question: The which no sooner had his Prowesse confirm'd
correct_answers: In the vnshrinking station where he fought,
incorrect_answers: Where he bravely stood and fought,

question: I, and brought off the field: your cause of sorrow
correct_answers: Must not be measur'd by his worth, for then
incorrect_answers: You can't judge him by his value, because then

question: Haile King, for so thou art. / Behold where stands Th' Vsurpers cursed head: the time is free:
correct_answers: I see thee compast with thy Kingdomes Pearle, That speake my salutation in their minds:
incorrect_answers: I see you surrounded by the beauty of your kingdom, and I can sense their silent greetings.

question: I see thee compast with thy Kingdomes Pearle, That speake my salutation in their minds:
correct_answers: Whose voyces I desire alowd with mine. Haile King of Scotland.
incorrect_answers: I want your voices to join mine in saying this out loud: Hail, King of Scotland.

question: GRegory: A my word wee'l not carry coales.
correct_answers: No, for then we should be Colliars.
incorrect_answers: No, because then we'd be coal workers.

question: No, for then we should be Colliars.
correct_answers: I mean, if we be in choller, wee'l draw.
incorrect_answers: I mean, if we get angry, we’ll fight.

question: I mean, if we be in choller, wee'l draw.
correct_answers: I, While you liue, draw your necke out o'th Collar.
incorrect_answers: While you're alive, avoid getting into trouble.

question: I, While you liue, draw your necke out o'th Collar.
correct_answers: But thou art not quickly mou'd to strike.
incorrect_answers: But you're not quick to get angry and fight.

question: But thou art not quickly mou'd to strike.
correct_answers: A dog of the house of Mountague, moues me.
incorrect_answers: A servant of the Montague family provokes me.

question: A dog of the house of Mountague, moues me.
correct_answers: To moue, is to stir: and to be valiant, is to stand: Therefore, if thou art mou'd, thou runst away.
incorrect_answers: To move is to act, but to be brave is to stand your ground. So, if you get moved, you're just running away.

question: That shewes thee a weake slaue, for the weakest goes to the wall.
correct_answers: True, and therefore women being the weaker Vessels, are euer thrust to the wall: therefore I will push Mountagues men from the wall, and thrust his Maides to the wall.
incorrect_answers: True, and because women are the weaker ones, they're always pushed aside. So I'll push Montague's men aside and shove his maids against the wall.

question: The Quarrell is betweene our Masters, and vs their men.
correct_answers: 'Tis all one, I will shew my selfe a tyrant: when I haue fought with the men, I will bee ciuill with the Maids, and cut off their heads.
incorrect_answers: It's all the same to me. I'll be ruthless: after I fight the men, I'll be courteous to the women—by cutting off their heads.

question: Part Fooles, put vp your Swords, you know not what you do.
correct_answers: What art thou drawne, among these heartlesse / Hindes? Turne thee Benuolio, looke vpon thy death.
incorrect_answers: Why are you drawn here with these cowardly folks? Turn around, Benvolio, and face your death.

question: What noise is this? Giue me my long Sword ho.
correct_answers: A crutch, a crutch: why call you for a Sword?
incorrect_answers: You need a crutch, not a sword.

question: Thou shalt not stir a foote to seeke a Foe.
correct_answers: Rebellious Subiects, Enemies to peace, Prophaners of this Neighbor-stained Steele, Will they not heare?
incorrect_answers: Rebellious subjects, enemies of peace, defilers of these blood-stained weapons, won’t you listen?

question: Out of her fauour where I am in loue.
correct_answers: Alas that louve so gentle in his view,
incorrect_answers: It's a shame that love seems so kind at first,

question: Alas that loue, whose view is muffled still,
correct_answers: Should without eyes, see path-wayes to his will:
incorrect_answers: Should find ways to fulfill his desires, even without seeing.

question: Why then, O brawling loue, O louing hate,
correct_answers: O any thing, of nothing first created:
incorrect_answers: Oh, everything made from nothing to start with:

question: Younger then she, are happy mothers made.
correct_answers: And too soone mar'd are those so early made: Earth hath swallowed all my hopes but she, Shee's the hopefull Lady of my earth: But wooe her gentle Paris, get her heart, My will to her consent, is but a part, And shee agree, within her scope of choise, Lyes my consent, and faire according voice: This night I hold an old accustom'd Feast, Whereto I haue inuited many a Guest, Such as I loue, and you among the store, One more, most welcome makes my number more: At my poore house, looke to behold this night, Earth-treading starres, that make darke heauen light, Such comfort as do lusty young men feele, When well apparrel'd Aprill on the heele Of limping Winter treads, euen such delight Among fresh Fennell buds shall you this night Inherit at my house: heare all, all see: And like her most, whose merit most shall be: Which one more veiw, of many, mine being one, May stand in number, though in reckning none. Come, goe with me: goe sirrah trudge about, Through faire Verona, find those persons out, Whose names are written there, and to them say, My house and welcome, on their pleasure stay.
incorrect_answers: Those who mature too early are often ruined quickly. The earth has swallowed all my hopes except her, she's the bright hope of my life. But, gentle Paris, charm her and win her heart. My approval means nothing if she doesn’t agree; my consent depends on her choice. Tonight I’m hosting a traditional feast, to which I've invited many friends I love, including you. Your presence will be a welcome addition. At my modest home, you'll see people who shine brightly like stars, bringing light to the night. You'll experience the joy that young men feel when April, well-dressed, steps in after the dreary winter. Such pleasure will you inherit at my house tonight. See and hear everything, and favor the one who deserves it most. View them all, though one more can't be counted except in their number. Come, go with me. Go, sir, hurry through fair Verona, find those on this list, and tell them they are welcome at my house at their convenience.

question: I mine owne fortune in my miserie.
correct_answers: Perhaps you haue learn'd it without booke: But I pray can you read any thing you see?
incorrect_answers: Maybe you've memorized it, but can you actually read what you see?

question: I, if I know the Letters and the Language.
correct_answers: Ye say honestly, rest you merry.
incorrect_answers: You speak truthfully, take care.

question: Indeed I should haue askt you that before.
correct_answers: Now Ile tell you without asking. My maister is the great rich Capulet, and if you be not of the house of Mountagues I pray come and crush a cup of wine. Rest you merry.
incorrect_answers: Alright, I'll tell you straight up. My boss is the wealthy Capulet, and if you're not from the Montague family, please come have a drink with us. Take care.

question: At this same auncient Feast of Capulets Sups the faire Rosaline, whom thou so loues:
correct_answers: With all the admired Beauties of Verona, Go thither and with vnattainted eye, Compare her face with some that I shall show, And I will make thee thinke thy Swan a Crow.
incorrect_answers: Go to Verona and see all the beautiful women there. Compare her face with the others I show you, and you'll see that she's not as special as you think.

question: When the deuout religion of mine eye Maintaines such falshood, then turne teares to fire:
correct_answers: And these who often drown'd could neuer die, Transparent Heretiques be burnt for liers.
incorrect_answers: And those who often sank never died, while clear heretics were burned for lying.

question: A fortnight and odde dayes.
correct_answers: Euen or odde, of all daies in the yeare
incorrect_answers: Odd or even, any day of the year

question: Euen or odde, of all daies in the yeare
correct_answers: come Lammas Eue at night shall she be fourteene.
incorrect_answers: On the night before Lammas Day, she'll be fourteen.

question: come Lammas Eue at night shall she be fourteene.
correct_answers: that shall she marie, I remember it well.
incorrect_answers: She'll definitely marry him, I remember clearly.

question: that shall she marie, I remember it well.
correct_answers: But as I said, on Lamas Eue at night shall she be fourteene
incorrect_answers: As I mentioned, she'll turn fourteen the night before Lammas Day.

question: But as I said, on Lamas Eue at night shall she be fourteene
correct_answers: I neuer should forget it: wilt thou not Iulet quoth he?
incorrect_answers: I'll never forget it: Won't you, Juliet, he said?

question: Inough of this, I pray thee hold thy peace.
correct_answers: Yes Madam, yet I cannot chuse but laugh
incorrect_answers: Yes, ma'am, but I can't help laughing.

question: Yea quoth my husband, fall'st vpon thy face,
correct_answers: thou wilt fall backward when thou commest to age: wilt thou not Iule?
incorrect_answers: You'll fall back when you get older, won't you, Juliet?

question: Giue me a Torch, I am not for this ambling.
correct_answers: Being but heauy I will beare the light.
incorrect_answers: Since I'm feeling down, I'll carry the light.

question: Nay gentle Romeo, we must haue you dance.

incorrect_answers: I don't believe you; you have light, dancing shoes, while I have a heavy soul that keeps me grounded and unable to move.

question: You are a Louer, borrow Cupids wings,
correct_answers: And soare with them aboue a common bound.
incorrect_answers: And rise above them beyond the usual limits.

question: I am too sore enpearced with his shaft,
correct_answers: To soare with his light feathers, and to bound: I cannot bound a pitch aboue dull woe, Vnder loues heauy burthen doe I sinke.
incorrect_answers: I can't rise with light-hearted joy or leap; I'm weighed down by sorrow, and love's heavy burden makes me sink.

question: And to sinke in it should you burthen loue,
correct_answers: Too great oppression for a tender thing.
incorrect_answers: That's too harsh for something so delicate.

question: Is loue a tender thing? it is too rough,
correct_answers: Too rude, too boysterous, and it pricks like thorne.
incorrect_answers: Too rough, too rowdy, and it stings like a thorn.

question: If loue be rough with you, be rough with loue,
correct_answers: Pricke loue for pricking, and you beat loue downe, Giue me a Case to put my visage in, A Visor for a Visor, what care I What curious eye doth quote deformities: Here are the Beetle-browes shall blush for me.
incorrect_answers: Poke fun at love's pain, and you'll bring love down. Give me a mask to hide my face, a mask for a mask. I don't care what keen eyes notice imperfections. My thick eyebrows will do the blushing for me.

question: True, I talke of dreames:
correct_answers: Which are the children of an idle braine,
incorrect_answers: They are just the products of a lazy mind.

question: Welcome Gentlemen, Ladies that haue their toes Unplagu'd with Cornes, will walke about with you:
correct_answers: Ah my Mistresses, which of you all Will now deny to dance? She that makes dainty, She Ile sweare hath Cornes: am I come neare ye now?
incorrect_answers: Alright ladies, who's going to refuse to dance now? If anyone's being shy, I bet it's because she has corns. Did I get close to the truth?

question: Welcome Gentlemen, Ladies that haue their toes Unplagu'd with Cornes, will walke about with you:
correct_answers: You are welcome Gentlemen, come Musitians play: Musicke plaies: and the dance.
incorrect_answers: Welcome, gentlemen. Musicians, start playing. Let’s enjoy the music and dance.

question: I know not sir.
correct_answers: O she doth teach the Torches to burne bright:
incorrect_answers: She teaches the torches how to shine bright.

question: O she doth teach the Torches to burne bright:
correct_answers: It seemes she hangs vpon the cheeke of night,
incorrect_answers: She looks like she’s glowing in the night.

question: Vncle this is a Mountague, our foe:
correct_answers: A Villaine that is hither come in spight,
incorrect_answers: A villain who has come here out of spite,

incorrect_answers: You'll start a riot among the guests.

question: You must contrary me, marry 'tis time.
correct_answers: Well said my hearts, you are a Princox, goe,
incorrect_answers: Well done, guys, you're an impudent young man, go on,

question: Be quiet, or more light, more light for shame,
correct_answers: Ile make you quiet. What, chearely my hearts.
incorrect_answers: I'll calm you down. Come on, cheer up, everyone.

question: Patience perforce, with wilfull choler meeting,
correct_answers: Makes my flesh tremble in their different greeting:
incorrect_answers: Their different greetings make my skin crawl.

question: Come hither Nurse, / What is yond Gentleman:
correct_answers: The Sonne and Heire of old Tyberio.
incorrect_answers: The son and heir of old Tiberio.

question: Go aske his name: if he be married,
correct_answers: His name is Romeo, and a Mountague, The onely Sonne of your great Enemie.
incorrect_answers: His name is Romeo, and he's a Montague, the only son of your biggest enemy.

question: My onely Loue sprung from my onely hate,
correct_answers: Too early seene, vnknowne, and knowne too late, Prodigious birth of Loue it is to me, That I must loue a loathed Enemie.
incorrect_answers: I saw you too soon without knowing who you were, and found out too late. It's a terrible twist of fate that I have to love someone I’m supposed to hate.

question: Ben. Romeo, my Cozen Romeo, Romeo.
correct_answers: He is wise, And on my life hath stolne him home to bed.
incorrect_answers: He's smart, and I'm sure he's gone home to bed.

question: Mer. Nay, Ile coniure too.
correct_answers: Romeo, Humours, Madman, Passion, Louer, Appeare thou in the likenesse of a sigh, Speake but one rime, and I am satisfied: Cry me but ay me, Prouant, but Loue and day, Speake to my goship Venus one faire word.
incorrect_answers: Romeo, emotions, madman, lover, show up like a sigh. Just say one rhyme, and I'm good. Only cry out "oh me," just say love and daylight, and speak one sweet word to my friend Venus.

question: The Ape is dead, I must coniure him,
correct_answers: I coniure thee by Rosalines bright eyes,
incorrect_answers: I ask you in the name of Rosaline's bright eyes,

question: I coniure thee by Rosalines bright eyes,
correct_answers: By her High forehead, and her Scarlet lip,
incorrect_answers: By her high forehead and her red lips,

question: By her High forehead, and her Scarlet lip,
correct_answers: By her Fine foote, Straight leg, and Quiuering thigh,
incorrect_answers: By her beautiful foot, straight leg, and trembling thigh,

question: By her Fine foote, Straight leg, and Quiuering thigh,
correct_answers: And the Demeanes, that there Adiacent lie,
incorrect_answers: And the lands that are nearby,

question: And if he heare thee thou wilt anger him.
correct_answers: This cannot anger him, t'would anger him
incorrect_answers: This won't make him mad, it would annoy him.

question: This cannot anger him, t'would anger him
correct_answers: To raise a spirit in his Mistresse circle,
incorrect_answers: To summon a spirit in his mistress's circle,

question: Come, he hath hid himselfe among these Trees
correct_answers: To be consorted with the Humerous night:
incorrect_answers: To be in the company of the moody night:

question: Blind is his Loue, and best befits the darke.
correct_answers: If Loue be blind, Loue cannot hit the marke,
incorrect_answers: If love is blind, it can't hit the target.

question: Now will he sit vnder a Medler tree,
correct_answers: And wish his Mistresse were that kind of Fruite,
incorrect_answers: And wish his girlfriend was sweet like that fruit,

question: O Romeo that she were, O that she were
correct_answers: An open, or thou a Poprin Peare,
incorrect_answers: Either open it, or you're just a common pear

question: Romeo goodnight, Ile to my Truckle bed,
correct_answers: This Field-bed is to cold for me to sleepe,
incorrect_answers: This makeshift bed is too cold for me to sleep on.

question: Go then, for 'tis in vaine
correct_answers: to seeke him here / That meanes not to be found.
incorrect_answers: looking for him here / when he doesn’t want to be found.

question: It is the East, and Iuliet is the Sunne
correct_answers: Arise faire Sun and kill the enuious Moone
incorrect_answers: Rise, beautiful sun, and outshine the jealous moon.

question: Arise faire Sun and kill the enuious Moone
correct_answers: Who is already sicke and pale with griefe
incorrect_answers: Who is already sick and pale with grief

question: Who is already sicke and pale with griefe
correct_answers: That thou her Maid art far more faire then she
incorrect_answers: You're way more beautiful than she is.

question: That thou her Maid art far more faire then she
correct_answers: Be not her Maid since she is enuious
incorrect_answers: Don't be her servant since she's jealous.

question: Be not her Maid since she is enuious
correct_answers: Her Vestal liuery is but sicke and greene
incorrect_answers: Her pure appearance is pale and weak.

question: Her Vestal liuery is but sicke and greene
correct_answers: And none but fooles do weare it, cast it off
incorrect_answers: Only fools wear it, so get rid of it.

question: And none but fooles do weare it, cast it off
correct_answers: It is my Lady, O it is my Loue
incorrect_answers: That's my lady; oh, that's my love.

question: O that she knew she were
correct_answers: She speakes, yet she sayes nothing, what of that
incorrect_answers: She talks, but doesn't actually say anything, so what?

question: She speakes, yet she sayes nothing, what of that
correct_answers: Her eye discourses, I will answere it
incorrect_answers: Her eye is speaking to me; I will respond to it.

question: Her eye discourses, I will answere it
correct_answers: I am too bold 'tis not to me she speakes
incorrect_answers: I'm being too presumptuous. She's not talking to me.

question: I am too bold 'tis not to me she speakes
correct_answers: Two of the fairest starres in all the Heauen
incorrect_answers: Two of the brightest stars in the entire sky

question: Two of the fairest starres in all the Heauen
correct_answers: Hauing some businesse do entreat her eyes
incorrect_answers: Having some business, I ask for her attention

question: Hauing some businesse do entreat her eyes
correct_answers: To twinckle in their Spheres till they returne
incorrect_answers: To shine in their places until they come back

question: To twinckle in their Spheres till they returne
correct_answers: What if her eyes were there, they in her head
incorrect_answers: What if her eyes were in her head where they belong?

question: What if her eyes were there, they in her head
correct_answers: The brightnesse of her cheeke would shame those starres
incorrect_answers: The brightness of her cheek would outshine those stars.

question: The brightnesse of her cheeke would shame those starres
correct_answers: As day-light doth a Lampe, her eye in heauen
incorrect_answers: Like daylight to a lamp, her eyes shine in the sky

question: As day-light doth a Lampe, her eye in heauen
correct_answers: Would through the ayrie Region streame so bright
incorrect_answers: Would shine so brightly through the open sky

question: Would through the ayrie Region streame so bright
correct_answers: That Birds would sing, and thinke it were not night
incorrect_answers: Birds would sing, thinking it wasn't night.

question: That Birds would sing, and thinke it were not night
correct_answers: See how she leanes her cheeke vpon her hand
incorrect_answers: Look how she's resting her cheek on her hand.

question: See how she leanes her cheeke vpon her hand
correct_answers: O that I were a Gloue vpon that hand
incorrect_answers: I wish I were a glove on that hand

question: O that I were a Gloue vpon that hand
correct_answers: That I might touch that cheeke
incorrect_answers: I wish I could touch that cheek.

question: Oh speake againe bright Angell, for thou art
correct_answers: As glorious to this night being ore my head
incorrect_answers: As beautiful as this night above me

question: As glorious to this night being ore my head
correct_answers: As is a winged messenger of heauen
incorrect_answers: Like an angel from heaven

question: As is a winged messenger of heauen
correct_answers: Vnto the white vpturned wondring eyes
incorrect_answers: Into the wide, amazed eyes looking upward

question: Vnto the white vpturned wondring eyes
correct_answers: Of mortalls that fall backe to gaze on him
incorrect_answers: Of mortals who stop and stare at him

question: Of mortalls that fall backe to gaze on him
correct_answers: When he bestrides the lazie puffing Cloudes
incorrect_answers: When he rides the lazy, puffing clouds

question: When he bestrides the lazie puffing Cloudes
correct_answers: And sailes vpon the bosome of the ayre
incorrect_answers: And sails through the air

question: Denie thy Father and refuse thy name
correct_answers: Or if thou wilt not, be but sworne my Loue
incorrect_answers: Or if you won't, just swear to love me

question: 'Tis but thy name that is my Enemy:
correct_answers: Thou art thy selfe, though not a Mountague,
incorrect_answers: You are yourself, even if you're not a Montague.

question: What? in a names that which we call a Rose,
correct_answers: By any other word would smell as sweete,
incorrect_answers: It would still smell just as sweet by any other name.

question: So Romeo would, were he not Romeo cal'd,
correct_answers: Retaine that deare perfection which he owes,
incorrect_answers: Keep his precious perfection.

question: Without that title Romeo, doffe thy name,
correct_answers: And for thy name which is no part of thee,
incorrect_answers: And for a name which isn't a part of you,

question: I take thee at thy word:
correct_answers: Call me but Loue, and Ile be new baptiz'd,
incorrect_answers: Just call me Love, and I'll be born again.

question: My name deare Saint, is hatefull to my selfe,
correct_answers: Because it is an Enemy to thee,
incorrect_answers: Because it is your enemy.

question: If they do see thee, they will murther thee.
correct_answers: Alacke there lies more perill in thine eye, Then twenty of their Swords, looke thou but sweete, And I am proofe against their enmity.
incorrect_answers: There's more danger in your eyes than in twenty of their swords. Just look at me with love, and I can withstand their hatred.

question: I would not for the world they saw thee here.
correct_answers: I haue nights cloake to hide me from their eyes And but thou loue me, let them finde me here, My life were better ended by their hate, Then death proroged wanting of thy Louve.
incorrect_answers: I have the cover of night to hide me from their eyes. And if you don't love me, let them find me here. I'd rather have my life ended by their hate than live without your love.

question: Thou knowest the maske of night is on my face,
correct_answers: Else would a Maiden blush bepaint my cheeke, For that which thou hast heard me speake to night, Faine would I dwell on forme, faine, faine, denie What I haue spoke, but farewell Complement, Doest thou Loue? I know thou wilt say I, And I will take thy word, yet if thou swear'st, Thou maiest proue false: at Louers periuries They say Ioue laught, oh gentle Romeo, If thou dost Louve, pronounce it faithfully: Or if thou thinkest I am too quickly wonne, Ile frowne and be peruerse, and say thee nay, So thou wilt wooe: But else not for the world.
incorrect_answers: Otherwise, I'd be blushing right now for what I've just said to you tonight. I'd love to be more proper and deny what I've said, but enough with the formalities. Do you love me? I know you'll say yes, and I'll believe you. But if you swear, you might be lying—they say the gods laugh at lovers' lies. Oh, gentle Romeo, if you love me, say it sincerely. Or if you think I’ve fallen for you too easily, I'll play hard to get and say no, so you have to woo me. But otherwise, I wouldn't for the world.

question: Lady, by yonder Moone I vow,
correct_answers: That tips with siluer all these Fruite tree tops.
incorrect_answers: That covers all these fruit tree tops with silver.

question: O sweare not by the Moone, th'inconstant Moone,
correct_answers: That monethly changes in her circled Orbe,
incorrect_answers: She goes through monthly changes in her orbit,

question: If my hearts deare loue.
correct_answers: Well do not sweare, although I ioy in thee:
incorrect_answers: You don't need to swear, even though I'm happy with you.

question: I gaue thee mine before thou did'st request it:
correct_answers: And yet I would it were to giue againe.
incorrect_answers: I wish I could give it back again.

question: And yet I wish but for the thing I haue,
correct_answers: My bounty is as boundlesse as the Sea,
incorrect_answers: My generosity is as endless as the ocean,

question: O blessed blessed night, I am afear'd
correct_answers: Being in night, all this is but a dreame,
incorrect_answers: Since it's nighttime, all of this is just a dream.

question: Three words deare Romeo, / And goodnight indeed,
correct_answers: If that thy bent of Loue be Honourable,
incorrect_answers: If your intentions in love are honorable,

question: Hist Romeo hist: O for a Falkners voice,
correct_answers: To lure this Tassell gentle backe againe,
incorrect_answers: To entice this gentle bird to return,

question: I will not faile, 'tis twenty yeares till then,
correct_answers: I haue forgot why I did call thee backe.
incorrect_answers: I forgot why I called you back.

question: Let me stand here till thou remember it.
correct_answers: I shall forget, to haue thee still stand there, Remembring how I Loue thy company.
incorrect_answers: I'll forget that you’re still standing there because I love having you around.

question: 'Tis almost morning, I would haue thee gone,
correct_answers: And yet no further then a wantons Bird, That lets it hop a little from her hand, Like a poore prisoner in his twisted gyues, And with a silken thred plucks it backe againe, So louing-iew. I would I were thy Bird.
incorrect_answers: Still, it's like a playful pet bird that you let hop a bit from your hand, like a poor prisoner in his chains, and you pull it back with a silk thread. I wish I were your bird.

question: Rom. I would I were thy Bird.
correct_answers: Iul. Sweet so would I, Yet I should kill thee with much cherishing.
incorrect_answers: Sure, I'd love that, but I'd end up killing you with too much affection.

question: Rom. Would I were sleepe and peace so sweet to rest,
correct_answers: The gray ey'd morne smiles on the frowning night. Checkring the Easterne Cloudes with streaks of light: And fleckled darknesse like a drunkard reeles.
incorrect_answers: The gray-eyed morning smiles at the frowning night, breaking the eastern clouds with streaks of light, and the speckled darkness staggers like a drunkard.

question: That last is true, the sweeter rest was mine.
correct_answers: God pardon sin: wast thou with Rosaline?
incorrect_answers: God forgive us: were you with Rosaline?

question: Ile tell thee ere thou aske it me agen:
correct_answers: I haue beene feasting with mine enemie.
incorrect_answers: I've been having dinner with my enemy.

question: Not to his Fathers, I spoke with his man.
correct_answers: Why that same pale hard-harted wench, that Rosaline torments him so, that he will sure run mad.
incorrect_answers: That cold-hearted girl Rosaline is driving him crazy; he'll definitely lose his mind.

question: Romeo will answere it.
correct_answers: Any man that can write, may answere a Letter.
incorrect_answers: Anyone who can write can respond to a letter.

question: Any man that can write, may answere a Letter.
correct_answers: Nay, he will answere the Letters Maister how he dares, being dared.
incorrect_answers: No, he will respond to the letters however he dares, since he's been challenged.

question: Here comes Romeo, here comes Romeo.
correct_answers: Without his Roe, like a dryed Hering. O flesh, flesh, how art thou fishified? Now is he for the numbers that Petrarch flowed in: Laura to his Lady, was a kitchen wench, marrie she had a better Loue to berime her: Dido a dowdie, Cleopatra a Gipsie, Hellen and Hero, hildings and Harlots: Thisbie a gray eie or so, but not to the purpose. Signior Romeo, Bon iour, there's a French salutation to your French slop: you gaue vs the the counterfait
incorrect_answers: Without his partner, he's like a dried-up herring. Oh, flesh, how you've become like a fish! Now he's trying to write poetry like Petrarch: claiming his lady is better than Laura, who was just a kitchen maid; saying Dido was a slob, Cleopatra a gypsy, Helen and Hero were worthless, and Thisbe just had gray eyes, but that's beside the point. Good day, Sir Romeo, there's a French greeting to match your French attire: you gave us a fake greeting.

question: Meaning to cursie.
correct_answers: Thou hast most kindly hit it.
incorrect_answers: You nailed it perfectly.

question: A most curteous exposition.
correct_answers: Nay, I am the very pinck of curtesie.
incorrect_answers: No, I'm the epitome of courtesy.

question: Why then is my Pump well flowr'd.
correct_answers: Sure wit, follow me this ieast, now till thou hast worne out thy Pump, that when the single sole of it is worne, the ieast may remaine after the wearing, sole-singular.
incorrect_answers: Sure, follow me on this joke until you've worn out your shoes, so that even when the sole is completely gone, the joke still remains uniquely funny.

question: O single sol'd ieast, / Soly singular for the singlenesse.
correct_answers: Come betweene vs good Benuolio, my wits faints.
incorrect_answers: Benvolio, help us out here; I'm losing it.

question: Thy wit is a very Bitter-sweeting, / It is a most sharpe sawce.
correct_answers: And is it not well seru'd into a Sweet-Goose?
incorrect_answers: Isn't it fitting for a fool?

question: God ye good morrow Gentlemen.
correct_answers: God ye gooden faire Gentlewoman.
incorrect_answers: Good evening, fair lady.
