correct_answers: Good heart, and yfaith I will tell her as much: Lord, Lord she will be a ioyfull woman.
incorrect_answers: Sure thing, I'll tell her. Oh, she'll be so happy!

question: Is your man secret, did you nere heare say two may keepe counsell putting one away.
correct_answers: Warrant thee my man as true as steele.
incorrect_answers: I assure you, my man is as reliable as steel.

question: The clocke strook nine, when I did send the Nurse,
correct_answers: In halfe an houre she promised to returne,
incorrect_answers: She promised to come back in half an hour.

question: In halfe an houre she promised to returne,
correct_answers: Perchance she cannot meete him: that's not so:
incorrect_answers: Maybe she can't meet him: that's not true.

question: Perchance she cannot meete him: that's not so:
correct_answers: Oh she is lame, Loues Herauld should be thoughts,
incorrect_answers: Oh, she is so slow; love’s messenger should be quick thoughts.

question: Oh she is lame, Loues Herauld should be thoughts,
correct_answers: Now is the Sun vpon the highmost hill
incorrect_answers: The sun is at its highest point.

question: Now is the Sun vpon the highmost hill
correct_answers: I three long houres, yet she is not come.
incorrect_answers: I've been waiting three long hours, and she's still not here.

question: I three long houres, yet she is not come.
correct_answers: Had she affections and warme youthfull blood,
incorrect_answers: If she had feelings and youthful passion,

question: Had she affections and warme youthfull blood,
correct_answers: O God she comes, O hony Nurse what newes?
incorrect_answers: Oh God, here she comes. Tell me, Nurse, what’s the news?

question: Hast thou met with him? send thy man away.
correct_answers: Now good sweet Nurse: / O Lord, why lookest thou sad?
incorrect_answers: Hey, dear Nurse: Oh Lord, why do you look so sad?

question: Though newes, be sad, yet tell them merrily.
correct_answers: If good thou sham'st the musicke of sweet newes,
incorrect_answers: If you're embarrassed by the sound of good news,

question: How art thou out of breath, when thou hast breth
correct_answers: To say to me, that thou art out of breath?
incorrect_answers: You’re telling me you’re out of breath?

question: Is thy newes good or bad? answere to that,
correct_answers: Say either, and Ile stay the circustance:
incorrect_answers: Just say which one, and I'll wait to hear the details.

question: Well, you haue made a simple choice, you know
correct_answers: not how to chuse a man: Romeo, no not he though
incorrect_answers: I don't know how to choose a man; not Romeo, no, not him.

question: Are you so hot? marrie come vp I trow,
correct_answers: Is this the Poultis for my aking bones?
incorrect_answers: Is this the remedy for my aching bones?

question: The day is hot, the Capulets abroad:
correct_answers: And if we meet, we shal not scape a brawle,
incorrect_answers: And if we run into each other, we won't avoid a fight.

question: Thou art like one of these fellowes, that when he enters the confines of a Tauerne, claps me his Sword vpon the Table, and sayes, God send me no need of thee:
correct_answers: and by the operation of the second cup, drawes him on the Drawer, when indeed there is no need.
incorrect_answers: And with the effect of the second drink, he picks a fight with the bartender, even though it's unnecessary.

question: And I were so apt to quarell as thou art, any man should buy the Fee-simple of my life, for an houre and a quarter.
correct_answers: The Fee-simple? O simple.
incorrect_answers: The full ownership? Oh, how simple.

question: Gentlemen, Good den, a word with one of you.
correct_answers: And but one word with one of vs? couple it with something, make it a word and a blow.
incorrect_answers: Are you just going to say one thing to one of us? Add something to it, like a word and a punch.

question: And but one word with one of vs? couple it with something, make it a word and a blow.
correct_answers: You shall find me apt inough to that sir, and you will giue me occasion.
incorrect_answers: You'll see I'm ready for that if you give me the chance.

question: You shall find me apt inough to that sir, and you will giue me occasion.
correct_answers: Could you not take some occasion without giuing?
incorrect_answers: Couldn't you find an excuse without giving?

question: Mercutio thou consort'st with Romeo.
correct_answers: Consort? what dost thou make vs Minstrels? & thou make Minstrels of vs, looke to heare nothing but discords: heere's my fiddlesticke, heere's that shall make you daunce. Come consort.
incorrect_answers: Band? Do you think we're musicians? If you call us musicians, expect to hear nothing but clashes: here's my bow, ready to make you dance. Come on, band.

question: Well peace be with you sir, here comes my man.
correct_answers: But Ile be hang'd sir if he weare your Liuery.
incorrect_answers: But I'll bet he doesn't work for you.

question: Tibalt, the reason that I haue to loue thee, Doth much excuse the appertaining rage To such a greeting:
correct_answers: Villaine am I none; Therefore farewell, I see thou know'st me not.
incorrect_answers: I'm no villain; goodbye, I see you don't recognize me.

question: Boy, this shall not excuse the iniuries That thou hast done me, therefore turne and draw.
correct_answers: I do protest I neuer iniur'd thee, But lou'd thee better then thou can'st deuise: Till thou shalt know the reason of my loue, And so good Capulet, which name I tender As dearely as my owne, be satisfied.
incorrect_answers: I swear I never wronged you, but loved you more than you could imagine. Until you understand why I care, please believe, good Capulet, I value your name as much as my own, and be at peace.

question: Come sir, your Passado.
correct_answers: Draw Benuolio, beat downe their weapons: Gentlemen, for shame forbeare this outrage, Tibalt, Mercutio, the Prince expresly hath Forbidden bandying in Verona streetes. Hold Tybalt, good Mercutio.
incorrect_answers: Benvolio, draw your sword and stop this fight. Gentlemen, stop this disgraceful behavior. Tybalt, Mercutio, the Prince has specifically forbidden fighting in the streets of Verona. Hold on, Tybalt, good Mercutio.

question: I, I, a scratch, a scratch, marry 'tis inough
correct_answers: Where is my Page? go Villaine fetch a Surgeon.
incorrect_answers: Where's my page? Go, you scoundrel, get a doctor.

question: Courage man, the hurt cannot be much.
correct_answers: No: 'tis not so deepe as a well, nor so wide as a Church doore, but 'tis inough, 'twill serue: aske for me to morrow, and you shall find me a graue man. I am pepper'd I warrant, for this world: a plague a both your houses.
incorrect_answers: No, it's not as deep as a well or as wide as a church door, but it's enough, it'll do. Ask for me tomorrow and you'll find me dead. I'm done for, I swear, a curse on both your houses.

question: I thought all for the best.
correct_answers: Helpe me into some house Benuolio, Or I shall faint: a plague a both your houses.
incorrect_answers: Help me get to a house, Benvolio, or I’m going to faint. Curse both your families.

question: Here comes the Furious Tybalt backe againe.
correct_answers: He gon in triumph, and Mercutio slaine?
incorrect_answers: He’s gone off celebrating while Mercutio is dead?

question: This shall determine that.
correct_answers: They fight. Tybalt falles.
incorrect_answers: They fight. Tybalt falls.

question: Romeo, away be gone:
correct_answers: The Citizens are vp, and Tybalt slaine, Stand not amaz'd, the Prince will Doome thee death If thou art taken: hence, be gone, away.
incorrect_answers: The citizens are up in arms, and Tybalt is dead. Don't stand there shocked; the Prince will sentence you to death if you're caught. Get out of here, now!

question: O Noble Prince, I can discouer all
correct_answers: There lies the man slaine by young Romeo
incorrect_answers: There lies the man killed by young Romeo.

question: Ay me, what newes? / Why dost thou wring thy hands.
correct_answers:
A weladay, hee's dead, hee's dead,
We are vndone Lady, we are vndone.
Alacke the day, hee's gone, hee's kil'd, he's dead.
incorrect_answers: Oh no, he's dead, he's dead. We're ruined, my lady, we're ruined. What a terrible day, he's gone, he's been killed, he's dead.

question: I saw the wound, I saw it with mine eyes,
correct_answers: God saue the marke, here on his manly brest
incorrect_answers: God bless him, here on his chest

question: O breake my heart, / Poore Banckrout breake at once,
correct_answers: To prison eyes, nere looke on libertie.
incorrect_answers: To someone in prison, freedom is never seen.

question: O Tybalt, Tybalt, the best Friend I had:
correct_answers: O curteous Tybalt honest Gentleman,
incorrect_answers: Oh, polite Tybalt, an honorable gentleman.

question: Tybalt is gone, and Romeo banished,
correct_answers: Romeo that kil'd him, he is banished.
incorrect_answers: Romeo, who killed him, is banished.

question: There's no trust,
correct_answers: no faith, no honestie in men, / All periur'd, all forsworne, all naught, all dissemblers,
incorrect_answers: There's no trust or honesty in people anymore; everyone lies, everyone breaks promises, everyone is bad, everyone is a faker.

question: Blister'd be thy tongue
correct_answers: For such a wish, he was not borne to shame: Vpon his brow shame is asham'd to sit;
incorrect_answers: He wasn't meant to feel shame; shame itself would be embarrassed to be on his face.

question: Will you go to them? I will bring you thither.
correct_answers: Wash they his wounds with tears: mine shal be spentWhen theirs are drie for Romeo's banishment.
incorrect_answers: They can wash his wounds with their tears; I'll mourn once their tears for Romeo's banishment have dried up.

question: Come Cord, come Nurse, Ile to my wedding bed,And death not Romeo, take my Maiden head.
correct_answers: Hie to your Chamber, Ile find RomeoTo comfort you, I wot well where he is:
incorrect_answers: Go to your room. I'll find Romeo to comfort you; I know exactly where he is.

question: Romeo come forth, / Come forth thou fearfull man,
correct_answers: Father what newes? / What is the Princes Doome?
incorrect_answers: Dad, what's the news? What did the Prince decide?

question: Ha, banishment? be mercifull, say death:
correct_answers: Here from Verona art thou banished: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.
incorrect_answers: You have been banished from Verona: be patient, the world is big and full of possibilities.

question: Here from Verona art thou banished: Be patient, for the world is broad and wide.
correct_answers: There is no world without Verona walles, But Purgatorie, Torture, hell it selfe: Hence banished, is banisht from the world, And worlds exile is death.
incorrect_answers: If there's no life outside Verona's walls, it's like being in purgatory, tortured, or in hell itself. Being banished from here means being cut off from the world, and that kind of exile feels like death.

question: There is no world without Verona walles, But Purgatorie, Torture, hell it selfe: Hence banished, is banisht from the world, And worlds exile is death.
correct_answers: Is death, mistearm'd, calling death banished, Thou cut'st my head off with a golden Axe, And smilest vpon the stroke that murders me.
incorrect_answers: Is death, wrongly called banishment, like you chopping off my head with a golden axe and smiling as you do it?

question: Harke how they knocke: (Who's there) Romeo arise,
correct_answers: Thou wilt be taken, stay a while, stand vp
incorrect_answers: You'll get caught. Stop for a moment and stand up.

question: There on the ground, / With his owne teares made drunke.
correct_answers: O he is euen in my Mistresse case,
incorrect_answers: Oh, he's in the same situation as my mistress.

question: O he is euen in my Mistresse case,
correct_answers: Iust in her case. O wofull simpathy:
incorrect_answers: It's just her situation. Oh, what a sad fate.

question: Pittious predicament, euen so lies she,
correct_answers: Blubbring and weeping, weeping and blubbring,
incorrect_answers: Crying and sobbing, sobbing and crying,

question: Stand vp, stand vp, stand and you be a man,
correct_answers: For Iuliets sake, for her sake rise and stand:
incorrect_answers: For Juliet's sake, get up and stand.

question: Why should you fall into so deepe an O.
correct_answers: Speak'st thou of Iuliet? how is it with her?
incorrect_answers: Are you talking about Juliet? How is she?

question: Oh she sayes nothing sir, but weeps and weeps,
correct_answers: And now fals on her bed, and then starts vp,
incorrect_answers: And now she falls on her bed, then suddenly gets up,

question: And Tybalt calls, and then on Romeo cries,
correct_answers: As if that name shot from the dead leuell of a Gun,
incorrect_answers: Like that name was fired from the barrel of a gun,

question: As if that name shot from the dead leuell of a Gun,
correct_answers: Did murder her, as that names cursed hand
incorrect_answers: He killed her with that cursed hand.

question: Did murder her, as that names cursed hand
correct_answers: Murdred her kinsman. Oh tell me Frier, tell me,
incorrect_answers: She killed her relative. Oh, tell me, Friar, please tell me,

question: Hold thy desperate hand:
correct_answers: Art thou a man? thy forme cries out thou art:
incorrect_answers: Are you a man? Your appearance clearly says you are.

question: Art thou a man? thy forme cries out thou art:
correct_answers: Thy teares are womanish, thy wild acts denote
incorrect_answers: Your tears are childish, and your wild actions show

question: It was the Nightingale, and not the Larke,
correct_answers: That pier'st the fearefull hollow of thine eare.
incorrect_answers: That pierces the fearful hollow of your ear.

question: No Nightingale: looke Loue what enuious streakes
correct_answers: Do lace the seuering Cloudes in yonder East.
incorrect_answers: Are streaking the parting clouds in the eastern sky.

question: Yond light is not daylight, I know it I:
correct_answers: It is some Meteor that the Sun exhales.
incorrect_answers: It's just a meteor that the sun has caused.

question: Let me be tane, let me be put to death,
correct_answers: I am content, so thou wilt haue it so.
incorrect_answers: I'm fine with it if that's what you want.

question: Ile say yon gray is not the mornings eye,
correct_answers: 'Tis but the pale reflexe of Cinthias brow.
incorrect_answers: It's just the faint reflection of the moon.

question: I haue more care to stay, then will to go:
correct_answers: Come death and welcome, Iuliet wills it so.
incorrect_answers: Come death, if that’s what Juliet wants.

question: It is, it is, hie hence be gone away:
correct_answers: It is the Larke that sings so out of tune.
incorrect_answers: It's the lark singing off-key.

question: Your Lady Mother is comming to your chamber,
correct_answers: The day is broke, be wary, looke about.
incorrect_answers: It's daylight, stay alert and keep an eye out.

question: Then window let day in, and let life out.
correct_answers: Farewell, farewell, one kisse and Ile descend.
incorrect_answers: Goodbye, goodbye, one kiss and I'll come down.

question: Art thou gone so? Loue, Lord, ay Husband, Friend,
correct_answers: I must heare from thee euery day in the houre,
incorrect_answers: I need to hear from you every hour of the day.

question: O God! I haue an ill Diuining soule,
correct_answers: Me thinkes I see thee now, thou art so lowe,
incorrect_answers: I think I see you now, you're so far away,

question: And trust me Loue, in my eye so do you:
correct_answers: O Fortune, Fortune, all men call thee fickle,
incorrect_answers: Oh Luck, Luck, everyone says you're unreliable,

question: Who ist that calls? Is it my Lady Mother.
correct_answers: Is she not downe so late, or vp so early?
incorrect_answers: Is she up early or did she stay up late?

question: Yet let me weepe, for such a feeling losse.
correct_answers: So shall you feele the losse, but not the Friend
incorrect_answers: You will feel the loss, but not miss the friend.

question: Feeling so the losse,
correct_answers: I cannot chuse but euer weepe the Friend.
incorrect_answers: I can't help but always cry for my friend.

question: Well Girle, thou weep'st not so much for his death,
correct_answers: As that the Villaine liues which slaughter'd him.
incorrect_answers: The villain who killed him is still alive.

question: Villaine and he, be many Miles assunder:
correct_answers: God pardon, I doe with all my heart:
incorrect_answers: God forgive me, I truly mean it.

question: God pardon, I doe with all my heart:
correct_answers: And yet no man like he, doth grieue my heart.
incorrect_answers: But no one else breaks my heart like he does.

question: That is because the Traitor liues.
correct_answers: I Madam from the reach of these my hands:
incorrect_answers: Yes, ma'am, out of my reach.

question: I Madam from the reach of these my hands:
correct_answers: Would none but I might venge my Cozins death.
incorrect_answers: I wish I could be the one to avenge my cousin's death.

question: We will haue vengeance for it, feare thou not.
correct_answers: Then weepe no more, Ile send to one in Mantua,
incorrect_answers: Don’t cry anymore, I’ll send word to someone in Mantua.

question: Then weepe no more, Ile send to one in Mantua,
correct_answers: Where that same banisht Run-agate doth liue,
incorrect_answers: Where that same banished runaway lives,

question: Where that same banisht Run-agate doth liue,
correct_answers: Shall giue him such an vnaccustom'd dram,
incorrect_answers: I'll give him such an unusual dose,

question: Shall giue him such an vnaccustom'd dram,
correct_answers: That he shall soone keepe Tybalt company:
incorrect_answers: He'll soon join Tybalt.

question: I hope thou wilt be satisfied.
correct_answers: Indeed I neuer shall be satisfied
incorrect_answers: I'll never be satisfied.

question: Madam if you could find out but a man
correct_answers: To beare a poyson, I would temper it;
incorrect_answers: If I had poison, I would dilute it.

question: Find thou the meanes, and Ile find such a man.
correct_answers: But now Ile tell thee ioyfull tidings Gyrle.
incorrect_answers: But now I have good news for you, girl.

question: One who to put thee from thy heauinesse,
correct_answers: Hath sorted out a sudden day of ioy,
incorrect_answers: Has planned a sudden day of joy,

question: Hath sorted out a sudden day of ioy,
correct_answers: That thou expects not, nor I lookt not for.
incorrect_answers: You weren’t expecting that, and neither was I.

question: I pray you tell my Lord and Father Madam,
correct_answers: I will not marrie yet, and when I doe, I sweare
incorrect_answers: I'm not getting married yet, and when I do, I swear

question: I will not marrie yet, and when I doe, I sweare
correct_answers: It shallbe Romeo, whom you know I hate
incorrect_answers: It will be Romeo, whom you know I hate.

question: I would the foole were married to her graue.
correct_answers: Soft, take me with you, take me with you wife,
incorrect_answers: Wait, hold on a moment, listen to me, my wife,

question: Is she not proud? doth she not count her blest,
correct_answers: Vnworthy as she is, that we haue wrought
incorrect_answers: She doesn't deserve what we've done for her.

question: Proud can I neuer be of what I haue,
correct_answers: But thankfull that you haue
incorrect_answers: But grateful that you have

question: Is there no pittie sitting in the Cloudes,
correct_answers: That sees into the bottome of my griefe?
incorrect_answers: Who can understand the depth of my sorrow?

question: O sweet my Mother cast me not away,
correct_answers: Delay this marriage, for a month, a weeke,
incorrect_answers: Postpone this marriage for a month, or even a week.

question: Talk not to me, for Ile not speake a word,
correct_answers: Do as thou wilt, for I haue done with thee.
incorrect_answers: Do whatever you want; I'm done with you.

question: Immoderately she weepes for Tybalts death,
correct_answers: And therfore haue I little talke of Loue,
incorrect_answers: That's why I don't talk much about love.

question: Now sir, her Father counts it dangerous
correct_answers: That she doth giue her sorrow so much sway:
incorrect_answers: She lets her sorrow take over too much.

question: And in his wisedome, hasts our marriage,
correct_answers: To stop the inundation of her teares,
incorrect_answers: To stop her from crying uncontrollably,

question: I would I knew not why it should be slow'd.
correct_answers: Looke sir, here comes the Lady towards my Cell.
incorrect_answers: Hey sir, here comes the Lady to my room.

question: Happily met, my Lady and my wife.
correct_answers: That may be sir, when I may be a wife.
incorrect_answers: Maybe, sir, when I'm a wife.

question: To answere that, I should confesse to you.
correct_answers: Do not denie to him, that you Loue me.
incorrect_answers: Don't deny to him that you love me.

question: Do not denie to him, that you Loue me.
correct_answers: I will confesse to you that I Loue him.
incorrect_answers: I'll admit to you that I love him.

question: I will confesse to you that I Loue him.
correct_answers: So will ye, I am sure that you Loue me.
incorrect_answers: You will too; I'm sure that you love me.

question: So will ye, I am sure that you Loue me.
correct_answers: If I do so, it will be of more price, Benig spoke behind your backe, then to your face.
incorrect_answers: If I do that, it will be more valuable, coming from someone who spoke behind your back, than someone who said it to your face.

question: If I do so, it will be of more price, Benig spoke behind your backe, then to your face.
correct_answers: Poore soule, thy face is much abus'd with teares.
incorrect_answers: Poor thing, your face is all messed up from crying.

question: Poore soule, thy face is much abus'd with teares.
correct_answers: The teares haue got small victorie by that: For it was bad inough before their spight.
incorrect_answers: The tears haven't achieved much because it was already bad enough before they came.

question: The teares haue got small victorie by that: For it was bad inough before their spight.
correct_answers: Thou wrong'st it more then teares with that report.
incorrect_answers: You're making it worse than tears would with that statement.

question: Thou wrong'st it more then teares with that report.
correct_answers: That is no slaunder sir, which is a truth, And what I spake, I spake it to thy face.
incorrect_answers: It's not slander, sir, if it's true, and I said it right to your face.

question: That is no slaunder sir, which is a truth, And what I spake, I spake it to thy face.
correct_answers: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slaundred it.
incorrect_answers: Your face belongs to me, and you've disrespected it.

question: Thy face is mine, and thou hast slaundred it.
correct_answers: It may be so, for it is not mine owne.
incorrect_answers: That could be true, because it’s not mine.

question: It may be so, for it is not mine owne.
correct_answers: Are you at leisure, Holy Father now, Or shall I come to you at euening Masse?
incorrect_answers: Are you free right now, Holy Father, or should I come to see you during the evening Mass?

question: My leisure serues me pensiue daughter now.
correct_answers: Godsheild: I should disturbe Deuotion, Iuliet, on Thursday early will I rowse yee, Till then adue, and keepe this holy kisse.
incorrect_answers: God forbid I should disrupt your prayers. Juliet, I'll wake you early on Thursday. Until then, goodbye, and keep this holy kiss.

question: O Iuliet, I alreadie know thy griefe,
correct_answers: It streames me past the compasse of my wits:
incorrect_answers: It's beyond my understanding.

question: I heare thou must and nothing may prorogue it,
correct_answers: On Thursday next be married to this Countie.
incorrect_answers: Get married to this count next Thursday.

question: Tell me not Frier that thou hearest of this,
correct_answers: Vnlesse thou tell me how I may preuent it:
incorrect_answers: Unless you tell me how I can prevent it:

question: If in thy wisedome, thou canst giue no helpe,
correct_answers: Do thou but call my resolution wise,
incorrect_answers: Just say my decision is sensible,

question: God ioyn'd my heart, and Romeos, thou our hands,
correct_answers: And ere this hand bythee to Romeo seal'd:
incorrect_answers: Before this hand promised itself to Romeo:

question: Therefore out of thy long expetien'st time,
correct_answers: Giue me some present counsell, or behold
incorrect_answers: Give me some advice right now, or watch

question: Hold Daughter, I doe spie a kind of hope,
correct_answers: Which craues as desperate an execution,
incorrect_answers: That requires an equally drastic action,

question: If rather then to marrie Countie Paris
correct_answers: Thou hast the strength of will to stay thy selfe,
incorrect_answers: You have the willpower to control yourself.

question: Then is it likely thou wilt vndertake
correct_answers: A thinglike death to chide away this shame,
incorrect_answers: A death-like state to erase this shame,

question: And if thou dar'st, Ile giue thee remedie.
correct_answers: Oh bid me leape, rather then marrie Paris,
incorrect_answers: Oh, ask me to jump rather than marry Paris.

question: Hold then: goe home, be merrie, giue consent,
correct_answers: To marrie Paris: wensday is to morrow,
incorrect_answers: To marry Paris: Wednesday is tomorrow.

question: Now when the Bridegroome in the morning comes,
correct_answers: To rowse thee from thy bed, there art thou dead:
incorrect_answers: To wake you from your sleep, that's where you lie dead.

question: Send for the Countie, goe tell him of this,
correct_answers: Ile haue this knot knit vp to morrow morning.
incorrect_answers: I'll have this resolved by tomorrow morning.

question: I met the youthfull Lord at Lawrence Cell,
correct_answers: And gaue him what becomed Loue I might, Not stepping ore the bounds of modestie.
incorrect_answers: And gave him all the love I could, without crossing the lines of modesty.

question: Why I am glad on't, this is well, stand vp,
correct_answers: This is as't should be, let me see the County: I marrie go I say, and fetch him hither.
incorrect_answers: This is how it should be. Let me see the Count. Yes, go and bring him here.

question: Nurse will you goe with me into my Closet,
correct_answers: To helpe me sort such needfull ornaments, As you thinke fit to furnish me to morrow?
incorrect_answers: Can you help me gather the necessary accessories you think I'll need for tomorrow?

question: Tush, I will stirre about,
correct_answers: And all things shall be well, I warrant thee wife: Go thou to Iuliet, helpe to decke vp her, Ile not to bed to night, let me alone: Ile play the huswife for this once. What ho?
incorrect_answers: Everything will be fine, I promise you, my wife. Go to Juliet and help get her ready. I won't go to bed tonight; leave it to me. I'll take care of things for once. What's going on?

question: No Madam, we haue cul'd such necessaries As are behoouefull for our state to morrow:
correct_answers: So please you, let me now be left alone; And let the Nurse this night sit vp with you, For I am sure, you haue your hands full all, In this so sudden businesse.
incorrect_answers: Please, let me be alone now. Let the Nurse stay up with you tonight because I know you're all very busy with this sudden situation.

question: No not a whit: what? I haue watcht ere now All night for lesse cause, and nere beene sicke.
correct_answers: I you haue bin a Mouse-hunt in your time, But I will watch you from such watching now.
incorrect_answers: You've been a womanizer in the past, but I’ll keep an eye on you from now on to prevent that.

question: Make hast, make hast, sirrah, fetch drier Logs. Call Peter, he will shew thee where they are.
correct_answers: I haue a head sir, that will find out logs, And neuer trouble Peter for the matter.
incorrect_answers: I have a mind, sir, that will take care of finding logs without bothering Peter about it.

question: Masse and well said, a merrie horson, ha,  Thou shalt be loggerhead; good Father, 'tis day.
correct_answers: The Countie will be here with Musicke straight, For so he said he would, Play Musicke I heare him neere, Nurse, wife, what ho? what Nurse I say?
incorrect_answers: The Count will be here with music soon, just like he said. I hear the music coming closer. Nurse, wife, where are you? Nurse, I’m calling you!

question: Mistris, what Mistris? Iuliet? Fast I warrant her she.
correct_answers: Why Lambe, why Lady? fie you sluggabed, Why Loue I say? Madam, sweet heart: why Bride?
incorrect_answers: Why are you still in bed? Hey, wake up, sweetheart! Come on, darling, time to get up!

question: What not a word? You take your peniworths now.
correct_answers: Sleepe for a weeke, for the next night I warrant The Countie Paris hath set vp his rest, That you shall rest but little, God forgiue me: Marrie and Amen: how sound is she a sleepe?
incorrect_answers: Get some sleep this week, because tomorrow night I bet Count Paris will keep you up, hardly letting you rest. God forgive me—well, marry and amen—how soundly she's sleeping!

question: Looke, looke, oh heauie day.
correct_answers: O me, O me, my Child, my onely life: Reuiue, looke vp, or I will die with thee: Helpe, helpe, call helpe.
incorrect_answers: Oh no, my child, my only life: wake up, open your eyes, or I'll die with you. Help, someone call for help!

question: O me, O me, my Child, my onely life: Reuiue, looke vp, or I will die with thee: Helpe, helpe, call helpe.
correct_answers: For shame bring Iuliet forth, her Lord is come.
incorrect_answers: Get Juliet out here; her husband is here.

question: For shame bring Iuliet forth, her Lord is come.
correct_answers: Shee's dead: deceast, shee's dead: alacke the day.
incorrect_answers: She's gone, she's passed away. What a sad day.

question: Ha? Let me see her: out alas shee's cold,
correct_answers: Her blood is setled and her ioynts are stiffe:
incorrect_answers: Her blood has settled, and her joints are stiff.

question: Her blood is setled and her ioynts are stiffe:
correct_answers: Life and these lips haue long bene seperated:
incorrect_answers: She's been dead for a while now.

question: Ready to go, but neuer to returne.
correct_answers: O Sonne, the night before thy wedding day,
incorrect_answers: The night before your wedding day, my son,

question: Never was seene so blacke a day as this:
correct_answers: O wofull day, O wofull day.
incorrect_answers: What a terrible day, what a terrible day.

question: Beguild, diuorced, wronged, spighted, slaine,
correct_answers: Most detestable death, by thee beguil'd, By cruell, cruell thee, quite ouerthrowne: O loue, O life; not life, but loue in death.
incorrect_answers: Horrible death, you've tricked me and completely undone me with your cruelty: Oh love, oh life; it’s not life, but love in death.

question: Despis'd, distressed, hated, martir'd, kil'd,
correct_answers: Vncomfortable time, why cam'st thou now To murther, murther our solemnitie?
incorrect_answers: Terrible timing, why did you have to come now and ruin our celebration?

question: O Child, O Child; my soule, and not my Child,
correct_answers: Dead art thou, alacke my Child is dead, And with my Child, my ioyes are buried.
incorrect_answers: You're dead, oh no, my child is gone, and with my child, my happiness is buried.

question: Peace ho for shame, confusions: Care liues not
correct_answers: In these confusions, heauen and your selfe Had part in this faire Maid, now heauen hath all, And all the better is it for the Maid: Your part in her, you could not keepe from death, But heauen keepes his part in eternall life: The most you sought was her promotion, For 'twas your heauen, she should be aduan'st, And weepe ye now, seeing she is aduan'st Aboue the Cloudes, as high as Heauen it selfe? O in this loue, you loue your Child so ill, That you run mad, seeing that she is well: Shee's not well married, that liues married long, But shee's best married, that dies married yong.
incorrect_answers: In all this turmoil, both heaven and yourself had a role in this lovely girl, but now heaven has taken her completely, and it's better for her. You couldn't protect your share of her from death, but heaven guards its part in eternal life. You wanted the best for her because it was your dream to see her rise. And now you cry because she's risen above the clouds, as high as heaven itself? In this love, you actually harm your child because you go mad upon seeing that she is in a better place. It's not the one who lives long in marriage who is well-married, but the one who dies young, married, who is best off.

question: Drie vp your teares, and sticke your Rosemarie
correct_answers: On this faire Coarse, and as the custome is, And in her best array beare her to Church: For though some Nature bids all vs lament, Yet Natures teares are Reasons merriment.
incorrect_answers: On this beautiful body, as is the custom, carry her to the church in her best attire: For though it is natural for us all to mourn, nature's tears bring reason joy.

question: All things that we ordained Festiuall,
correct_answers: Turne from their office to blacke Funerall: Our instruments to melancholy Bells, Our wedding cheare, to a sad buriall Feast: Our solemne Hymnes, to sullen Dyrges change
incorrect_answers: Turn our celebration into a funeral: our music turns to somber bells, our wedding feast to a sorrowful meal, our joyful hymns to mournful dirges.

question: Sir go you in; and Madam, go with him,
correct_answers: And go sir Paris, euery one prepare
incorrect_answers: Alright Paris, everyone get ready.

question: And go sir Paris, euery one prepare
correct_answers: To follow this faire Coarse vnto her graue:
incorrect_answers: To follow this lovely body to her grave.

question: Honest goodfellowes: Ah put vp, put vp,
correct_answers: For well you know, this is a pitifull case.
incorrect_answers: You know very well this is a sad situation.

question: Why hearts ease;
correct_answers: O Musitions, / Because my heart it selfe plaies, my heart is full.
incorrect_answers: Musicians, because my heart is already playing, my heart is full.

question: Seruing creature.
correct_answers: Then will I lay the seruing Creatures Dagger on your pate. I will carie no Crochets, Ile Re you, Ile Fa you, do you note me?
incorrect_answers: I'll smack you on the head with the servant's dagger. I won't be taking any nonsense. Do you hear me?

question: And you Re vs, and Fa vs, you Note vs.
correct_answers: Pray you put vp your Dagger, / And put out your wit.
incorrect_answers: Please put away your dagger and use your common sense.

question: Pray you put vp your Dagger, / And put out your wit.
correct_answers: Then haue at you with my wit. / I will drie-beate you with an yron wit, / And put vp my yron Dagger. / Answere me like men:
incorrect_answers: Alright, let's see how clever I can be. I'll outsmart you with my sharp mind and put away my iron dagger. Respond to me like men.

question: Then haue at you with my wit. / I will drie-beate you with an yron wit, / And put vp my yron Dagger. / Answere me like men:
correct_answers: When griping griefes the heart doth wound, then Musicke with her siluer sound.
incorrect_answers: When deep sorrow wounds the heart, music with its soothing sound.

question: Mary sir, because siluer hath a sweet sound.
correct_answers: Pratest, what say you Hugh Rebicke?
incorrect_answers: So, what do you think, Hugh Rebicke?

question: I say siluer sound, because Musitions sound for siluer
correct_answers: Pratest to, what say you Iames Sound-Post?
incorrect_answers: What do you think, James Sound-Post?

question: Faith I know not what to say.
correct_answers: O I cry you mercy, you are the Singer. / I will say for you; it is Musicke with her siluer sound, / Because Musitions haue no gold for sounding:
incorrect_answers: Oh, I beg your pardon, you're the singer. I'll say it for you; it's music with its silver sound because musicians don't have gold for playing.

question: O I cry you mercy, you are the Singer. / I will say for you; it is Musicke with her siluer sound, / Because Musitions haue no gold for sounding:
correct_answers: Then Musicke with her siluer sound, with speedy helpe doth lend redresse.
incorrect_answers: Then music, with its sweet sound, quickly provides relief.

question: Then she is well, and nothing can be ill.
correct_answers: Her body sleepes in Capels Monument, And her immortall part with Angels liue, I saw her laid low in her kindreds Vault, And presently tooke Poste to tell it you: O pardon me for bringing these ill newes, Since you did leaue it for my office Sir.
incorrect_answers: Her body is resting in the Capulet tomb, and her soul is with the angels. I saw her laid to rest in the family vault and quickly came to tell you. Please forgive me for bringing this bad news, since it was my duty to do so, sir.

question: Is it euen so? / Then I denie you Starres.
correct_answers: Thou knowest my lodging, get me inke and paper, And hire Post-Horses, I will hence to night.
incorrect_answers: You know where I’m staying; get me some ink and paper, and hire some horses. I’m leaving tonight.

question: I do beseech you sir, haue patience:
correct_answers: Your lookes are pale and wild, and do import Some misaduenture.
incorrect_answers: You look pale and wild, like something bad is about to happen.

question: Tush, thou art deceiu'd,
correct_answers: Leaue me, and do the thing I bid thee do.
incorrect_answers: Leave me and do what I told you to do.

question: No my good Lord.
correct_answers: Mo matter: Get thee gone, And hyre those Horses, Ile be with thee straight.
incorrect_answers: It doesn't matter. Go, hire those horses, and I'll be with you soon.

question: Well Iuliet, I will lie with thee to night:
correct_answers: Lets see for meanes: O mischiefe thou art swift, To enter in the thoughts of desperate men:
incorrect_answers: Let's figure out a way: Trouble, you enter desperate minds so quickly.

question: An if a man did need a poyson now,
correct_answers: Whose sale is persent death in Mantua, Here liues a Caitiffe wretch would sell it him.
incorrect_answers: It's illegal to sell it in Mantua, but there's a miserable guy here who would sell it to him.

question: Giue me thy Torch Boy, hence and stand aloft,
correct_answers: Yet put it out, for I would not be seene:
incorrect_answers: Turn it off, I don't want to be seen.

question: Vnder yond young Trees lay thee all along,
correct_answers: Holding thy eare close to the hollow ground,
incorrect_answers: Put your ear close to the ground,

question: I am almost afraid to stand alone
correct_answers: Here in the Churchyard, yet I will aduenture.
incorrect_answers: I'll take my chances here in the graveyard.

question: The Boy giues warning, something doth approach,
correct_answers: What cursed foot wanders this wayes to night,
incorrect_answers: Whose cursed foot is wandering this way tonight?

question: Giue me that Mattocke, & the wrenching Iron,
correct_answers: Hold take this Letter, early in the morning
incorrect_answers: Here, take this letter first thing in the morning.

question: Why I descend into this bed of death,
correct_answers: Is partly to behold my Ladies face:
incorrect_answers: It’s partly to see my lady’s face.

question: I will be gone sir, and not trouble you
correct_answers: So shalt thou shew me friendship: take thou that, Liue and be prosperous, and farewell good fellow.
incorrect_answers: That’s how you can show me friendship: take this, live well, be successful, and goodbye, my friend.

question: Thou detestable mawe, thou wombe of death, Gorg'd with the dearest morsell of the earth:
correct_answers: Thus I enforce thy rotten Iawes to open, And in despight, Ile cram thee with more food.
incorrect_answers: I force your decayed jaws to open, and out of spite, I'll stuff you with more food.

question: Wilt thou prouoke me? Then haue at thee Boy.
correct_answers: O Lord they fight, I will go call the Watch.
incorrect_answers: Oh no, they're fighting! I'll go get help.

question: O I am slaine, if thon be mercifull,
correct_answers: Open the Tombe, lay me with Iuliet.
incorrect_answers: Open the tomb and place me with Juliet.

question: In faith I will, let me peruse this face:
correct_answers: Mercutius kinsman, Noble Countie Paris,
incorrect_answers: Mercutio's relative, the honorable County Paris,

question: Mercutius kinsman, Noble Countie Paris,
correct_answers: What said my man, when my betossed soule
incorrect_answers: What did my servant say when my troubled soul

question: What said my man, when my betossed soule
correct_answers: Did not attend him as we rode? I thinke
incorrect_answers: Didn't he come with us while we were riding? I think so.

question: Did not attend him as we rode? I thinke
correct_answers: He told me Paris should haue married Iuliet.
incorrect_answers: He told me Paris was supposed to marry Juliet.

question: He told me Paris should haue married Iuliet.
correct_answers: Said he not so? Or did I dreame it so?
incorrect_answers: Did he really say that, or did I just dream it?

question: Or am I mad, hearing him talke of Iuliet,
correct_answers: To thinke it was so? O giue me thy hand,
incorrect_answers: Did you really think that? Oh, give me your hand.

question: O giue me thy hand,
correct_answers: One, writ with me in sowre misfortunes booke.
incorrect_answers: Someone who shares my bad luck.

question: One, writ with me in sowre misfortunes booke.
correct_answers: Ile burie thee in a triumphant graue.
incorrect_answers: I'll bury you in a glorious grave.

question: Ile burie thee in a triumphant graue.
correct_answers: A Graue; O no, a Lanthorne; slaughtred Youth:
incorrect_answers: A grave? No, more like a lantern holding a murdered youth.

question: A Graue; O no, a Lanthorne; slaughtred Youth:
correct_answers: For here lies Iuliet, and her beautie makes
incorrect_answers: Here's Juliet, and her beauty makes

question: For here lies Iuliet, and her beautie makes
correct_answers: This Vault a feasting presence full of light.
incorrect_answers: This room is a bright and festive space.

question: This Vault a feasting presence full of light.
correct_answers: Death lie thou there, by a dead man inter'd.
incorrect_answers: Death, you rest here, buried by a dead man.

question: Death lie thou there, by a dead man inter'd.
correct_answers: How oft when men are at the point of death,
incorrect_answers: How often when people are about to die,

question: How oft when men are at the point of death,
correct_answers: Haue they beene merrie? Which their Keepers call
incorrect_answers: Have they been in good spirits, as their caretakers say?

question: Haue they beene merrie? Which their Keepers call
correct_answers: A lightning before death? Oh how may I
incorrect_answers: Is it a flash of light before death? Oh, how can I

question: A lightning before death? Oh how may I
correct_answers: Call this a lightning? O my Loue, my Wife,
incorrect_answers: Is this what they call lightning? Oh my love, my wife,

question: Call this a lightning? O my Loue, my Wife,
correct_answers: Death that hath suckt the honey of thy breath,
incorrect_answers: Death has stolen the sweetness of your breath,

question: Death that hath suckt the honey of thy breath,
correct_answers: Hath had no power yet vpon thy Beautie:
incorrect_answers: Hasn't affected your beauty yet.

question: Hath had no power yet vpon thy Beautie:
correct_answers: Thou are not conquer'd: Beauties ensigne yet
incorrect_answers: You are not defeated: Beauty's banner still

question: Thou are not conquer'd: Beauties ensigne yet
correct_answers: Is Crymson in thy lips, and in thy cheekes,
incorrect_answers: Are your lips and cheeks colored crimson?

question: Is Crymson in thy lips, and in thy cheekes,
correct_answers: And Deaths pale flag is not aduanced there.
incorrect_answers: And Death's pale flag isn't raised there.

question: And Deaths pale flag is not aduanced there.
correct_answers: Tybalt, ly'st thou there in thy bloudy sheet?
incorrect_answers: Tybalt, are you lying there in your bloody shroud?

question: O what more fauour can I do to thee,
correct_answers: Then with that hand that cut thy youth in twaine,
incorrect_answers: Then with the hand that took your youth away,

question: Then with that hand that cut thy youth in twaine,
correct_answers: To sunder his that was thy enemie?
incorrect_answers: To destroy the one who was your enemy?

question: Forgiue me Cozen. Ah deare Iuliet:
correct_answers: Why art thou yet so faire? I will beleeue,
incorrect_answers: Why are you still so beautiful? I can't believe it.

question: Why art thou yet so faire? I will beleeue,
correct_answers: Shall I beleeue, that vnsubstantiall death is amorous?
incorrect_answers: Should I believe that death, which isn't even real, can feel love?

question: For feare of that, I still will stay with thee
correct_answers: And neuer from this Pallace of dym night Depart againe: come lie thou in my armes, / Heere's to thy health, where ere thou tumblest in. / O true Appothecarie!
incorrect_answers: And never leave this dark place again: come lie in my arms, here's to your health, wherever you are. Oh true Apothecary!

question: Thy drugs are quicke. Thus with a kisse I die.
correct_answers: Enter Frier with Lanthorne, Crow, and Spade. Fri.
incorrect_answers: The Friar enters with a lantern, a crowbar, and a spade.

question: Enter Frier with Lanthorne, Crow, and Spade. Fri.
correct_answers: St. Francis be my speed, how oft to night Haue my old feet stumbled at graues? Who's there?
incorrect_answers: God help me, how many times tonight have my old feet stumbled over graves? Who's there?

question: Here's one, a Friend, & one that knowes you well.
correct_answers: Blisse be vpon you. Tell me good my Friend What Torch is yond that vainely lends his light To grubs, and eyelesse Sculles? As I discerne, It burneth in the Capels Monument.
incorrect_answers: Blessings upon you. Tell me, my good friend, what is that torch over there that uselessly shines its light on worms and eyeless skulls? As far as I can see, it's burning in the Capulet's tomb.

question: O much I feare some ill vnluckie thing.
correct_answers: As I did sleepe vnder this young tree here, I dreamt my maister and another fought, And that my Maister slew him.
incorrect_answers: While I was sleeping under this young tree, I dreamt that my master and someone else were fighting, and my master killed him.

question: O the people in the streete crie Romeo.
correct_answers: Some Iuliet, and some Paris, and all runne With open outcry toward out Monument.
incorrect_answers: Some called for Juliet, some for Paris, and everyone rushed to our monument, shouting loudly.

question: Search, / Seeke, and know how, this foule murder comes.
correct_answers: Here is a Frier, and Slaughter'd Romeos man, With Instruments vpon them fit to open These dead mens Tombes.
incorrect_answers: Here's a friar and Romeo's murdered servant, with tools to open these tombs.

question: O heauen! / O wife looke how our Daughter bleedes!
correct_answers: This Dagger hath mistaine, for loe his house Is empty on the backe of Mountague, And is misheathed in my Daughters bosome.
incorrect_answers: This dagger has missed its mark, for look, it's empty on Montague's back, and instead, it's lodged in my daughter's chest.

question: Alas my liege, my wife is dead to night, Griefe of my Sonnes exile hath stopt her breath:
correct_answers: What further woe conspires against my age?
incorrect_answers: What more trouble is coming my way in my old age?

question: Looke: and thou shalt see.
correct_answers: O thou vntaught, what manners in is this,
incorrect_answers: You uneducated person, what kind of behavior is this?

question: Romeo there dead, was husband to that Iuliet, And she there dead, that's Romeos faithfull wife:
correct_answers: I married them; and their stolne marriage day Was Tybalts Doomesday: whose vntimely death Banish'd the new-made Bridegroome from this Citie: For whom (and not for Tybalt) Iuliet pinde.
incorrect_answers: I married them, but on their secret wedding day, Tybalt was killed, leading to the banishment of her new husband. Juliet mourned for him, not for Tybalt.

question: Giue me the Letter, I will look on it.
correct_answers: He came with flowres to strew his Ladies graue, And bid me stand aloofe, and so I did: Anon comes one with light to ope the Tombe, And by and by my Maister drew on him, And then I ran away to call the Watch.
incorrect_answers: He came with flowers to scatter on his lady's grave and told me to stand back, so I did. Then someone came with a light to open the tomb, and soon my master attacked him. Then I ran off to call the guards.

question: Where be these Enemies? Capulet, Mountague,
correct_answers: See what a scourge is laide vpon your hate,
incorrect_answers: Look at the punishment your hatred has brought.

question: IN sooth I know not why I am so sad,
correct_answers: It wearies me: you say it wearies you; But how I caught it, found it, or came by it, What stuffe 'tis made of, whereof it is borne, I am to learne:
incorrect_answers: It tires me out, and you say it tires you too; but how I got it, where it came from, what it's made of— I have yet to figure out.

question: Your minde is tossing on the Ocean,
correct_answers: There where your Argosies with portly saile Like Signiors and rich Burgers on the flood, Or as it were the Pageants of the sea, Do ouer-peere the pettie Traffiquers That curtsie to them, do them reuerence As they flye by them with their wouen wings.
incorrect_answers: Your large ships, with their grand sails, float on the sea like wealthy men or majestic parades, towering over the smaller trading boats that bow in respect as they pass by swiftly.

question: Beleeue me sir, had I such venture forth,
correct_answers: The better part of my affections, would Be with my hopes abroad. I should be still Plucking the grasse to know where sits the winde, Peering in Maps for ports, and peers, and rodes: And euery obiect that might make me feare Misfortune to my ventures, out of doubt Would make me sad.
incorrect_answers: Most of my feelings would be with my hopes overseas. I would constantly be checking the grass to see which way the wind is blowing, looking at maps for ports and docks and roads, and anything that might make me worry about bad luck for my journeys would definitely make me sad.

question: My winde cooling my broth,
correct_answers: Would blow me to an Ague, when I thought What harme a winde too great might doe at sea. I should not see the sandie houre-glasse runne, But I should thinke of shallows, and of flats, And see my wealthy Andrew docks in sand, Vailing her high top lower then her ribs To kisse her buriall; should I goe to Church And see the holy edifice of stone, And not bethinke me straight of dangerous rocks, Which touching but my gentle Vessels side Would scatter all her spices on the streame, Enrobe the roring waters with my silkes
incorrect_answers: A strong wind would make me shiver, thinking of the damage it could cause at sea. Every time I saw an hourglass, I would think of shallow waters and sandbanks and imagine my rich ship stuck there, sinking down. If I went to church and saw the stone building, I would instantly think of dangerous rocks that could wreck my delicate ship, spreading its spices into the water and dressing the roaring waves with my silks.

question: And now worth nothing. Shall I haue the thought
correct_answers: To thinke on this, and shall I lacke the thought
incorrect_answers: To think about this, and will I be without the thought?

question: To thinke on this, and shall I lacke the thought
correct_answers: That such a thing bechaunc'd would make me sad?
incorrect_answers: If something like that happened, it would make me sad?

question: Your worth is very deere in my regard.
correct_answers: I take it your owne busines calls on you, And you embrace th' occasion to depart.
incorrect_answers: I assume you have your own matters to attend to, and you’re taking this opportunity to leave.

question: You look not well signior Anthonio,
correct_answers: You have too much respect upon the world.
incorrect_answers: You care too much about what the world thinks.

question: I hold the world but as the world Gratiano,
correct_answers: A stage, where every man must play a part, And mine a sad one.
incorrect_answers: Life is like a stage where everyone has a role to play, and mine is a sad one.

question: Let me play the fool,
correct_answers: With mirth and laughter let old wrinkles come, And let my liver rather heat with wine, Then my heart cool with mortifying groans.
incorrect_answers: Let old age come with happiness and laughter, and let me enjoy wine, rather than suffering with sorrow.

question: I love thee, and it is my love that speaks:
correct_answers: There are a sort of men, whose visages Do cream and mantle like a standing pond, And do a willful stillness entertain, With purpose to be dressed in an opinion Of wisdom, gravity, profound conceit, As who should say, I am sir an Oracle, And when I ope my lips, let no dog bark.
incorrect_answers: There are some people who look calm and composed on the outside, holding a deliberate silence, to make themselves seem wise and serious, as if they were saying, "I am an oracle, and when I speak, everyone should listen."

question: Well, we will leaue you then till dinner time.
correct_answers: I must be one of these same dumbe wise men, For Gratiano neuer let's me speake.
incorrect_answers: I guess I'm one of those quiet wise guys because Gratiano never lets me talk.

question: If to doe were as easie as to know what were good to doe, Chappels had beene Churches, and poore mens cottages Princes Pallaces:
correct_answers: it is a good Diuine that followes his owne instructions; I can easier teach twentie what were good to be done, then be one of the twentie to follow mine owne teaching
incorrect_answers: It's a good preacher who practices what they preach; I can easily teach twenty people what they should do, but it's harder to be one of the twenty who follows their own advice.

question: I may neither choose whom I would, nor refuse whom I dislike
correct_answers: so is the wil of a liuing daughter curb'd by the will of a dead father: it is not hard Nerrissa, that I cannot choose one, nor refuse none.
incorrect_answers: Just like a living daughter's will is restricted by the will of her dead father. It's tough, Nerissa, that I can't choose anyone or refuse anyone.

question: I that's a colt indeede, for he doth nothing but talke of his horse, and hee makes it a great appropriation to his owne good parts that he can shoo him himselfe:
correct_answers: I am much afraid my Ladie his mother plaid false with a Smyth.
incorrect_answers: I'm really worried that his mother cheated with a blacksmith.

question: Anthonio is a good man.
correct_answers: Haue you heard any imputation to the contrary.
incorrect_answers: Have you heard anything different?

question: Haue you heard any imputation to the contrary.
correct_answers: Ho no, no, no, no: my meaning in saying he is a good man, is to haue you vnderstand me that he is sufficient, yet his meanes are in supposition: he hath an Argosie bound to Tripolis, another to the Indies, I vnderstand moreouer vpon the Ryalta, he hath a third at Mexico, a fourth for England, and other ventures hee hath squandred abroad, but ships are but boords, Saylers but men, there be land rats, and water rats, water theeues, and land theeues, I meane Pyrats, and then there is the perrill of waters, windes, and rocks: the man is notwithstanding sufficient, three thousand ducats, I thinke I may take his bond.
incorrect_answers: No, no, no. When I said he's a good man, I meant he's reliable. He has a ship headed for Tripoli, another for the Indies, one in Mexico, a fourth bound for England, and other ventures scattered around. But ships can be lost, sailors are only human, and there are dangers like pirates, harsh waters, and rocks. Still, I believe he's trustworthy. I think I can take his bond for three thousand ducats.

question: This is signior Anthonio.
correct_answers: This is signior Anthonio.
incorrect_answers: This is Mr. Antonio.

question: Shylock, doe you heare.
correct_answers: I am debating of my present store, And by the neere gesse of my memorie I cannot instantly raise vp the grosse Of full three thousand ducats: what of that?
incorrect_answers: I'm thinking about my current funds, and from what I can remember, I can't quickly come up with the full three thousand ducats. So, what does it matter?

question: No, not take interest, not as you would say
correct_answers: Directly interest, marke what Iacob did
incorrect_answers: Pay attention to what Jacob did.

question: Directly interest, marke what Iacob did
correct_answers: When Laban and himselfe were compremyz'd
incorrect_answers: When Laban and he made a deal

question: When Laban and himselfe were compremyz'd
correct_answers: That all the eanelings which were streakt and pied
incorrect_answers: All the young animals that were striped and spotted

question: That all the eanelings which were streakt and pied
correct_answers: Should fall as Iacobs hier, the Ewes being rancke
incorrect_answers: Should inherit like Jacob, when the ewes were in heat

question: Should fall as Iacobs hier, the Ewes being rancke
correct_answers: In end of Autumne turned to the Rammes
incorrect_answers: At the end of autumn, they turned back to the rams.

question: In end of Autumne turned to the Rammes
correct_answers: And when the worke of generation was
incorrect_answers: And when the act of creation was done

question: And when the worke of generation was
correct_answers: Betweene these woolly breeders in the act
incorrect_answers: Between these woolly animals when they mate

question: Betweene these woolly breeders in the act
correct_answers: The skilfull shepheard pil'd me certaine wands
incorrect_answers: The skilled shepherd gave me some sticks

question: The skilfull shepheard pil'd me certaine wands
correct_answers: And in the dooing of the deede of kinde
incorrect_answers: And while performing the act of kindness

question: And in the dooing of the deede of kinde
correct_answers: He stucke them vp before the fulsome Ewes
incorrect_answers: He put them up in front of the fat sheep.

question: He stucke them vp before the fulsome Ewes
correct_answers: Who then conceauing, did in eaning time
incorrect_answers: Who, after conceiving, gave birth

question: Who then conceauing, did in eaning time
correct_answers: Fall party-colour'd lambs, and those were Iacobs.
incorrect_answers: Spotted lambs were born, and they belonged to Jacob.

question: This was a way to thriue, and he was blest
correct_answers: And thrift is blessing if men steale it not.
incorrect_answers: And saving money is good, as long as people don't steal.

question: Marke you this Bassanio
correct_answers: The diuell can cite Scripture for his purpose
incorrect_answers: The devil can quote Scripture to suit his agenda.

question: The diuell can cite Scripture for his purpose
correct_answers: An euill soule producing holy witnesse
incorrect_answers: An evil person pretending to be virtuous.

question: An euill soule producing holy witnesse
correct_answers: Is like a villaine with a smiling cheeke
incorrect_answers: Is like a villain with a smiling face

question: Is like a villaine with a smiling cheeke
correct_answers: A goodly apple rotten at the heart.
incorrect_answers: A nice apple that’s rotten inside.

question: I pray you leade me to the Caskets
correct_answers: To trie my fortune: By this Symitare That slew the Sophie, and a Persian Prince That won three fields of Sultan Solyman, I would ore-stare the sternest eies that looke: Out-braue the heart most daring on the earth: Plucke the yong sucking Cubs from the she Beare, Yea, mocke the Lion when he rores for pray To win the Ladie. But alas, the while If Hercules and Lychas plaie at dice Which is the better man, the greater throw May turne by fortune from the weaker hand: So is Alcides beaten by his rage, And so may I, blinde fortune leading me Misse that which one vnworthier may attaine, And die with grieuing.
incorrect_answers: To try my luck: By this scimitar that killed the Sophie and a Persian prince, and won three battles against Sultan Solyman, I would face the fiercest eyes and out-brave the boldest hearts. I’d take young cubs from a mother bear, even mock a lion when it roars for prey, just to win the lady. But alas, if Hercules and Lichas play dice to see who’s better, luck could turn the game in favor of the weaker hand. Just as Hercules is sometimes defeated by his own anger, I might be led by blind luck to miss what an unworthy person might win, and die grieving.

question: You must take your chance
correct_answers: And either not attempt to choose at all, Or sweare before you choose, if you choose wrong Neuer to speake to Ladie afterward In way of marriage, therefore be aduis'd.
incorrect_answers: You should either not try to choose at all, or swear that if you choose wrong, you'll never speak to a lady about marriage again. So think carefully.

question: Nor will not, come bring me vnto my chance.
correct_answers: First forward to the temple, after dinner Your hazard shall be made.
incorrect_answers: Let's go to the temple first. After dinner, we'll get on with your challenge.

question: Lau. Do I look like a cudgell or a houell-post, a
correct_answers: Nay that's true, I was the chiefe of the hundreth too.
incorrect_answers: That's true, I was the leader of the group as well.

question: staffe or a prop: doe you know me Father.
correct_answers: Alacke the day, I know you not yong Gentleman, but I praie you tell me, is my boy God rest his soule aliue or dead.
incorrect_answers: Oh dear, I don't know you, young man, but please tell me, is my boy, God rest his soul, alive or dead?

question: Doe you not know me Father.
correct_answers: Alacke sir I am sand blinde, I know you not.
incorrect_answers: Oh sir, I'm almost blind; I don't recognize you.

question: To be briefe, the verie truth is, that the Iew
correct_answers: hauing done me wrong, doth cause me as my Father being I hope an old man shall frutifie vnto you.

question: Heere comes Lorenzo, more of this hereafter.
correct_answers: Sweete friends, your patience for my long abode, Not I, but my affaires haue made you wait: When you shall please to play the theeues for wiues Ile watch as long for you then: approach Here dwels my father Iew. Hoa, who's within?
incorrect_answers: Dear friends, thank you for your patience during my long absence. It wasn't me, but my responsibilities that kept you waiting. When you're ready to steal wives, I'll wait just as long for you. Let's go now. My father's house is here. Hello, is anyone inside?

question: Lorenzo certaine, and my loue indeed,
correct_answers: For who loue I so much? and now who knowes But you Lorenzo, whether I am yours?
incorrect_answers: Who do I love more than you? And who knows if I belong to anyone but you, Lorenzo?

question: Heaven and thy thoughts are witness that thou art.
correct_answers: Heere, catch this casket, it is worth the paines, I am glad 'tis night, you do not looke on me, For I am much asham'd of my exchange: But loue is blinde, and louers cannot see The pretty follies that themselues commit, For if they could, Cupid himselfe would blush To see me thus transformed to a boy.
incorrect_answers: Here, catch this box, it's worth the effort. I'm glad it's night so you can't see me because I'm really embarrassed about my disguise. But love is blind, and lovers can't see their own silly mistakes. If they could, even Cupid would be embarrassed to see me dressed as a boy.

question: Descend, for you must be my torch-bearer.
correct_answers: What, must I hold a Candle to my shames? They in themselues goodsooth are too too light. Why, 'tis an office of discouery Loue, And I should be obscur'd.
incorrect_answers: Do I really have to highlight my own shame? They're already pretty obvious. This is a job for someone else, not me—I should stay hidden.

question: Now by my hood, a gentle, and no Jew.
correct_answers: Beshrew me but I loue her heartily. For she is wise, if I can iudge of her, And faire she is, if that mine eyes be true, And true she is, as she hath prou'd her selfe: And therefore like her selfe, wise, faire, and true, Shall she be placed in my constant soule.
incorrect_answers: I swear, I love her deeply. She's wise, as far as I can tell, and she's beautiful, if my eyes don't deceive me. She's also genuine, just as she's shown herself to be. So she'll be in my heart, wise, beautiful, and true.

question: I am a Iewe: Hath not a Iew eyes
correct_answers: hath not a Iew hands, organs, dementions, sences, affections, passions, fed with the same foode, hurt with the same weapons, subiect to the same diseases, healed by the same meanes, warmed and cooled by the same Winter and Sommmer as a Christian is: if you pricke vs doe we not bleede?
incorrect_answers: Doesn't a Jew have hands, organs, dimensions, senses, feelings, and passions? Aren't we fed with the same food, hurt by the same weapons, subject to the same diseases, healed by the same means, warmed and cooled by the same winter and summer as a Christian? If you prick us, do we not bleed?

incorrect_answers: If a Jew wrongs a Christian, should the Christian seek revenge?

correct_answers: and it shall goe hard but I will better the instruction.
incorrect_answers: I'll make sure to improve on the lesson.

question: I often came where I did heare of ster, but cannot finde her.
correct_answers: Why there, there, there, there, a diamond gone cost me two thousand ducats in Franckford, the curse neuer fell vpon our Nation till now, I neuer felt it till now, two thousand ducats in that, and other precious, precious iewels: I would my daughter were dead at my foot, and the iewels in her eare: would she were hearst at my foote, and the duckets in her coffin: no newes of them, why so? and I know not how much is spent in the search: why thou losse vpon losse, the theefe gone with so much, and so much to finde the theefe, and no satisfaction, no reuenge, nor no ill luck stirring but what lights a my shoulders, no sighes but a my breathing, no teares but a my shedding.
incorrect_answers: There, there, there, a diamond that cost me two thousand ducats in Franckford is gone. Our people have never been cursed until now. I never felt it until now—two thousand ducats in that diamond and other precious jewels. I wish my daughter were dead at my feet and the jewels in her ears; I wish she were in her coffin at my feet with the ducats. No news of them, why is that? And I don't know how much has been spent searching. It’s one loss after another—the thief gone with so much, and so much spent trying to find the thief, with no satisfaction, no revenge, and all the bad luck falling on my shoulders. No sighs except mine, no tears except those I shed.

question: What, what, what, ill lucke, ill lucke.
correct_answers: Hath an Argosie cast away comming from Tripolis.
incorrect_answers: A large merchant ship coming from Tripoli has been wrecked.

question: Vpon the racke Bassanio, then confesse
correct_answers: What treason there is mingled with your loue.
incorrect_answers: What kind of betrayal is mixed in with your love?

question: None but that vglie treason of mistrust.
correct_answers: Which makes me feare the enioying of my loue: There may as well be amitie and life, 'Tweeen snow and fire, as treason and my loue.
incorrect_answers: It makes me afraid to embrace my love: it’s as unlikely for betrayal and my love to coexist as it is for snow and fire to be friends.

question: I, but I feare you speake vpon the racke,
correct_answers: Where men enforced doth speake any thing.
incorrect_answers: Where people are forced, they say anything.

question: Promise me life, and ile confesse the truth.
correct_answers: Well then, confesse and liue.
incorrect_answers: Alright then, confess and live.

question: If you doe love me, you will finde me out.
correct_answers: Nerryssa and the rest, stand all aloofe.
incorrect_answers: Nerissa and the others, stand back.

question: Let musicke sound while he doth make his choise,
correct_answers: Then if he loose he makes a Swan-like end, Fading in musique.
incorrect_answers: If he loses, he goes out like a swan, disappearing with music.

question: Then if he loose he makes a Swan-like end, Fading in musique.
correct_answers: That the comparison May stand more proper, my eye shall be the streame And watrie death-bed for him: he may win, And what is musique than? Than musique is Euen as the flourish, when true subiects bowe To a new crowned Monarch: Such it is, As are those dulcet sounds in breake of day, That creepe into the dreaming bride-groomes eare, And summon him to marriage. Now he goes With no lesse presence, but with much more loue Then yong Alcides, when he did redeeme The virgine tribute, paied by howling Troy To the Sea-monster: I stand for sacrifice, The rest aloofe are the Dardanian wiues: With bleared visages come forth to view The issue of th' exploit: Goe Hercules, Liue thou, I liue with much more dismay I view the sight, then thou that mak'st the fray.
incorrect_answers: To make the comparison clearer, my eyes will be the stream and watery grave for him: he may win, and what is music then? Music will be like the fanfare when loyal subjects bow to a newly crowned king. It will be as sweet as the sounds at dawn that whisper into a dreaming bridegroom's ear and call him to his wedding. He goes out with no less importance, but with much more love than young Hercules when he rescued the virgin tribute given by Troy to the sea-monster. I am the sacrifice, while the other Trojan women stand back with tear-streaked faces, watching to see what happens. Go, Hercules, live on; I am far more distressed watching this scene than you are fighting in it.

question: You see my Lord Bassiano where I stand,
correct_answers: A gentle scroule: Faire Lady, by your leaue, I come by note to giue, and to receiue, Like one of two contending in a prize That thinks he hath done well in peoples eies: Hearing applause and vniuersall shout, Giddie in spirit, still gazing in a doubt Whether those peales of praise be his or no. So thrice faire Lady stand I euen so, As doubtfull whether what I see be true, Vntill confirm'd, sign'd, ratified by you.
incorrect_answers: A polite message: Fair lady, with your permission, I come to give and receive, like someone competing for a prize who believes they’ve done well in the eyes of the people. Hearing applause and universal cheers, feeling dizzy and unsure whether the praise is truly for them. So, thrice fair lady, I stand here just as uncertain whether what I see is real, until confirmed, signed, and ratified by you.

question: Iaylor, looke to him, tell not me of mercy,
correct_answers: This is the foole that lends out money gratis.
incorrect_answers: This is the idiot who lends out money for free.

question: Heare me yet good Shylok.
correct_answers: Ile haue my bond, speake not against my bond,
incorrect_answers: I want my contract fulfilled, don't argue against it.

question: Thou call'dst me dog before thou hadst a cause,
correct_answers: But since I am a dog, beware my phangs,
incorrect_answers: But since I am like a dog, watch out for my bite.

question: I pray thee heare me speake.
correct_answers: Ile haue my bond, I will not heare thee speake,
incorrect_answers: I'll have my contract. I'm not listening to you.

question: Ile haue my bond, and therefore speake no more.
correct_answers: Ile not be made a soft and dull ey'd foole, To shake the head, relent, and sigh, and yeeld To Christian intercessors: follow not, Ile haue no speaking, I will haue my bond.
incorrect_answers: I won't be made a fool, giving in and softening up for people to plead with me. Don't follow me; I'm done talking. I want what's owed to me.

question: It is the most impenetrable curre That euer kept with men.
correct_answers: Let him alone, Ile follow him no more with bootlesse prayers: He seekes my life, his reason well I know; I oft deliuer'd from his forfeitures Many that haue at times made mone to me, Therefore he hates me.
incorrect_answers: Leave him be; I won't waste any more prayers on him. He's after my life, and I understand why. I've often saved people from his penalties, and many have expressed their gratitude to me, so he hates me for it.

question: I am sure the Duke will neuer grant this forfeiture to hold.
correct_answers: The Duke cannot deny the course of law: For the commoditie that strangers haue With vs in Venice, if it be denied, Will much impeach the iustice of the State, Since that the trade and profit of the citty Consisteth of all Nations. Therefore goe, These greefes and losses haue so bated mee, That I shall hardly spare a pound of flesh To morrow, to my bloudy Creditor. Well Iaylor, on, pray God Bassanio come To see me pay his debt, and then I care not.
incorrect_answers: The Duke can't go against the law: If we deny the rights that foreigners have here in Venice, it would seriously harm the justice of the State since trade and profit in the city depend on all nations. So, go on. I'm so affected by these troubles and losses that I will barely be able to spare a pound of flesh for my bloodthirsty creditor tomorrow. Well, jailer, let's proceed. I just hope Bassanio comes to see me pay his debt, and then I won't care anymore.

incorrect_answers: And when she put it on, she made me promise

question: The moone shines bright. In such a night as this,
correct_answers: When the sweet winde did gently kisse the trees, And they did make no nnyse, in such a night Troylus me thinkes mounted the Troian walls, And sigh'd his soule toward the Grecian tents Where Cressed lay that night.
incorrect_answers: On a night like this, when the soft wind gently kissed the trees and they made no noise, I think Troilus climbed the Trojan walls and sighed his soul towards the Greek tents where Cressida lay.

question: In such a night
correct_answers: Did Thisbie fearefully ore-trip the dewe, And saw the Lyons shadow ere himselfe, And ranne dismayed away.
incorrect_answers: Did Thisbie nervously tiptoe through the dew, seeing the lion's shadow before the lion itself, and then ran away in a panic.

question: It is your musicke Madame of the house.
correct_answers: Nothing is good I see without respect, Methinkes it sounds much sweeter then by day?
incorrect_answers: I don't think anything is truly good without respect. Isn't it much sweeter at night than during the day?

question: Silence bestowes that vertue on it Madam.
correct_answers: The Crow doth sing as sweetly as the Larke When neither is attended: and I thinke The Nightingale if she should sing by day When every Goose is cackling, would be thought No better a Musitian then the Wren?
incorrect_answers: A crow's song sounds just as sweet as a lark's when no one's listening, and I believe even the nightingale, if it sang during the day when all the geese are cackling, wouldn't be considered any better a musician than a wren.

question: how the Moone sleepes with Endimion, And would not be awak'd.
correct_answers: That is the voice, Or I am much deceiu'd of Portia.
incorrect_answers: That's Portia's voice, or I'm very mistaken.

question: What talke you of the Poesie or the valew:
correct_answers: You swore to me when I did giue it you, That you would weare it til the houre of death, And that it should lye with you in your graue, Though not for me, yet for your vehement oaths, You should haue beene respectiue and haue kept it.
incorrect_answers: You promised me when I gave it to you that you'd wear it until you died and that it would be buried with you. Even if not for my sake, you should have honored your strong promises and kept it.

question: I, if a Woman liue to be a man.
correct_answers: Now by this hand I gaue it to a youth, A kinde of boy, a little scrubbed boy, No higher then thy selfe, the Iudges Clearke, A prating boy that begg'd it as a Fee, I could not for my heart deny it him.
incorrect_answers: I swear, I gave it to a young boy, just a small kid, about your height, the judge's clerk. He begged for it as payment, and I just couldn't say no.

question: Not that I hope which you receiu'd of me.
correct_answers: If I could adde a lie vnto a fault, I would deny it: but you see my finger Hath not the Ring vpon it, it is gone.
incorrect_answers: If I could lie about a mistake, I would deny it, but you can see my finger doesn't have the ring on it; it's gone.

question: No Woman had it, but a ciuill Doctor,

incorrect_answers: Who turned down three thousand ducats from me,

question: And beg'd the Ring; the which I did denie him,

incorrect_answers: My sense of honor wouldn't allow me to be ungrateful.

incorrect_answers: By these blessed stars in the night,

question: Orsino: I haue heard my father name him.
correct_answers: He was a Batchellor then.
incorrect_answers: He was single back then.

question: O that I seru'd that Lady,
correct_answers: And might not be deliuered to the world
incorrect_answers: And couldn’t be told to everyone

question: Then hadst thou had an excellent head of haire.

incorrect_answers: Would that have fixed my hair?

question: And I can cut the Mutton too't.
correct_answers: And. And I thinke I haue the backe-tricke, simply as strong as any man in Illyria.
incorrect_answers: And I think I can backflip just as well as any man in Illyria.

question: And I thinke I haue the backe-tricke, simply as strong as any man in Illyria.
correct_answers: To. Wherefore are these things hid? Wherefore have these gifts a Curtaine before 'em? Are they like to take dust, like mistris Mals picture? Why dost thou not goe to Church in a Galliard, and come home in a Carranto? My verie walke should be a Iigge: I would not so much as make water but in a Sinke-a-pace: What dooest thou meane? Is it a world to hide vertues in? I did thinke by the excellent constitution of thy legge, it was form'd vnder the starre of a Galliard.
incorrect_answers: Why are these things hidden? Why are these gifts covered up? Are they just going to gather dust, like Mistress Mal's picture? Why don't you go to church in a lively dance and come home in a more formal dance? Even my walk should be a jig. I wouldn't even use the bathroom without some flair. What do you mean by this? Is this a world where we hide virtues? I thought your excellent leg was made for dancing.

question: Val. If the Duke continue these fauours towards you Cesario, you are like to be much aduanc'd, he hath known you but three dayes, and already you are no stranger.
correct_answers: Vio. You either feare his humour, or my negligence, that you call in question the continuance of his loue. Is he inconstant sir, in his fauours.
incorrect_answers: You either doubt his mood or my reliability, questioning whether his love will last. Is he unreliable in his affections, sir?

question: On your attendance my Lord heere.
correct_answers: Stand you a-while aloofe. Cesario, Thou knowst no lesse, but all: I haue vnclasp'd To thee the booke euen of my secret soule.
