Therefore good youth, addresse thy gate vnto her, Be not deni'de accesse, stand at her doores, And tell them, there thy fixed foot shall grow Till thou haue audience.
incorrect_answers: Stand back a bit. Cesario, you know everything about me — I've shared all my secrets with you. So, my good friend, go to her and don't take no for an answer. Wait at her door and tell them you won't leave until she agrees to see you.

question: Stand you a-while aloofe. Cesario, Thou knowst no lesse, but all: I haue vnclasp'd To thee the booke euen of my secret soule. Therefore good youth, addresse thy gate vnto her, Be not deni'de accesse, stand at her doores, And tell them, there thy fixed foot shall grow Till thou haue audience.
correct_answers: Sure my Noble Lord, If she be so abandon'd to her sorrow As it is spoke, she neuer will admit me.
incorrect_answers: I'm sure, my Lord, if she's really consumed by her sorrow as they say, she won't see me.

question: Sure my Noble Lord, If she be so abandon'd to her sorrow As it is spoke, she neuer will admit me.
correct_answers: Be clamorous, and leape all ciuill bounds, Rather then make vnprofited returne,
incorrect_answers: Be loud and break all social rules, rather than come back empty-handed.

question: Be clamorous, and leape all ciuill bounds, Rather then make vnprofited returne,
correct_answers: Say I do speake with her (my Lord) what then?
incorrect_answers: If I do talk to her, my Lord, what then?

question: O then, vnfold the passion of my loue, Surprize her with discourse of my deere faith; It shall become thee well to act my woes: She will attend it better in thy youth, Then in a Nuntio's of more graue aspect.
correct_answers: I thinke not so, my Lord.
incorrect_answers: I don't think so, my Lord.

question: I thinke not so, my Lord.
correct_answers: Deere Lad, beleeue it; For they shall yet belye thy happy yeeres, That say thou art a man: Dianas lip Is not more smooth, and rubious: thy small pipe Is as the maidens organ, shrill, and sound, And all is semblatiue a womans part. I know thy constellation is right apt
incorrect_answers: Dear boy, believe it; anyone who says you're a man is wrong. Your lips are smoother and redder than Diana's, your voice is like a girl's, high and clear, and you resemble a woman in every way. I know your stars align perfectly for it.

question: Make your proofe.
correct_answers: I must catechize you for it Madona, Good my Mouse of vertue answer mee.
incorrect_answers: I need to question you about it, Madona. Please, my virtuous friend, give me an answer.

question: I think his soule is in hell, Madona.
correct_answers: I know his soule is in heauen, foole.
incorrect_answers: I know his soul is in heaven, you fool.

question: The more foole (Madona) to mourne for your Brothers soule, being in heauen.
correct_answers: What thinke you of this foole Maluolio, doth he not mend?
incorrect_answers: What do you think of this fool Malvolio? Isn't he improving?

question: Clo. Now Mercury indue thee with leasing, for thou speak'st well of fooles.
correct_answers: Enter Maria. Mar. Madam, there is at the gate, a young Gentleman, much desires to speake with you. Ol. From the Count Orsino, is it? Ma I know not (Madam) 'tis a faire young man, and well attended.
incorrect_answers: Maria enters. Maria: Madam, there's a young gentleman at the gate who really wants to speak with you. Olivia: Is he from Count Orsino? Maria: I don't know, Madam. He's a handsome young man and has a good entourage.

question: Ma I know not (Madam) 'tis a faire young man, and well attended.
correct_answers: Ol. Who of my people hold him in delay: Ma. Sir Toby Madam, your kinsman.
incorrect_answers: Olivia: Who's keeping him waiting? Maria: It's Sir Toby, Madam, your relative.

question: Ol. Who of my people hold him in delay:
correct_answers: Ma. Sir Toby Madam, your kinsman.
incorrect_answers: Sir Toby’s here, ma'am, your relative.

question: Ma. Sir Toby Madam, your kinsman.
correct_answers: Ol. Fetch him off I pray you, he speakes nothing but
incorrect_answers: Olivia: Please get him away, he just keeps talking nonsense.

question: Madam, yond young fellow sweares hee will speak with you.
correct_answers: I told him you were sicke, he takes on him to vnderstand so much, and therefore comes to speak with you. I told him you were asleepe, he seems to haue a fore knowledge of that too, and therefore comes to speake with you. What is to be said to him Ladie, hee's fortified against any deniall.
incorrect_answers: I told him you were sick, but he insists he knows and still wants to talk to you. I said you were asleep, but he seems to know that too and still wants to talk. What should I tell him, my lady? He's determined not to take no for an answer.

question: Tell him, he shall not speake with me.
correct_answers: Ha's beene told so: and hee sayes hee'l stand at your doore like a Sheriffes post, and be the supporter to a bench, but hee'l speake with you.
incorrect_answers: He's heard that, and he says he'll stand by your door like a guard and be as solid as a rock, but he will talk to you.

question: Gentlewoman, my Lady calles.
correct_answers: Give me my vaile: come throw it ore my face, Wee'l once more heare Orsinos Embassie.
incorrect_answers: Give me my veil and throw it over my face. Let's hear Orsino's message one more time.

question: Most radiant, exquisite, and vnmatchable beautie.
correct_answers: I pray you tell me if this bee the Lady of the house, for I neuer saw her. I would bee loath to cast away my speech: for besides that it is excellently well pend, I haue taken great paines to con it. Good Beauties, let mee sustaine no scorne; I am very comptible, euen to the least sinister vsage.
incorrect_answers: Could you please tell me if this is the lady of the house? I've never seen her before, and I don't want my words to go to waste. I've put a lot of effort into preparing them, and they're written very well. Please, don't mock me; I'm sensitive to even the slightest bit of rudeness.

question: But this is from my Commission:
correct_answers: I will on with my speech in your praise, and then shew you the heart of my message.
incorrect_answers: I'll continue telling you how great you are, and then I'll get to the main point.

question: Come to what is important in't:
correct_answers: I forgiue you the praise.
incorrect_answers: You can keep the compliment.

question: It is the more like to be feigned, I pray you keep it in.
correct_answers: I heard you were sawcy at my gates, & allowd your approach rather to wonder at you, then to heare you. If you be not mad, be gone: if you haue reason, be breefe: 'tis not that time of Moone with me, to make one in so skipping a dialogue.
incorrect_answers: I heard you were rude at my gates, and I let you in more out of curiosity than to listen to you. If you're not crazy, leave; if you're sensible, be quick. It's not the right time for me to engage in such a frivolous conversation.

question: Will you hoyst sayle sir, here lies your way.
correct_answers: No good swabber, I am to hull here a little longer.
incorrect_answers: No, good cleaner, I have to stay here a bit longer.

question: Some mollification for your Giant, sweete Ladie; tell me your minde, I am a messenger.
correct_answers: Sure you haue some hiddeous matter to deliuer, when the curtesie of it is so fearefull. Speake your office.
incorrect_answers: You must have something terrible to say because your politeness is so unsettling. Just say what you need to say.

question: It alone concernes your eare:
correct_answers: I bring no ouverture of warre, no taxation of homage; I hold the Olyffe in my hand: my words are as full of peace, as matter.
incorrect_answers: I come bearing no signs of war, no demands of loyalty; I hold an olive branch in my hand: my words are filled with peace and substance.

question: The rudeness that hath appear'd in mee, haue I learned from my entertainment. What I am, and what I would, are as secret as maiden-head:
correct_answers: to your eares, Diuinity; to any others, prophanation.
incorrect_answers: To you, it's sacred; to anyone else, it's sacrilegious.

question: Giue vs the place alone,
correct_answers: We will heare this diuinitie. Now sir, what is your text?
incorrect_answers: We'll listen to this sermon. So, sir, what are you going to talk about?

question: But if you were the diuell, you are faire:
correct_answers: My Lord, and master loues you: O such loue
incorrect_answers: My lord and master loves you deeply. Oh, such love!

question: What hoa, Maluolio.
correct_answers: Heere Madam, at your seruice.
incorrect_answers: Here, ma'am, at your service.

question: Will you stay no longer: nor will you not that I go with you.
correct_answers: By your patience, no: my starres shine darkely ouer me; the malignancie of my fate, might perhaps distemper yours; therefore I shall craue of you your leaue, that I may beare my euils alone. It were a bad recompence for your loue, to lay any of them on you.
incorrect_answers: No, please understand, my fate is unfortunate and it may negatively affect you too. So I ask that you allow me to deal with my troubles alone. It wouldn't be fair to burden you with them.

question: Let me yet know of you, whither you are bound.
correct_answers: No sooth sir: my determinate voyage is meere extrauagancie. But I perceiue in you so excellent a touch of modestie, that you will not extort from me, what I am willing to keepe in: therefore it charges me in manners, the rather to expresse my selfe: you must know of mee then Antonio, my name is Sebastian (which I call'd Rodorigo) my father was that Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you haue heard of. He left behinde him, myselfe, and a sister, both borne in an houre: if the Heanens had beene pleas'd, would we had so ended. But you sir, alter'd that, for some houre before you tooke me from the breach of the sea, was my sister drown'd.
incorrect_answers: No, sir, my journey is just aimless wandering. But I see in you such excellent modesty that you won't force me to say what I'm willing to keep to myself. So, out of politeness, I feel compelled to express myself. You must know, Antonio, my name is Sebastian (though I have been called Rodorigo). My father was Sebastian of Messaline, whom I know you've heard of. He left behind myself and a twin sister. If the heavens had been kind, we would have died together. But you changed that fate because just hours before you saved me from the sea, my sister drowned.

question: She returnes this Ring to you (sir) you might haue saued mee my paines, to haue taken it away your selfe.
correct_answers: She adds moreouer, that you should put your Lord into a desperate assurance, she will none of him.
incorrect_answers: She also says you should make it clear to your master that she won't have anything to do with him.

question: She tooke the Ring of me, Ile none of it.
correct_answers: Come sir, you peeuishly threw it to her: and her will is, it should be so return'd: If it bee worth stooping for, there it lies, in your eye: if not, bee it his that findes it.
incorrect_answers: Alright sir, you threw it to her in a bad mood, and she wants it returned the same way. If it's worth picking up, there it is for you to see; if not, let whoever finds it keep it.

question: Nay by my troth I know not: but I know, to be vp late, is to be vp late.
correct_answers: A false conclusion: I hate it as an vnfill'd Canne.
incorrect_answers: That's a wrong assumption. I hate it like an empty can.

question: A false conclusion: I hate it as an vnfill'd Canne.
correct_answers: To be vp after midnight, and to go to bed then is early: so that to go to bed after midnight, is to goe to bed betimes.
incorrect_answers: Staying up past midnight and then going to bed is still considered early; so going to bed after midnight is actually going to bed on time.

question: Byrlady sir, and some dogs will catch well.
correct_answers: Most certaine: Let our Catch be, Thou
incorrect_answers: Absolutely: Let's sing this song, "You"

question: Hold thy peace, thou Knaue knight. I shall be constrained in't, to call thee knaue, Knight.
correct_answers: 'Tis not the first time I haue constrained one to call me knaue. Begin foole: it begins, Hold thy peace.
incorrect_answers: It's not the first time I've forced someone to call me a scoundrel. Go ahead, fool: it starts with, Hold your tongue.

question: What a catterwalling doe you keepe heere? If my Lady haue not call'd vp her Steward Maluolio, and bid him turne you out of doores, neuer trust me.
correct_answers: My Lady's a Catayan, we are politicians, Maluolios a Peg-a-ramsie, and Three merry men be wee.
incorrect_answers: My Lady's from China, we're schemers, Malvolio's a fool, and we're three merry men.

question: Am not I consanguinious? Am I not of her blood: tilly vally. Ladie, There dwelt a man in Babylon, Lady, Lady.
correct_answers: Beshrew me, the knights in admirable fooling.
incorrect_answers: I swear, the knights are hilarious.

question: I, he do's well enough if he be dispos'd, and so do I too: he does it with a better grace, but I do it more naturall.
correct_answers: O the twelfe day of December.
incorrect_answers: On the twelfth day of December.

question: We did keepe time sir in our Catches. Snecke vp.
correct_answers: Sir Toby, I must be round with you. My Lady bad me tell you, that though she harbors you as her kinsman, she's nothing ally'd to your disorders. If you can separate your selfe and your misdemeanors, you are welcome to the house: if not, and it would please you to take leaue of her, she is very willing to bid you farewell.
incorrect_answers: Sir Toby, I have to be frank with you. My Lady asked me to tell you that while she shelters you as her relative, she doesn’t approve of your behavior. If you can control yourself and your actions, you're welcome to stay. If not, and you wish to leave, she’s more than willing to say goodbye.

question: Good night Penthisilea.
correct_answers: Before me she's a good wench.
incorrect_answers: She's a good woman in my opinion.

question: Before me she's a good wench.
correct_answers: She's a beagle true bred, and one that adores me: what o'that?
incorrect_answers: She's a purebred beagle who loves me. So what?

question: I was ador'd once too.
correct_answers: Let's to bed knight: Thou hadst neede send for more money.
incorrect_answers: Let’s go to bed, knight. You should send for more money.

question: Let's to bed knight: Thou hadst neede send for more money.
correct_answers: If I cannot recouer your Neece, I am a foule way out.
incorrect_answers: If I can't win your niece over, I'm in big trouble.

question: If I cannot recouer your Neece, I am a foule way out.
correct_answers: Send for money knight, if thou hast her not i'th end, call me Cut.
incorrect_answers: Ask for money, knight, and if you don't have her in the end, you can call me a failure.

question: Send for money knight, if thou hast her not i'th end, call me Cut.
correct_answers: If I do not, neuer trust me, take it how you will.
incorrect_answers: If I don't, don't believe me, think of it however you want.

question: If I do not, neuer trust me, take it how you will.
correct_answers: Come, come, Ile go burne some Sacke, tis too late to go to bed now: Come knight, come knight.
incorrect_answers: Alright, alright, I'll get some wine; it's too late to go to sleep now. Come on, knight, let's go.

question: There's for thy paines.
correct_answers: No paines sir, I take pleasure in singing sir.
incorrect_answers: No trouble, sir. I enjoy singing.

question: No paines sir, I take pleasure in singing sir.
correct_answers: Ile pay thy pleasure then.
incorrect_answers: I'll pay you back later.

question: Ile pay thy pleasure then.
correct_answers: Truely sir, and pleasure will be paide one time, or another.
incorrect_answers: Honestly, sir, and you'll have to pay for pleasure sooner or later.

question: Giue me now leaue, to leaue thee.
correct_answers: Now the melancholly God protect thee, and the Tailor make thy doublet of changeable Taffata, for thymind is a very Opall. I would haue men of such constancie put to Sea, that their businesse might be euery thing, and their intent euerie where, for that's it, thatalwayes makes a good voyage of nothing. Farewell.
incorrect_answers: May the sad god keep you safe, and the tailor make your jacket from changing fabric, because your mind is so unpredictable. I think people like you should be sent to sea, where their work could be anything and their purpose everywhere, because that's what always turns a trip into something out of nothing. Goodbye.

question: Let all the rest giue place:
correct_answers: Once more Cesario,Get thee to yond same soueraigne crueltie:Tell her my loue, more noble then the worldPrizes not quantitie of dirtie lands,The parts that fortune hath bestow'd vpon her:Tell her I hold as giddily as Fortune:But 'tis that miracle, and Queene of IemsThat nature prankes her in, attracts my soule.
incorrect_answers: Cesario, go back to that cruel lady and tell her that my love is more noble than anything in the world. I don't care about her wealth or the land she owns. Tell her I value those things as lightly as Fortune does. It's her natural beauty and grace that captivate my soul.

question: But if she cannot loue you sir.
correct_answers: It cannot be so answer'd.
incorrect_answers: That can't be the answer.

question: There is no womans sides
correct_answers: Can bide the beating of so strong a passion,
incorrect_answers: Can handle the intensity of such strong emotions,

question: There is no womans sides
correct_answers: As loue doth giue my heart: no womans heart
incorrect_answers: As love fills my heart, no woman's heart

question: As loue doth giue my heart: no womans heart
correct_answers: So bigge, to hold so much, they lacke retention.
incorrect_answers: They're so big, but they can't hold that much.

question: Besides you waste the treasure of your time, with a foolish knight.
correct_answers: That's mee I warrant you.
incorrect_answers: That's me, I promise you.

question: One sir Andrew.
correct_answers: I knew 'twas I, for many do call mee foole.
incorrect_answers: I knew it was me, because a lot of people call me a fool.

question: Oh peace, and the spirit of humors intimate reading aloud to him.
correct_answers: By my life this is my Ladies hand: these bee her very C's, her V's, and her T's, and thus makes shee her great P's. It is in contempt of question her hand.
incorrect_answers: I swear, this is my lady's handwriting: these are her exact C's, V's, and T's, and that's how she writes her capital P's. There's no doubt it's her writing.

question: no man must know.
correct_answers: No man must know. What followes? The numbers alter'd: No man must know, If this should be thee Maluolio?
incorrect_answers: No one can know. What's next? The numbers have changed: No one can know. Could this be you, Malvolio?

question: I may command where I adore,
correct_answers: but silence like a Lucresse knife: With bloodlesse stroke my heart doth gore, M.O.A.I. doth sway my life.
incorrect_answers: But silence, like a knife, wounds my heart without drawing blood. M.O.A.I. controls my life.

question: I, or Ile cudgell him, and make him cry O.
correct_answers: And then I. comes behind.
incorrect_answers: And then I come up from behind.

question: Vio. So thou maist say the Kings lyes by a begger, if a begger dwell neer him: or the Church stands by thy Tabor, if thy Tabor stand by the Church.
correct_answers: Clo. I am the Kings poore Cousin sir.
incorrect_answers: I'm the King's poor cousin, sir.

question: You haue said sir: To see this age: A sentence is but a cheu'rill gloue to a good witte, how quickely the wrong side may be turn'd outward. Vio.
correct_answers: Nay that's certaine: they that dally nicely with words, may quickely make them wanton.
incorrect_answers: No doubt about it: those who play around too carefully with words can easily twist them.

question: I warrant thou art a merry fellow, and car'st for nothing.
correct_answers: Not so sir, I do care for something: but in my concience sir, I do not care for you: if that be to care for nothing sir, I would it would make you inuisible.
incorrect_answers: That's not true, sir. I do care about some things; but honestly, sir, I don't care about you. If that means I care about nothing, sir, I hope it makes you disappear.

question: I saw thee late at the Count Orsino's.
correct_answers: Foolery sir, does walke about the Orbe like the Sun, it shines euery where. I would be sorry sir, but the Foole
incorrect_answers: Foolishness, sir, is everywhere like the sun; it shines on everything. I'd be sorry, sir, but the fool...

question: I thinke I saw your wisedome there.
correct_answers: Nay, and thou passe vpon me, Ile no more with thee. Hold there's expences for thee.
incorrect_answers: No, if you're going to take advantage of me, I'm done with you. Here, take this money and go.

question: Nay, and thou passe vpon me, Ile no more with thee. Hold there's expences for thee.
correct_answers: Now Ioue in his next commodity of hayre, send thee a beard.
incorrect_answers: May the next time you grow hair, Jupiter sends you a beard.

question: Yes being kept together, and put to vse.
correct_answers: I would play Lord Pandarus of Phrygia sir, to bring a Cressida to this Troylus.
incorrect_answers: I'd be like a matchmaker, bringing Cressida to Troilus.

question: I understand you sir, tis well begg'd.
correct_answers: The matter I hope is not great sir; begging, but a begger: Cressida was a begger. My Lady is within sir.
incorrect_answers: I hope it's nothing serious, sir; just a beggar asking for help: Cressida was a beggar. My lady is inside, sir.

question: My seruant sir? 'Twas neuer merry world, Since lowly feigning was call'd complement: y'are seruant to the Count Orsino youth.
correct_answers: And he is yours, and his must needs be yours: your seruants seruant, is your seruant Madam.
incorrect_answers: He's yours, and everything of his is yours too: your servant's servant is at your service, ma'am.

question: For him, I thinke not on him: for his thoughts, Would they were blankes, rather then fill'd with me.
correct_answers: Madam, I come to whet your gentle thoughts On his behalfe.
incorrect_answers: Ma'am, I'm here to put in a good word for him.

question: If I thinke so, I thinke the same of you.
correct_answers: Then think you right: I am not what I am.
incorrect_answers: You're correct: I’m not who I seem to be.

question: I would you were, as I would have you be.
correct_answers: Would it be better Madam, then I am?
incorrect_answers: Would it then be better, ma'am, than I am?

question: Thy reason deere venom, giue thy reason.
correct_answers: You must needes yeelde your reason, Sir Andrew?
incorrect_answers: Sir Andrew, you really have to explain why, don't you?

question: Marry I saw your Neece do more fauours to the Counts Seruing-man, then euer she bestow'd vpon me: I saw't i'th Orchard.
correct_answers: Did she see the while, old boy, tell me that.
incorrect_answers: Did she see it, buddy, tell me that.

question: Did she see the while, old boy, tell me that.
correct_answers: As plaine as I see you now.
incorrect_answers: As clear as I see you now.

question: S'light; will you make an Asse o'me.
correct_answers: I will proue it legitimate sir, vpon the Oathes of judgement, and reason.
incorrect_answers: I will prove it legally, sir, based on judgment and reason.

question: And they haue beene grand Iurie men, since before Noah was a Saylor.
correct_answers: Shee did shew fauour to the youth in your sight, onely to exasperate you, to awake your dormouse valour, to put fire in your Heart, and brimstone in your Liuer: you should then haue accosted her, and with some excellent iests, fire-new from the mint, you should haue bangd the youth into dumbenesse: this was look'd for at your hand, and this was baulkt: the double gilt of this opportunitie you let time wash off, and you are now sayld into the North of my Ladies opinion, where you will hang like an ysickle on a Dutchmans beard, vnlesse you do redeeme it, by some laudable attempt, either of valour or policie.
incorrect_answers: She showed favor to the young man in front of you just to provoke you, to wake up your dormant courage, to ignite passion in your heart and anger in your liver. You should have approached her and, with some clever jokes, completely silenced the young man. This was expected of you, but you missed the chance. You let this golden opportunity slip away, and now you're in my lady's bad graces, like an icicle on a Dutchman's beard, unless you do something commendable, whether through bravery or cunning, to make up for it.

question: And't be any way, it must be with Valour, for policie I hate: I had as liefe be a Brownist, as a Politician.
correct_answers: Why then build me thy fortunes vpon the basis of valour. Challenge me the Counts youth to fight with him / hurt him in eleuen places, my Neece shall take note of it, and assure thy selfe, there is no loue-Broker in the world, can more preuaile in mans commendation with woman, then report of valour.
incorrect_answers: So, build your future on bravery. Challenge the Count's young man to a fight, hurt him in eleven places; my niece will notice, and trust me, nothing impresses a woman more than a reputation for courage.

question: This is a deere Manakin to you Sir Toby.
correct_answers: I haue beene deere to him lad, some two thousand strong, or so.
incorrect_answers: I've meant a lot to him, kid, with around two thousand men or so.

question: We shall haue a rare Letter from him; but you'le not deliuer't.
correct_answers: Neuer trust me then: and by all meanes stirre on the youth to an answer. I thinke Oxen and waine-ropes cannot hale them together. For Andrew, if he were open'd and you finde so much blood in his Liuer, as will clog the foote of a flea, Ile eate the rest of th'anatomy.
incorrect_answers: Never trust me again: and by all means, push the young man for a response. I don't think anything could bring them together. As for Andrew, if you were to examine him and find as much blood in his liver as would clog a flea's foot, I'd eat the rest of his body.

question: And his opposit the youth beares in his visage no great presage of cruelty.
correct_answers: Looke where the youngest Wren of mine comes.
incorrect_answers: Look, here comes my youngest child.

question: Enter Sebastian and Anthonio.
correct_answers: Seb. I would not by my will haue troubled you, But since you make your pleasure of your paines, I will no further chide you. Ant. I could not stay behinde you: my desire (More sharpe then filed steele) did spurre me forth, And not all loue to see you (though so much As might haue drawne one to a longer voyage) But iealousie, what might befall your rrauell, Being skillesse in these parts: which to a stranger, Vnguided, and vnfriended, often proue Rough, and vnhospitable. My willing loue, The rather by these arguments of feare Set forth in your pursuite.
incorrect_answers: Seb. I didn't want to bother you, but since you seem to enjoy this, I won't scold you any further. Ant. I couldn't stay behind; my desire, sharper than sharpened steel, pushed me forward. It wasn't just love for you (though that could have led anyone on a longer journey), but also jealousy of what might happen to you, being inexperienced in these parts. For a stranger without guidance or friends, it can often be rough and unwelcoming. My love for you was driven even more by these fears to follow you.

question: I pray you let vs satisfie our eyes
correct_answers: With the memorials, and the things of fame
incorrect_answers: With the memories and famous things

question: Belike you slew great number of his people.
correct_answers: Th offence is not of such a bloody nature
incorrect_answers: The offense isn't that violent.

question: Hold sir, here's my purse
correct_answers: In the South Suburbes at the Elephant
incorrect_answers: In the southern suburbs at the Elephant.

question: He's comming Madame: / But in very strange manner.
correct_answers: He is sure possest Madam.
incorrect_answers: He is definitely possessed, ma'am.

question: Go call him hither.
correct_answers: I am as madde as hee, If sad and merry madnesse equall bee.
incorrect_answers: I'm just as crazy as he is, if being sad and happy mad are the same.

question: Smil'st thou? I sent for thee vpon a sad occasion.
correct_answers: Sad Lady, I could be sad: / This does make some obstruction in the blood: / This crosse-gartering, but what of that? / If it please the eye of one, it is with me as the very true / Sonnet is: Please one, and please all.
incorrect_answers: My dear lady, I could feel sorrowful. This crisscrossing does mess with the circulation a bit, but so what? If it pleases someone's eye, it's like a perfect sonnet to me: pleasing one means pleasing everyone.

question: Why appeare you with this ridiculous boldnesse before my Lady.
correct_answers: Be not afraid of greatnesse: 'twas well writ.
incorrect_answers: Don't be scared of greatness; it was well written.

question: Oh ho, do you come neere me now: no worse man then sir Toby to looke to me.
correct_answers: This concurres directly with the Letter, she sends him on purpose, that I may appeare stubborne to him: for she incites me to that in the Letter.
incorrect_answers: This matches perfectly with the letter—she sent it to make me seem stubborn to him, since she urged me to act that way in the letter.

question: Which way is hee in the name of sanctity. If all the diuels of hell be drawne in little, and Legion himselfe possest him, yet Ile speake to him.
correct_answers: Heere he is, heere he is: how ist with you sir? How ist with you man?
incorrect_answers: Here he is, here he is: how are you doing, sir? How are you, man?

question: Go off, I discard you: let me enioy my priuate: go off.
correct_answers: Lo, how hollow the fiend speakes within him; did not I tell you? Sir Toby, my Lady prayes you to haue a care of him.
incorrect_answers: Look how deceitfully the demon speaks through him; didn't I tell you? Sir Toby, my lady asks you to take care of him.

question: Carry his water to th'wise woman.
correct_answers: Marry and it shall be done to morrow morning if I liue. My Lady would not loose him for more then ile
incorrect_answers: Sure, I'll get it done tomorrow morning if I'm still alive. My lady wouldn't lose him for more than I'll possoiy offer.

question: Why we shall make him mad indeede.
correct_answers: The house will be the quieter.
incorrect_answers: The house will be quieter.

question: Come, wee'l haue him in a darke room &
correct_answers: bound. My Neece is already in the beleefe that he's mad: we may carry it thus for our pleasure, and his pennance, til our very pastime tyred out of breath, prompt vs to haue mercy on him: at which time, we wil bring the deuice to the bar and crowne thee for a finder of madmen: but see, but see.
incorrect_answers: My niece already thinks he's gone mad. We can keep this up for our fun and his punishment until we get tired of it and decide to have mercy on him. Then we'll reveal the truth and praise you for discovering a madman. But look, look.

question: More matter for a May morning.
correct_answers: Heere's the Challenge, reade it: I warrant there's vinegar and pepper in't.
incorrect_answers: Here's the challenge, read it: I bet it's full of sharp and spicy remarks.

question: Very breefe, and to exceeding good sence-
correct_answers: I will way-lay thee going home, where if it be thy chance to kill me.
incorrect_answers: I'll ambush you on your way home, and if you get the chance, kill me.

question: Thou kilst me like a rogue and a villaine.
correct_answers: Still you keepe o'th windie side of the Law: good.
incorrect_answers: You still manage to stay on the right side of the law. Good.

question: Thy friend as thou vsest him, & thy sworne enemie, Andrew Ague-cheeke. If this Letter moue him not, his legges cannot.
correct_answers: Yon may haue verie fit occasion fot't: he is now in some commerce with my Ladie, and will by and by depart.
incorrect_answers: You may have a good opportunity for it since he's currently talking with my lady and will leave soon.

question: Go sir Andrew: scout mee for him at the corner of the Orchard like a bum-Baylie: so soone as euer thou seest him, draw, and as thou draw'st, sweare horrible:
correct_answers: Nay let me alone for swearing.
incorrect_answers: No, leave the swearing to me.

question: Enter Oliuia and Viola.
correct_answers: Fab. Heere he comes with your Neece, giue them way till he take leaue, and presently after him.
incorrect_answers: Fabian: Here he comes with your niece. Let them have their moment to say goodbye, and then follow him.

question: That defence thou hast, betake the too't: of what nature the wrongs are thou hast done him, I knowe not: but thy intercepter full of despight, bloody as the Hunter, attends thee at the Orchard end: dismount thy tucke, be yare in thy preparation, for thy assaylant is quick, skilfull, and deadly.
correct_answers: You mistake sir I am sure, no man hath any quarrell to me: my remembrance is very free and cleere from any image of offence done to any man.
incorrect_answers: I think you're mistaken, sir. No one has any issue with me; I'm quite sure I haven't offended anybody.

question: You'l finde it otherwise I assure you: therefore, if you hold your life at any price, betake you to your gard: for your opposite hath in him what youth, strength, skill, and wrath, can furnish man withall.
correct_answers: I pray you sir what is he?
incorrect_answers: Excuse me, who is he?

question: He is knight dubb'd with vnhatch'd Rapier, and on carpet consideration, but he is a diuell in priuate brall, soules and bodies hath he diuorc'd three, and his incensement at this moment is so implacable, that satisfaction can be none, but by pangs of death and sepulcher: Hob, nob, is his word: giu't or take't.
correct_answers: I will returne againe into the house, and desire some conduct of the Lady. I am no fighter, I haue heard of some kinde of men, that put quarrells purposely on others, to taste their valour: belike this is a man of that quirke.
incorrect_answers: I'll go back inside and ask the lady for some guidance. I'm not a fighter; I've heard there are some people who provoke others on purpose just to test their bravery. Maybe this guy is one of those.

question: you might answer him: therefore on, or strippe your sword starke naked: for meddle you must that's certain, or forsweare to weare iron about you.
correct_answers: This is as vnciuill as strange. I beseech you doe me this courteous office, as to know of the Knight what my offence to him is: it is something of my negligence, nothing of my purpose.
incorrect_answers: This is as rude as it is unusual. Please do me the favor of asking the Knight what I did to offend him: it was an oversight, not intentional.

question: I shall bee much bound to you for't: I am one, that had rather go with sir Priest, then sir knight: I care not who knowes so much of my mettle.
correct_answers: Why man hee s a verie diuell, I haue not seen such a firago: I had a passe with him, rapier, scabberd, and all: and he giues me the stucke in with such a mortall motion that it is ineuitable: and on the answer, he payes you as surely, as your feete hits the ground they step on.
incorrect_answers: He's like a devil, man. I've never seen such a fierce guy. I had a fight with him, using swords and all, and he attacked me with such deadly precision that it was unavoidable. When you try to hit back, he counters so accurately that it's as certain as your feet touching the ground.

question: Pox on't, Ile not meddle with him.
correct_answers: I but he will not now be pacified, / Fabian can scarse hold him yonder.
incorrect_answers: But he won't calm down now; Fabian is barely able to keep him over there.

question: Plague on't, and I thought he had beene valiant, and so cunning in Fence, I'de haue seene him damn'd ere I'de haue challeng'd him. Let him let the matter slip, and Ile giue him my horse, gray Capilet.
correct_answers: Ile make the motion: stand heere, make a good shew on't, this shall end without the perdition of soules, marry Ile ride your horse as well as I ride you. I haue his horse to take vp the quarrell, I haue perswaded him the youths a diuell.
incorrect_answers: I'll handle it: stand here and put on a good show, this will end without anyone getting damned. And yes, I'll ride your horse as well as I control you. I've got his horse ready to resolve the argument, and I've convinced him that the young guy is trouble.

question: He is as horribly conceited of him: and pants, & looks pale, as if a Beare were at his heeles.
correct_answers: There's no remedie sir, he will fight with you for's oath sake: marrie hee hath better bethought him of his quarrell, and hee findes that now scarse to be worth talking of: therefore draw for the supportance of his vowe, he protests he will not hurt you.
incorrect_answers: There's no way around it, sir. He'll fight you to keep his oath, though he's now realized his quarrel isn't worth much anymore. So, draw your weapon to help him keep his promise, but he assures you he won't harm you.

question: Pray God defend me: a little thing would make me tell them how much I lacke of a man.
correct_answers: Giue ground if you see him furious.
incorrect_answers: Back off if you see him getting angry.

question: Come sir Andrew, there's no remedie, the Gentleman will for his honors sake haue one bowt with you: he cannot by the Duello avoide it: but hee has promised me, as he is a Gentleman and a Soldiour, he will not hurt you. Come on, too't.
correct_answers: Pray God he keepe his oath.
incorrect_answers: I hope he keeps his promise.

question: I do assure you tis against my will.
correct_answers: Put vp your sword: if this yong Gentleman Haue done offence, I take the fault on me: If you offend him, I for him defie you.
incorrect_answers: Put away your sword. If this young gentleman has done something wrong, blame me. If you harm him, you'll have to answer to me.

question: Put vp your sword: if this yong Gentleman Haue done offence, I take the fault on me: If you offend him, I for him defie you.
correct_answers: Nay, if you be an vndertaker, I am for you.
incorrect_answers: If you're up for it, so am I.

question: Nay, if you be an vndertaker, I am for you.
correct_answers: O good sir Toby hold: heere come the Officers.
incorrect_answers: Please, Sir Toby, stop; the officers are coming.

question: Pray sir, put your sword vp if you please.
correct_answers: Marry will I sir: and for that I promis'd you Ile be as good as my word. Hee will beare you easily, and raines well.
incorrect_answers: Yes, sir, I will: and since I promised you, I'll keep my word. He will handle you easily and reins well.

question: This is the man, do thy Office.
correct_answers: Anthonio, I arrest thee at the suit of Count Orsino
incorrect_answers: Antonio, you're under arrest by order of Count Orsino.

question: You do mistake me sir.
correct_answers: No sir, no iot: I know your fauour well: Though now you haue no sea-cap on your head: Take him away, he knowes I know him well.
incorrect_answers: No, sir, definitely not: I recognize you perfectly. Even without your sea-cap, I know who you are. Take him away; he knows I do.

question: Ant. Will you deny me now,
correct_answers: Ist possible that my deserts to you Can lacke perswasion. Do not tempt my misery, Least that it make me so vnsound a man As to vpbraid you with those kindnesses That I haue done for you.
incorrect_answers: Is it possible that my efforts for you can go unappreciated? Don't test my suffering, or it might push me to remind you of all the favors I've done for you.

question: Vio. I know of none,
correct_answers: Nor know I you by voyce, or any feature: I hate ingratitude more in a man, Then lying, vainnesse, babling drunkennesse, Or any taint of vice, whose strong corruption Inhabites our fraile blood.
incorrect_answers: I don't recognize you by voice or appearance: I despise ingratitude in a person more than lying, vanity, senseless chatter, drunkenness, or any vice that corrupts our weak nature.

question: Ant. Oh heauens themselues.
correct_answers: 2. Off. Come sir, I pray you go.
incorrect_answers: Officer: Sir, please come with us.

question: Ant. Let me speake a little. This youth that you see heere,
correct_answers: I snatch'd one halfe out of the iawes of death, Releeu'd him with such sanctitie of Ioue; And to his image, which me thought did promise Most venerable worth, did I deuotion.
incorrect_answers: I rescued one person from the brink of death, saved him with the sacred power of Jupiter; and showed my deepest respect to that image, which I believed promised the highest honor.

question: I prethee gentle friend,
correct_answers: Let thy fayre wisedome, not thy passion sway
incorrect_answers: Let your good sense guide you, not your emotions.

question: Sir Topas the Curate, who comes to visit Maluolio the Lunaticke.
correct_answers: Sir Topas, sir Topas, good sir Topas goe to my Ladie.
incorrect_answers: Sir Topas, please go to my lady.

question: Sir Topas, neuer was man thus wronged, good sir Topas do not thinke I am mad: they haue layde me heere in hideous darknesse.
correct_answers: Fye, thou dishonest sathan: I call thee by the most modest termes, for I am one of those gentle ones, that will vse the diuell himselfe with curtesie: sayst thou that house is darke?
incorrect_answers: Shame on you, you dishonest devil. I'm being polite here, because I'm the kind of person who would treat even the devil with respect. Are you really saying that house is dark?

question: As hell sir Topas.
correct_answers: Why it hath bay Windowes transparant as baricadoes, and the cleere stores toward the South north.
incorrect_answers: It has bay windows as clear as blockades, and the clear stores face both south and north.

question: I am not mad sir Topas, I say to you this house is darke.
correct_answers: Madman thou errest: I say there is no darknesse but ignorance, in which thou art more puzel'd then the Agyptians in their fogge.
incorrect_answers: You're crazy: I'm telling you that the only darkness is ignorance, and you're more confused by it than the Egyptians were by their fog.

question: Madman thou errest: I say there is no darknesse but ignorance, in which thou art more puzel'd then the Agyptians in their fogge.
correct_answers: I say this house is as darke as Ignorance, thogh Ignorance were as darke as hell; and I say there was neuer man thus abus'd, I am no more madde then you are, make the triall of it in any constant question.
incorrect_answers: I say this house is as dark as ignorance, even if ignorance were as dark as hell; and I say no one has ever been treated this badly, I'm no crazier than you are, test me on anything to see for yourself.

question: Hey Robin, iolly Robin,
correct_answers: tell me how thy Lady does.
incorrect_answers: Tell me how your lady is doing.

question: They haue heere propertied me: keepe mee in darkenesse, send Ministers to me, Asses, and doe all they can to face me out of my wits.
correct_answers: Aduise you what you say: the Minister is heere.
incorrect_answers: Be careful what you say: the official is here.

question: Maintaine no words with him good fellow.
correct_answers: Who I sir, not I sir. God buy you good sir Topas: Marry Amen.
incorrect_answers: Who, me? No, not me. Goodbye, good sir Topas. God bless you.

question: Good foole, helpe me to some light, and some paper, I tell thee I am as well in my wittes, as any man in Illyria.
correct_answers: Well-a-day, that you were sir.
incorrect_answers: It's a pity you're not, sir.

question: By this hand I am: good foole, some inke, paper, and light: and conuey what I will set downe to my Lady: it shall aduantage thee more, then euer the bearing of Letter did.
correct_answers: I will help you too't. But tel me true, are you not mad indeed, or do you but counterfeit.
incorrect_answers: I'll help you with it. But tell me honestly, are you really mad, or are you just pretending?

question: Beleeue me I am not, I tell thee true.
correct_answers: Nay, Ile nere beleeue a madman till I see his brains / I will fetch you light, and paper, and inke.
incorrect_answers: No way, I'll never believe a madman until I see his brains. I'll get you a light, some paper, and ink.

question: Why this is excellent.
correct_answers: By my troth sir, no: though it please you to be one of my friends.
incorrect_answers: Honestly sir, no: but I'd still like to be friends with you.

question: Thou shalt not be the worse for me, there's gold.
correct_answers: But that it would be double dealing sir, I would you could make it another.
incorrect_answers: But that would be dishonest, sir. I wish you could change it.

question: O you giue me ill counsell.
correct_answers: Put your grace in your pocket sir, for this once, and let your flesh and blood obey it.
incorrect_answers: Keep your dignity in check for now, and let yourself act on your emotions.

question: Primo, secundo, tertio, is a good play, and the olde saying is, the third pays for all: the triplex sir, is a good tripping measure, or the belles of S. Bennet sir, may put you in minde, one, two, three.
correct_answers: You can foole no more money out of mee at this throw: if you will let your Lady know I am here to speak with her, and bring her along with you, it may awake my
incorrect_answers: You can't swindle any more money out of me this time. If you let your lady know I'm here to speak with her and bring her along, it might spark my interest.

question: Here comes the man sir, that did rescue mee.
correct_answers: That face of his I do remember well, yet when I saw it last, it was besmear'd As blacke as Vulcan, in the smoake of warre: A bawbling Vessell was he Captaine of, For shallow draught and bulke vnprizable, With which such scathfull grapple did he make, With the most noble bottome of our Fleete, That very enuy, and the tongue of losse Cried fame and honor on him: What's the matter?
incorrect_answers: I remember his face well, but the last time I saw it, it was smeared black like Vulcan in the smoke of war. He was captain of a worthless ship, shallow and insignificant, but he managed to engage in such a fierce fight with the best ship in our fleet that even envy and defeat spoke of his fame and honor. What's happening?

question: Orsino, this is that Anthonio That tooke the Phoenix, and her fraught from Candy, And this is he that did the Tiger boord, When your yong Nephew Titus lost his legge; Heere in the streets, desperate of shame and state, In priuate brabble did we apprehend him.
correct_answers: He did me kindnesse sir, drew on my side, But in conclusion put strange speech vpon me, I know not what 'twas, but distraction.
incorrect_answers: He was kind to me, sir, and supported me, but in the end, he said something strange to me that I couldn't understand; it was just confusing.

question: What do you say Cesario? Good my Lord.
correct_answers: My Lord would speake, my dutie hushes me.
incorrect_answers: My Lord wants to speak, so I’ll stay quiet.

question: My Lord would speake, my dutie hushes me.
correct_answers: If it be ought to the old tune my Lord, It is as fat and fulsome to mine eare As howling after Musicke.
incorrect_answers: If it's the same old story, my Lord, it's as annoying to me as howling after music.

question: Still so constant Lord.
correct_answers: What to peruersenesse? you vnciuill Ladie To whose ingrate, and vnauspicious Altars My soule the faithfull'st offrings haue breath'd out That ere deuotion tender'd. What shall I do?
incorrect_answers: What do you want from me, you uncivil woman? I've given my most faithful offerings to your ungrateful and ominous altars. What should I do?

question: Why should I not, (had I the heart to do it) Like to th'Egyptian theefe, at point of death Kill what I loue: (a sauage iealousie, That sometime sauours nobly) but heare me this:
correct_answers: Since you to non-regardance cast my faith, And that I partly know the instrument That screwes me from my true place in your fauour: Liue you the Marble-brested Tirant still.
incorrect_answers: Since you disregard my loyalty and I partly know what's causing you to push me away from your favor, continue living as the cold-hearted tyrant you are.

question: Since you to non-regardance cast my faith, And that I partly know the instrument That screwes me from my true place in your fauour: Liue you the Marble-brested Tirant still.
correct_answers: But this your Minion, whom I know you loue, And whom, by heauen I sweare, I tender deerely, Him will I teare out of that cruell eye, Where he sits crowned in his masters spight.
incorrect_answers: But this guy you love, and I swear I care about deeply, I will drag him out of that hateful gaze where he sits against his master's will.

question: O thou dissembling Cub: what wilt thou be
correct_answers: When time hath sow'd a grizzle on thy case?
incorrect_answers: When time has made your hair gray?

question: Or will not else thy craft so quickely grow
correct_answers: That thine owne trip shall be thine ouerthrow:
incorrect_answers: Your own fall will be your undoing.

question: Why do you speake to me, I neuer hurt you:
correct_answers: you drew your sword vpon me without cause, But I bespake you faire, and hurt you not.
incorrect_answers: You pulled your sword on me for no reason, but I spoke to you kindly and didn't harm you.

question:
If a bloody coxcombe be a hurt, you haue
hurt me:
correct_answers: I thinke you set nothing by a bloody Coxecombe.
incorrect_answers: I think you don't value a bloody fool.

question:
O he's drunke sir Toby an houre agone: his eyes
were set at eight i'th morning.
correct_answers: Then he's a Rogue, and a passy measures panyn: I hate a drunken rogue.
incorrect_answers: He's a scoundrel and a disorderly drunk: I can't stand a drunken troublemaker.

question: I am sorry Madam I haue hurt your kinsman:
correct_answers: But had it beene the brother of my blood, I must haue done no lesse with wit and safety.
incorrect_answers: Even if he were my own brother, I would have had to act with just as much cleverness and caution.

question: And so had mine.
correct_answers: And dide that day when Viola from her birth Had numbred thirteene yeares.
incorrect_answers: And died that day when Viola turned thirteen.

question: And dide that day when Viola from her birth Had numbred thirteene yeares.
correct_answers: O that record is liuely in my soule, He finished indeed his mortall acte That day that made my sister thirteene yeares.
incorrect_answers: That memory is vivid in my soul; he passed away the day my sister turned thirteen.

question: If nothing lets to make vs happie both, But this my masculine vsurp'd attyre
correct_answers: Do not embrace me, till each circumstance, Of place, time, fortune, do co-here and iumpe That I am Viola, which to confirme, Ile bring you to a Captaine in this Towne, Where lye my maiden weeds: by whose gentle helpe, I was preseru'd to serue this Noble Count: All the occurrence of my fortune since Hath beene betweene this Lady, and this Lord.
incorrect_answers: Don't hug me yet. Let's first make sure all the details of place, time, and events match up to confirm that I am Viola. I'll take you to a captain in this town who has my clothes from when I was saved to serve this noble count. Everything that has happened to me since has been between this lady and this lord.

question: So comes it Lady, you haue beene mistooke
correct_answers: But Nature to her bias drew in that.
incorrect_answers: But nature corrected itself.

question: You would haue bin contracted to a Maid
correct_answers: Nor are you therein (by my life) deceiu'd, You are betroth'd both to a maid and man.
incorrect_answers: You're not mistaken, I swear. You're engaged to both a maiden and a man.

question: Be not amaz'd, right noble is his blood
correct_answers: If this be so, as yet the glasse seemes true, I shall haue share in this most happy wracke, Boy, thou hast saide to me a thousand times, Thou neuer should'st loue woman like to me.
incorrect_answers: If this is true, as it seems to be, I might have a part in this joyful chaos. Boy, you've told me a thousand times that you'd never love a woman the way you love me.

question: And all those sayings, will I ouer sweare
correct_answers: And all those swearings keepe as true in soule, As doth that Orbed Continent, the fire, That seuers day from night.
incorrect_answers: And all those promises are kept as genuinely as the sun that separates day from night.

question: Giue me thy hand,
correct_answers: And let me see thee in thy womans weedes.
incorrect_answers: And let me see you in women's clothes.

question: The Captaine that did bring me first on shore
correct_answers: Hath my Maides garments: he vpon some Action
incorrect_answers: She's wearing my maid's clothes; he's doing something.

question: He shall inlarge him: fetch Maluolio hither,
correct_answers: And yet alas, now I remember me, They say poore Gentleman, he's much distract.
incorrect_answers: And yet, oh no, I remember now, they say the poor guy is very disturbed.

question: Open't, and read it.
correct_answers: Looke then to be well edified, when the Foole deliuers the Madman.
incorrect_answers: Expect to be thoroughly enlightened when the fool presents the madman.

question: Prethee reade i'thy right wits.
correct_answers: So I do Madona: but to reade his right wits, is to reade thus: therefore, perpend my Princesse, and giue eare.
incorrect_answers: Yes, my lady, but to understand his true state of mind, you need to read it like this: so listen carefully, my princess.

question: Haue you your Fathers leaue? / What sayes Pollonius?
correct_answers: He hath my Lord: I do beseech you giue him leaue to go.
incorrect_answers: Yes, my lord. Please, let him go.

question: How is it that the Clouds still hang on you?
correct_answers: Not so my Lord, I am too much i'th' Sun.
incorrect_answers: No, my Lord, I'm getting too much attention.

question: By what it fed on; and yet within a month?
correct_answers: Let me not thinke on't: Frailty, thy name is woman.
incorrect_answers: I can't bear to think about it: Women are so weak.

question: But what is your affaire in Elsenour?
correct_answers: Wee'l teach you to drinke deepe, ere you depart.
incorrect_answers: We'll make sure you know how to drink properly before you leave.

question: Very like, very like: staid it long?
correct_answers: While one with moderate hast might tell a hun-(dred.
incorrect_answers: While someone moving at an average pace could count to a hundred.

question: What ist Ophelia he hath said to you?
correct_answers: So please you, somthing touching the L. Hamlet.
incorrect_answers: If you don't mind, it's about Lord Hamlet.

question: The Ayre bites shrewdly: is it very cold?
correct_answers: It is a nipping and an eager ayre.
incorrect_answers: The air is sharp and biting.

question: What if it tempt you toward the Floud my Lord?
correct_answers: Or to the dreadfull Sonnet of the Cliffe,
incorrect_answers: Or to the terrifying roar of the cliff,

question: Oh all you host of Heauen! Oh Earth; what els?
correct_answers: And shall I couple Hell? Oh fie: hold my heart; And you my sinnewes, grow not instant Old;
incorrect_answers: And should I link myself with Hell? Oh no: stay strong, my heart; And you, my muscles, don’t suddenly age;

question: But beare me stiffely vp: Remember thee?
correct_answers: I, thou poore Ghost, while memory holds a seate In this distracted Globe: Remember thee?
incorrect_answers: I, poor ghost, as long as I have a memory in this troubled mind: Remember you?

question: I, thou poore Ghost, while memory holds a seate In this distracted Globe: Remember thee?
correct_answers: Yea, from the Table of my Memory, Ile wipe away all triuiall fond Records, All sawes of Bookes, all formes, all presures past, That youth and obseruation coppied there; And thy Commandment all alone shall liue Within the Booke and Volume of my Braine, Vnmixt with baser matter; yes, yes, by Heauen:
incorrect_answers: Sure, I'll erase all unnecessary memories and old notions, and only your commandment will remain in my mind, untouched by any trivial thoughts. Yes, I swear by Heaven.

question: How now Ophelia, what's the matter?
correct_answers: Alas my Lord, I haue beene so affrighted.
incorrect_answers: Oh my Lord, I was so scared.

question: With what, in the name of Heauen?
correct_answers: My Lord, as I was sowing in my Chamber,
incorrect_answers: My Lord, while I was sewing in my room,

question: What haue you giuen him any hard words of late?
correct_answers: No my good Lord: but as you did command,
incorrect_answers: No, my good Lord, but just as you ordered.

question: Say Voltumand, what from our Brother Norwey?
correct_answers: Most faire returne of Greetings, and Desires.
incorrect_answers: I warmly return your greetings and good wishes.

question: O Iephta Iudge of Israel, what a Treasure had'st thou?
correct_answers: What a Treasure had he, my Lord?
incorrect_answers: What kind of treasure did he have, my Lord?

question: What a Treasure had he, my Lord?
correct_answers: Why one faire Daughter, and no more, The which he loued passing well.
incorrect_answers: Why did he have only one beautiful daughter, whom he loved very much?

question: Am I not i'th'right old Iephta?
correct_answers: If you call me Iephta my Lord, I haue a daughter that I loue passing well.
incorrect_answers: If you call me Jephtha, my Lord, I have a daughter whom I love very much.

question: Am I a Coward? Who calles me Villaine? breakes my pate a-crosse?
correct_answers: Pluckes off my Beard, and blowes it in my face?
incorrect_answers: You're pulling out my beard and blowing it in my face?

question: O what a Noble minde is heere o're-throwne?
correct_answers: The Courtiers, Soldiers, Schollers: Eye, tongue, sword, Th'expectansie and Rose of the faire State, The glasse of Fashion, and the mould of Forme, Th'obseru'd of all Obseruers, quite, quite downe. Haue I of Ladies most deiect and wretched, That suck'd the Honie of his Musicke Vowes.
incorrect_answers: The courtiers, soldiers, and scholars: the eyes, tongues, and swords of the kingdom, the epitome of style and form, admired by all observers, are now completely fallen. I, of all the ladies most sorrowful and miserable, who believed his sweet promises, am devastated.

question: I meane, my Head vpon your Lap?
correct_answers: Do you thinke I meant Country matters?
incorrect_answers: Do you think I meant something dirty?

question: Do you thinke I meant Country matters?
correct_answers: That's a faire thought to ly between Maids legs
incorrect_answers: That's a nice idea to keep between a woman's legs.

question: Ophe.	What meanes this, my Lord?
correct_answers: Ham.	Marry this is Miching Malicho, that meanes	Mischeefe.
incorrect_answers: This play is sneaky and up to no good.

question: Ophe.	Belike this shew imports the Argument of the	Play?
correct_answers: Ham.	We shall know by these Fellowes: the Players cannot	keepe counsell, they'l tell all.
incorrect_answers: We'll find out from these guys; actors can't keep secrets, they'll spill everything.

question: Ophe.	Will they tell vs what this shew meant?
correct_answers: Ham.	I, or any shew that you'l shew him. Bee not	you asham'd to shew, hee'l not shame to tell you what	it meanes.
incorrect_answers: Yeah, or any show you put on for him. Don't be embarrassed to show it; he won't hesitate to explain what it means.

question: Madam, how like you this Play?
correct_answers: The Lady protests to much me thinkes.
incorrect_answers: I think the lady is overreacting.

question: Haue you heard the Argument, is there no Offence in't?
correct_answers: No, no, they do but iest, poyson in iest, no Offence i'th'world.
incorrect_answers: No, no, they’re just joking, the poison is a joke, no harm meant.

question: Good my Lord, what is your cause of distemper?
correct_answers: You do freely barre the doore of your owne Libertie, if you deny your greefes to your Friend.
incorrect_answers: If you keep your troubles from your friend, you're shutting the door on your own freedom.

question: But to confront the visage of Offence?
correct_answers: And what's in Prayer, but this two-fold force,
incorrect_answers: And what is prayer but this double power

question: Now Mother, what's the matter?
correct_answers: Hamlet, thou hast thy Father much offended.
incorrect_answers: Hamlet, you've really upset your father.

question: What Gertrude? How do's Hamlet?
correct_answers: Mad as the Seas, and winde, when both contend Which is the Mightier, in his lawlesse fit Behinde the Arras, hearing something stirre, He whips his Rapier out, and cries a Rat, a Rat, And in his brainish apprehension killes The vnseene good old man.
incorrect_answers: He's as crazy as a stormy sea, and in his wild madness, he heard something move behind the curtain. He drew his sword, shouted "A rat, a rat!" and, in his frenzy, killed the unseen old man.

question: What haue you done my Lord with the dead body?
correct_answers: Compounded it with dust, whereto 'tis Kinne.
incorrect_answers: Mixed it with dust, which is its kind.

question: Take you me for a Spundge, my Lord?
correct_answers: I sir, that sokes vp the Kings Countenance, his Rewards, his Authorities (but such Officers do the King best seruice in the end. He keepes them like an Ape in the corner of his iaw, first mouth'd to be last swallowed, when he needes what you haue glean'd, it is but squeezing you, and Spundge you shall be dry againe.
incorrect_answers: Yes, sir, I'm the one who flatters the King, benefiting from his favors and power (though such officers serve the King best in the long run). He keeps them like a bit of food in his cheek, chews on them a bit before swallowing, and when he needs what you've gathered, he just squeezes you and you’ll be used up and dry again.

question: What are they that would speake with me?
correct_answers: Saylors sir, they say they haue Letters for you.
incorrect_answers: Sailors, sir. They say they have letters for you.

question: From Hamlet? Who brought them?
correct_answers: Saylors my Lord they say, I saw them not.
incorrect_answers: Sailors, my Lord—they said they saw them, but I didn't.

question: What should this meane? Are all the rest come backe?
correct_answers: Or is it some abuse? Or no such thing?
incorrect_answers: Is it a trick? Or is there nothing to worry about?

question: There's another: why might not that bee the Scull of a Lawyer?
correct_answers: where be his Quiddits now? his Quillets? his Cases? his Tenures, and his Tricks? why doe's he suffer this rude knaue now to knocke him about the Sconce with a dirty Shouell, and will not tell him of his Action of Battery? hum. This fellow might be in's time a great buyer of Land, with his Statutes, his Recognizances, his Fines, his double Vouchers, his Recoueries: Is this the fine of his Fines, and the recouery of his Recoueries, to haue his fine Pate full of fine Dirt? will his Vouchers vouch him no more of his Purchases, and double ones too, then the length and breadth of a paire of Indentures? the very Conueyances of his Lands will hardly lye in this Boxe; and must the Inheritor himselfe haue no more? ha?
incorrect_answers: Where are his clever arguments now? His little legal subtleties? His cases? His property holdings and his tricks? Why does he let this rude fellow hit him on the head with a dirty shovel and not say anything about being assaulted? Hm. This guy might have been a big land buyer in his time, with his statutes, his recognizances, his fines, his double vouchers, his recoveries. Is this the end result of all his fines and recoveries, to have his fine head full of dirt? Can his vouchers guarantee no more of his purchases, even the double ones, than the size of a pair of indentures? The actual deeds to his lands won’t even fit in this box; and is this all the inheritor himself gets? Huh?

question: Is not Parchment made of Sheep-skinnes?
correct_answers: I my Lord, and of Calue-skinnes too.
incorrect_answers: Yes, my Lord, and with calfskin too.

question: I marry, why was he sent into England?
correct_answers: Why, because he was mad; hee shall recouer his wits there; or if he do not, it's no great matter there.
incorrect_answers: Because he went crazy; he'll get his sanity back there. And if he doesn't, it's not a big deal there.

question: How long will a man lie 'ith' earth ere he rot?
correct_answers: Ifaith, if he be not rotten before he die (as we haue many pocky Coarses now adaies, that will scarce hold the laying in) he will last you some eight yeare, or nine yeare. A Tanner will last you nine yeare.
incorrect_answers: Honestly, if he isn't decayed before he dies (like many diseased bodies these days that barely hold together for burial), he'll last about eight or nine years. A tanner will last nine years.

question: Woo't weepe? Woo't fight? Woo't teare thy selfe?
correct_answers: Woo't drinke vp Esile, eate a Crocodile?
incorrect_answers: Will you drink vinegar, eat a crocodile?

question: To outface me with leaping in her Graue?
correct_answers: Be buried quicke with her, and so will I.
incorrect_answers: I'll be buried alive with her, and I mean it.

question: What is the reason that you vse me thus?
correct_answers: I loud' you euer; but it is no matter:
incorrect_answers: I've always loved you, but it doesn't matter.

question: Shall I redeliuer you ee'n so?
correct_answers: To this effect Sir, after what flourish your nature will.
incorrect_answers: Sure thing, sir, however you see fit.

question: Is not this your Son, my Lord?
correct_answers: His breeding Sir, hath bin at my charge.
incorrect_answers: I've been responsible for his upbringing, sir.

question: So young, and so vntender?
correct_answers: So young my Lord, and true.
incorrect_answers: So young, my lord, and honest.

question: Call France, who stirres?
correct_answers: Call Burgundy, Cornwall, and Albanie, With my two Daughters Dowres, digest the third, Let pride, which she cals plainnesse, marry her: I doe inuest you ioyntly with my power, Preheminence, and all the large effects That troope with Maiesty. Our selfe by Monthly course, With reseruation of an hundred Knights, By you to be sustain'd, shall our abode Make with you by due turne, onely we shall retaine The name, and all th'addition to a King: the Sway, Reuennew, Execution of the rest, Beloued Sonnes be yours, which to confirme, This Coronet part betweene you.
incorrect_answers: Get Burgundy, Cornwall, and Albany here. With my two daughters' dowries, handle the third daughter's share. Let her marry for her so-called plainness, which is actually pride. I give you all my authority, power, and all the benefits that come with being royal. My wife and I will take turns living with you each month, keeping a hundred knights supported by you. We will retain the title and honors of a king, but you will manage all other powers, revenue, and duties. My beloved sons, to make this official, share this crown between you.

question: Aloofe from th'intire point, will you haue her?
correct_answers: She is herselfe a Dowrie.
incorrect_answers: She is her own dowry.

question: You know the character to be your Brothers?
correct_answers: If the matter were good my Lord, I durst swear it were his: but in respect of that, I would faine thinke it were not.
incorrect_answers: If the content were good, my Lord, I would swear it was his: but given the circumstances, I would rather believe it wasn't.

question: Has he neuer before sounded you in this busines?
correct_answers: Neuer my Lord. But I haue heard him oft maintaine it to be fit, that Sonnes at perfect age, and Fathers declin'd, the Father should bee as Ward to the Son, and the Sonne manage his Reuennew.
incorrect_answers: Never, my Lord. But I have often heard him say that when sons reach maturity and fathers grow old, the father should become dependent on the son, and the son should manage his father's estate.

question: Edg.	Do you busie your selfe with that?
correct_answers: Bast.	I promise you, the effects he writes of, succeede	vnhappily.
incorrect_answers: I assure you, the things he's predicting will turn out badly.

question: Shall I heare from you anon?
correct_answers: I do serue you in this businesse.
incorrect_answers: I'm helping you with this.

question: What dost thou professe? What would'st thou with vs?
correct_answers: I do profess to be no less than I seem; to serve him truly that will put me in trust, to love him that is honest, to converse with him that is wise and says little, to fear judgement, to fight when I cannot choose, and to eat no fish.
incorrect_answers: I claim to be exactly as I appear; to faithfully serve those who trust me, to love those who are honest, to talk with those who are wise and reserved, to respect judgement, to fight when necessary, and to not eat fish.

question: Do'st thou know me fellow?
correct_answers: No Sir, but you have that in your countenance.
incorrect_answers: No sir, but it's written all over your face.

question: What seruices canst thou do?
correct_answers: I can keepe honest counsaile, ride, run, marre a curious tale in telling it, and deliuer a plaine message bluntly: that which ordinary men are fit for, I am quallified in, and the best of me, is Dilligence.
incorrect_answers: I can keep a secret, ride, run, mess up a good story by telling it, and deliver a straightforward message bluntly. I'm capable of doing what ordinary men can do, and my best quality is diligence.

question: How old art thou?
correct_answers: Not so young Sir to loue a woman for singing, nor so old to dote on her for any thing. I haue yeares on my backe forty eight.
incorrect_answers: I'm not young enough to love a woman just for her singing, nor am I old enough to obsess over her for anything. I'm forty-eight years old.

question: Why came not the slaue backe to me when I call'd him?
correct_answers: Sir, he answered me in the roundest
incorrect_answers: Sir, he gave me a very direct answer.

question: Ha? Saist thou so?
correct_answers: I beseech you pardon me my Lord, if I bee mistaken, for my duty cannot be silent, when I thinke your Highnesse wrong'd.
incorrect_answers: Please forgive me, my Lord, if I'm mistaken, but I can't stay silent when I believe you've been wronged.

question: My Ladies Father?
correct_answers: My Ladies Father? my Lords knaue, you whorson dog, you slaue, you curre.
incorrect_answers: Your father, my Lord? You rotten scoundrel, you worthless dog, you servant, you beast.

question: Do you bandy lookes with me, you Rascall?
correct_answers: Ile not be strucken my Lord.
incorrect_answers: I won't be hit, my Lord.

question: How now my pretty knaue, how dost thou?
correct_answers: Sirrah, you were best take my Coxcombe.
incorrect_answers: Hey, you'd better take my fool's cap.

question: What two Crownes shall they be?
correct_answers: Why after I haue cut the egge i'th'middle and eate vp the meate, the two Crownes of the egge: when thou clouest thy Crownes i'th'middle, and gau'st away both parts, thou boar'st thine Asse on thy backe o're the durt, thou had'st little wit in thy bald crowne, when thou gau'st thy golden one away; if I speake like my selfe in this, let him be whipt that first findes it so.
incorrect_answers: After I’ve eaten the insides of the egg and cut it in half, you gave away both halves and carried the burden yourself. You didn't have much sense when you gave away your valuable crown. If I’m talking nonsense, let the first person who notices it be punished.

question: O God she comes, O hony Nurse what newes?
correct_answers: Hast thou met with him? send thy man away.
incorrect_answers: Have you met with him? Send your assistant away.

question: Now good sweet Nurse: / O Lord, why lookest thou sad?
correct_answers: Though newes, be sad, yet tell them merrily.
incorrect_answers: Even if the news is bad, deliver it cheerfully.

question: Iesu what hast? can you not stay a while?
correct_answers: Do you not see that I am out of breath?
incorrect_answers: Can't you see I'm out of breath?

question: What saies he of our marriage? what of that?
correct_answers: Lord how my head akes, what a head haue I?
incorrect_answers: Oh, my head hurts so much. What's wrong with it?

question: Sweet sweet, sweet Nurse, tell me what saies my Loue?
correct_answers: Your Loue saies like an honest Gentleman,
incorrect_answers: Your love speaks like an honest gentleman.

question: Am I like such a Fellow?
correct_answers: Come, come, thou art as hot a Iacke in thy mood, as any in Italie: and assoone moued to be moodie, and assoone moodie to be mou'd.
incorrect_answers: Come on, you have as quick a temper as anyone in Italy: you're easily angered and just as easily upset.

question: Could you not take some occasion without giuing?
correct_answers: Mercutio thou consort'st with Romeo.
incorrect_answers: Mercutio, you hang out with Romeo.

question: What woulds thou haue with me?
correct_answers: Good King of Cats, nothing but one of your nine liues, that I meane to make bold withall, and as you shall vse me hereafter dry beate the rest of the eight. Will you pluck your Sword out of his Pilcher by the eares? Make hast, least mine be about your eares ere it be out.
incorrect_answers: King of Cats, I just want one of your nine lives, and then I'll deal with the rest. Are you going to draw your sword, or should I hit you first? Hurry up, or my sword will be at your ears before yours is out.

question: What art thou hurt?
correct_answers: I, I, a scratch, a scratch, marry 'tis inough
incorrect_answers: It's just a scratch, just a scratch. Really, it's nothing.

question: He gon in triumph, and Mercutio slaine?
correct_answers: Away to heauen respectiue Lenitie, And fire and Fury, be my conduct now.
incorrect_answers: Forget about mercy, and let rage and fury guide me now.

question: Which way ran he that kild Mercutio?
correct_answers: Tibalt that Murtherer, which way ran he?
incorrect_answers: Where did that murderer Tybalt run off to?

question: Where are the vile beginners of this Fray?
correct_answers: O Noble Prince, I can discouer all
incorrect_answers: Oh noble prince, I can reveal everything.

question: Benuolio, who began this Fray?
correct_answers: Tybalt here slaine, whom Romeo's hand did slay
incorrect_answers: Tybalt is dead, killed by Romeo.

question: Now Nurse, what newes? what hast thou there?
correct_answers: The Cords that Romeo bid thee fetch?
incorrect_answers: The ropes Romeo told you to get?

question: What diuell art thou, That dost torment me thus?
correct_answers: This torture should be roar'd in dismall hell,
incorrect_answers: This torture should be shouted in a dreadful hell,

question: Is Romeo slaughtred? and is Tybalt dead?
correct_answers: My dearest Cozen, and my dearer Lord:
incorrect_answers: My closest cousin and my dearest lord:

question: Will you speake well of him, / That kil'd your Cozen?
correct_answers: Shall I speake ill of him that is my husband?
incorrect_answers: Should I say bad things about my own husband?

question: Where is my Father and my Mother Nurse?
correct_answers: Weeping and wailing ouer Tybalts Coarse,Will you go to them? I will bring you thither.
incorrect_answers: Crying and mourning over Tybalt's body, will you go to them? I'll take you there.

question: Father what newes? / What is the Princes Doome?
correct_answers: What lesse then Doomesday, / Is the Princes Doome?
incorrect_answers: What could be worse than the prince's fate?

question: What lesse then Doomesday, / Is the Princes Doome?
correct_answers: A gentler iudgement vanisht from his lips, Not bodies death, but bodies banishment.
incorrect_answers: He spoke with kindness, not sentencing him to death but to exile.

question: Who knocks so hard? Whence come you? what's your will?
correct_answers: Let me come in, And you shall know my errand: I come from Lady Iuliet.
incorrect_answers: Let me in and I'll tell you why I'm here; I came on behalf of Lady Juliet.

question: Where's my Ladies Lord? where's Romeo?
correct_answers: There on the ground, / With his owne teares made drunke.
incorrect_answers: Lying on the ground, drunk on his own tears.

question: Speak'st thou of Iuliet? how is it with her?
correct_answers: Oh she sayes nothing sir, but weeps and weeps,
incorrect_answers: She doesn’t say anything, sir; she just cries and cries.

question: O thinkest thou we shall euer meet againe?
correct_answers: I doubt it not, and all these woes shall serue
incorrect_answers: I'm sure of it, and all these troubles will help

question: Ho Daughter, are you vp?
correct_answers: Who ist that calls? Is it my Lady Mother.
incorrect_answers: Who's calling? Is it my mom?

question: Is she not downe so late, or vp so early?
correct_answers: What vnaccustom'd cause procures her hither?
incorrect_answers: What unexpected reason brings her here?

question: Euermore weeping for your Cozins death?
correct_answers: What wilt thou wash him from his graue with teares?
incorrect_answers: Are you trying to wash him out of his grave with your tears?

question: What wilt thou wash him from his graue with teares?
correct_answers: And if thou could'st, thou could'st not make him liue.
incorrect_answers: Even if you could, you wouldn't be able to bring him back to life.

question: What Villaine, Madam?
correct_answers: That same Villaine Romeo.
incorrect_answers: That scoundrel Romeo.

question: What are they, beseech your Ladyship?
correct_answers: Well, well, thou hast a carefull Father Child?
incorrect_answers: Well, you have a concerned father, don't you?

question: Madam in happy time, what day is this?
correct_answers: Marry my Child, early next Thursday morne,
incorrect_answers: Sure, my child, early next Thursday morning,

question: How, will she none? doth she not giue vs thanks?
correct_answers: Is she not proud? doth she not count her blest,
incorrect_answers: Isn't she proud? Doesn't she consider herself blessed?

question: O God! / O Nurse, how shall this be preuented?
correct_answers: My Husband is on earth, my faith in heauen,
incorrect_answers: My husband is here on earth, but my loyalty is in heaven.

question: You say you do not know the Ladies mind?
correct_answers: Vneuen is the course, I like it not.
incorrect_answers: The plan feels off; I don't like it.

question: Come you to make confession to this Father?
correct_answers: To answere that, I should confesse to you.
incorrect_answers: To answer that, I have to admit something to you.

question: Are you at leisure, Holy Father now, Or shall I come to you at euening Masse?
correct_answers: My leisure serues me pensiue daughter now.
incorrect_answers: I have time for you now, my thoughtful daughter.

question: How now my headstrong, / Where haue you bin gadding?
correct_answers: Where I haue learnt me to repent the sin / Of disobedient opposition, / To you, and your behests, and am enioyn'd / By holy Lawrence, to fall prostrate here / To beg your pardon. Pardon, I beseech you, / Henceforward I am euermore rul'd by you.
